Hmm, my previous message hasn't shown up yet...  Tonight(Wed.) you can try
Robert Fripp at Slim's.  Check with Bass to make sure it isn't sold out.
He's a guitarist who has become legendary among progressive and ambient
music fans. Masada, featuring the almost as legendary noisester John Zorn
will be playing Feb 5 at the Stork Club in Oakland. Laurie Anderson is
performing at Zellerbach Hall in Berkeley Feb 15-17.  Frog-S, weird old
school new wave, is playing Feb 5 at Cat's Grill.  Also look for UBZUB, just
plain weird, and dijeradooist(sp?) Stephen Kent or his group Trance Mission. 
I will continue to post non-rave events of interest to sfravers as long as
no one minds.

David

Someone posted a few daze ago asking about live ambient/trance/noise 
events in the Bay Area(if memory serves...).  I would highly recommend 
Robert Fripp's Soundscapes at Slim's tonite...  Fripp is a guitarist and 
progressive rock pioneer who has worked with Brian Eno and many others.  
He's reached god-like status in ambient circles lately.  If you go (I 
rarely go out on weeknights) you may want to pick up a ticket from BA$$ 
in case it sells out (or to avoid disappointment if it already has).  
I'll try to post more non-rave events of interest to ravers (and people 
who subscribe to this list but don't like being called a raver :-)), if no 
one minds...

Hi All,

Here's the info line message I recorded for friday:

Thank you for calling the Pre-Rave Info Line.  You can skip this
announcement at any time by pressing the # key.

Friday, Feb 3rd, there will be a pre-rave movie before the Kundalini rave.
It's an austrailian double feature of "Ballroom Dancing" and "Priscilla:
Queen Of The Desert."  The location is in Berkeley at the UC Theatre around
6:45 pm.

The UC Theatre is located at 2036 University Ave. The nearest cross street
is Shattuck.  Their phone number is 510.843.6267.  "Priscilla: Queen Of The
Desert" starts showing at 7:30 and "Strictly Ballroom" starts showing at
9:30.  Leave a message if you want a seat saved for you.

Look for me, I'm Purple Tiger.  On me, or near me, will be a flourescent
orange cap that sayz "Wired" on the front.  After I sit down in the theater
I'll hang the cap on the end of the row, but I don't know if it will be on
the left end or the right end.  If all else fails, call the info line and
leave a message, and then wait for me to run up to the phone to answer the
page.

If you get lost or need more directions, call the voice mail with a number I
can reach you at.  The voice mail calls my pager so I can reach you pretty
quickly anytime day or night.

I hope to see you.  If you have suggestions for future events or want to
help me organize new events, please leave a message.

Pre-Rave Info Line 415.522.3848
UC Theatre         510.843.6267
Kundalini          415.337.4337

Thanks to Milton and the E-Bee for the suggestion.

From: Phuture@aol.com
Received: by mail04.mail.aol.com
	(1.37.109.11/16.2) id AA192485210; Thu, 2 Feb 1995 12:13:30 -0500
Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 12:13:30 -0500
Message-Id: <950202121218_11010562@aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: HeadTravel:Enhanced Audio CD
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Anyone know anything about this - where to get it, who did it, how to contact
them?  It was reviewed briefly in the JUNGLE issue of XLR8R.  Its one of the
first of its kind and guess what, it was done by a small, independent SF
label and its got music/pics/video from our beloved local scene.  

Enhanced Audio or CD+ is a new CD Audio/CDROM format, essentially a mix of
the two i.e. it plays like  a regular CD in your CD Player but if you  drop
it in a MAc or a PC with a CDROM drive you get lots of cool extra stuff like
video clips, lyrics, whatever.  This has been possible for a while, its the
standard that's new and since its being backed by Sony and Phillips it looks
like it will happen.

phuture

ZIMMERMANJ@AOL.COM

From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb  3 13:16:27 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id NAA13870; Fri, 3 Feb 1995 13:16:27 -0800
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA13863; Fri, 3 Feb 1995 13:16:24 -0800

	id AA23536; Fri, 3 Feb 95 13:16:14 PST
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA06036; Fri, 3 Feb 95 13:16:12 PST
Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 13:16:12 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9502032116.AA06036@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Come/Unity report
Cc: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM, jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had a lot of fun at Come/Unity.  If any party has managed to
consistantly embody the SF HouseNation vibe, this is it.  It got 
pretty crowded, but just right.  Great overall energy and friendliness, 
comfy chillroom w/Dubtribe and pretty good sets by the DJs.  Like all
CU's I've been to, the party really soared during the last 3 hours.  My 
only gripe is the 4:15 end time.   

Come/Unity is one of those parties where the separation between
party-throwers and party-attendees breaks down.  At various times
I found myself dancing next to to Simon, Garth, Carlos and Tracy.
It really helps the we're-all-in-this-together feeling when some of
the musical shamans are right there beside you.

It think it is also important to occasionally let people in the scene
know that they are appreciated when they do something we like.  So
whether it's giving $5 to a renegade party, or complimenting a DJ on
hir set, or just telling a fellow raver that you like their style; it's 
not so much about feeding egos as much as it's about the recycling of 
positive energy.

It's an awkward problem for the rave/house scene - the ego thing. On one 
hand, big egos cab produce self-centered attitudes and a sense of 
divisiveness.  On the other hand, it seems that some ego is required for 
people to feel that they've got what it takes to organize a party, become 
a DJ, communicate a vision, i.e. help make things happen.  I guess I see 
ego as a tool; what really matters is how you use it.

So I finally got a chance to thank Simon for keeping Come/Unity going 
(he pretty much took over after Malachy's accident 2 year ago).  I also 
congatulated Carlos on the success of Area 51. He tells me that another 
one is being planned, early spring, new location.  

Chatted with Tracy for a little while. She's a little bit "weirded out" 
by the attention her DJing has been getting.  But in a good way.  She 
confessed to now being completely devoted to the art.  Yeah.

Anyway, if you find yourself in need of a "sure thing" party wise, 
Come/Unity on the first Wednesday of every month is still worth
taking a day off from work for. :)

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


----- End Included Message -----

Ack!  I just got back in town on Thursday after being gone for a week,
only to find out Derek had to leave on business for two weeks before
being able to put out a calendar.  Well, here's all I've been able to
gather from last week's list and the one post made this week - if
people have fliers for other parties please post them, and if there
are any more for tomorrow night I'll make an addendum post to the
calendar list.

Both of tonight's non-weeklies look promising musically - Venus will
probably be smaller and low-key.  

Again, let us know if there are more!  Even if they're not for this
weekend, as I'll be doing this next week as well.

	Brian

On Mon, 30 Jan 1995, Chris Beaumont wrote:

> 
> This is a great idea..
> You should talk to Steven Dunifer's lawyer and figure out a way to
> proceed.  There is no reason why people should have to pay six figures
> in order to start a small community-based radio station.
> My guess is that you could, if you played your cards right.. overturn
> the laws regulating small radio stations..
> Especially now that the Newtroids want to get rid of NPR..
> community radio is really important..
> 
> >How about non-stop rave radio in the Bay area? I'm sure there is
> more than ample audience for a station that could program rave in all its
> subgenres from ambient to gabber. And if it can't be done via usual
> methods, then why not pirate rave radio? - all it would take is a couple
> of techies, some radio widgets, local dj's and nerves o' steal. BTW the
> recent Free Radio Berkely / FCC court ruling seems to have created a
> precedent for other's to get in on the independant radio act. And then we
> would all have something to listen to on those quiet evenings. A great
> project for a telecommunications major or other subsidised individuals. 
> DD
> 
> -Chris

The Future of * rave * culture:

1.  No reference to current, or future technologies (will we focus on mUsic)

2.  No debates with "zippies" (they will be extinct)

3.  125 BPM (not faster or slower, a perfect speed:  the go between speed)

4.  It will be very dark and minimal (turn off the fuckin stadium lights)

5.  It will be hot and sweaty (long live the sweatbox)

6.  Techno will be techno, House will be house ( the mixture sounds really
cheezy these days!)

7.  Disco will be disco, Techno will be techno (the mixture sounds really
cheezy these days!)

8.  We will stop Creating new Genres of Techno  every fuckin' time someone
does something new & innovative.  ( what's the latest one?  Deep tribal trip
dance hop jungle?)

9.  We will stop using Kai's Power tools on fliers.  ( A&A sucks big fat
dicks)

10.  We will stop giving props to people who don't deserve it.  (Hardkiss
dorks especially)

11.  Blah Blah blah..


JOnathan

Precedence: bulk

Once again community comes through.  Community has been a party that 
consistantly has high energy and great music.  Last night there were 
times when the oneness of the shared energy made me feel such joy, that 
unfortunately it is beyond what I can describe in this post.  But I have 
a feeling many of you understand what I'm referring  to.  At the raves, 
as with all good raves our communication  is so good there is no need to 
communicate.  There is already a mutual understanding that is shared 
through our "vibe", our dance, our love for the music and one another and 
everything else there up to the point that I don't totally desolve into 
the oneness and beauty of all that there is. Sometimes I feel like  I 
go past that point into the oneness which just happens to include my 
separateness and all other separateness.  When I'm there there is 
incredible beauty in all our separateness, because our separateness 
combined takes us to the incredable beauty of our oneness.  I think an 
easier way of saying all this is there are times at raves when I feel in 
love.  
 
                          peter

order on the chaos, which if you study history, has never worked.  What
happens in the future will be a natural evolution.  Maybe we don't want to
dance to music that's as slow as 125 bpm's, ever think of that?

In article <199502051504.HAA12360@netcom6.netcom.com>,
larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching) wrote:

> DJs: Aquarius , Half , and Theta*Blip 
> ( NOT Theta Bret , as I missheard a few nights ago ).

Theta*Blip, otherwise know as Phillip, the guy who is always handing out
cards for Venus and Aumbient Eight House.  He dresses very uniquely in a
sort of cyber-gothe style suggestive of child like innocense.  He wears at
at least one piece of rubber clothing, for example, a shiny rubber shirt
with 1 inch soft rubber spikes sticking out a 1 inch intervals.  He wears
his hair in black dreds and has an asexual cast to his features.  He spins
real nice, is always friendly, and looks cool too.

I've only had one conversation with Theta*Blip, but its one of
my favorites.  I happened at Nag Champa with my friend Chris.

Theta*Blip: Hi
Chris and Me: Hi
TB: (to me) What's your name?
Me: Purple Tiger
(Theta nods his head indicating appreciation)
TB: (to Chris) What's your name?
Chris: Chris
(Theta looks to me and says:)
TB: Whoa!  Someone sure wimped out in the name department!
(Chris looks hurt, I laugh)
Chris:  (meekly) Well, on the net I spell it "X" "R" "I" "S"

Later on Chris says to me rather indignatly, "Well, I guess I have
to go home and tell my parents they wimped out."

In truth though, Chris wasn't hurt, he was just playing a bit.  Its
an inside joke with me and Chris now, whenever we hear someone's name,
one or the other of us will repeat Theta*Blip's remark.

--
< Purple Tiger (ptiger@crl.com) >
                       "Wow!" - Milton And The E-Bee

Hi,

Well, you may remeber me, you may not. I was subscribed to this list a few
months ago, while living in Scotland. After meeting my true love, a native of
the bay area, I emmigrated, and now we're renting a house in Moss Beach,
about twenty miles south of lovely San Francisco.

Before leaving, I collected a few phone numbers, which I promptly forgot in
the move, and so have been cast adrift from any connections since arriving
here in America. Until just now, that is. On a borrowed 386 with a 2400
modem, and an AOL sampler disk, I've managed to get connected (prior attempts
to purchase a machine have been hampered by lack of credit...) 

Things have been great since the move, I'm in love with the area in general,
and San Francisco in particular. Landing a job took a little while, but I'm
now working in Palo Alto, at the top of University.

Its great to be back on-line, as a way to meet people over here, and a chance
to find the choice places for a good night out (my previous attempt at a
night in San Francisco left a lot to be desired. )

Hello to everyone, and I'll look forward to talking, hopefully meeting 
, and partying with some of you here on the list,

Gary

I am asking anyone who can to help me out in assisting a fellow raver. 
Here's the story: After Tribal Funk in November Chuck Raeder and two 
friends of his drove from cow palace to Pleasant hill, Chuck drove Katies 
car to his place and then Katie and Jessica drove on to Martinez.  
Jessica was driving and after having been up all night was very tired. 
She fell asleep at the wheel and crashed the car. Katie was killed.  In 
the hospital they found e in Jessica's blood, although she hadn't done 
any that night. The D.A. is now charging Jessica with manslaughter.  I am 
asking anyone who can to help out with this.  Her lawyer doesn't know 
anything about e, so I have done a literature search on all recent 
journal publications which I am going to give to Chuck. If anyone has 
any legal experience with this sort of thing, help would be greatly 
appreciated. Justice is not being served in this case and help is greatly 
needed.  Katie's family does not hold Jessica responsible and doesn't 
want charges pressed, but the D.A. does.  

Personal mail responses are fine. Thanks to everyone in advance. 

Peace

Andrew Lawson


From sfraves-owner  Sun Feb  5 12:47:51 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA11360; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 12:47:51 -0800
Received: from B17.Catch22.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA11350; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 12:47:44 -0800
Received: (from jchrysler@localhost) by B17.Catch22.COM (8.6.9/8.6.9) id MAA19817; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 12:51:37 -0800
Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 12:51:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Jesus Chrysler <jchrysler@Catch22.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Fripp show
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950205124955.19735A-100000@B17.Catch22.COM>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It was cool... It was him and three of his students from his workshop, and 
they alternated between Fripp doing spacey music with just him and a bunch of 
effects stuff (which was totally cool in quad sound:  he made the tunes spin 
around the room and play off of eachother in the most alarming and fantastic 
ways), and the three students and sometimes Fripp playing beautiful 
acoustic guitar.                                                                        <
                                                                               <
At the beginning and the end of the show the four of them came out into 
the audience and played Discipline with variations on un-pickupped acoustic 
guitars (so that we had to be really quiet).  It was beautiful.  However, 
I think that the site, although really good, could have been better in that 
there was constant noise from the staff working there, and it was just a 
little too big.  The only thing was that during Fripp's  last ambient set he 
walked off the stage after a bit, and left all his equpiment going... still 
playing a loop.  It was nice for a bit, but it got boring, and after about 15 
minutes of the same loop, and still no Fripp, the confused crowd started 
applauding.  I should say confused and annoyed.  After a bit, the music faded, 
and then the 3 guys came out and played a song, looked at eachother 
questioningly, and then left the stage.  Everybody applauds anticipating an 
encore.  The crowd applauds for something like ten minutes.  I had given up, 
and started wondering what was going on... Finally fifteen minutes after the 
end of the show, the four of them come out again and do the final number in 
the middle of the crowd.                                                       <
                                                                               <
It was really cool, but what was up at the end.  Very odd.

...While mascarading at night as the winged AVENGER!!!!
	LSD:  melts in your mind, not in your hand...

This is just too much fun to pass up :)

On 1 Feb 1995, isao wrote:
> The Future of * rave * culture:
> 
> 1.  No reference to current, or future technologies (will we focus on mUsic)

But music and technology have always been inseparable - technology as 
"how much RAM does your sampler have" may become unimportant, but the 
pursuit of better ways to create music will always be a part of it.

> 2.  No debates with "zippies" (they will be extinct)

They'll just have a different name. :)

> 3.  125 BPM (not faster or slower, a perfect speed:  the go between speed)

Eh, I know lots of people who think it's way too slow, but this could be 
the beginning of a flame war we've already had... regardless, a wide 
variety of styles and speeds and types of music will continue to exist, 
and this should be seen as a Good Thing.

> 4.  It will be very dark and minimal (turn off the fuckin stadium lights)

Actually I'd prefer to see raves be daytime events, where we can SEE each 
other dancing and having fun and interacting - I can close my bedroom 
door and close off all the lights if I want to be dark and minimal.

> 5.  It will be hot and sweaty (long live the sweatbox)

Outdoor parties are rarely this... 

> 6.  Techno will be techno, House will be house ( the mixture sounds really
> cheezy these days!)
>
> 7.  Disco will be disco, Techno will be techno (the mixture sounds really
> cheezy these days!)
>
> 8.  We will stop Creating new Genres of Techno  every fuckin' time someone
> does something new & innovative.  ( what's the latest one?  Deep tribal trip
> dance hop jungle?)

Labels will become meaningless in the future (as if they had any real 
meaning now - ha).  Music will be typed by references alone - "this is a 
lot like this other piece, particularly in melody and bassline..."

> 9.  We will stop using Kai's Power tools on fliers.  ( A&A sucks big fat
> dicks)

I think someone's a graphic artist :)

	Brian


OnNow: Pentatonic "Anthology".  A better Orbital than Orbital.
WWW Engineers needed for HotWired!  Enquire within.

responsible. I myself see no justice served if the victum's family; isn't 
interested in pressing charges. There has alrealy been one life lost as a 
result of  a human being making a mistake. I see no point in putting 
someone through the criminal justice sysrtem; who is already no doubt 
feeling extreme distrogte and gulity. Accidents happened; people die; I 
would like to see the trauma minized to all the parties involved. If you 
can provide me with a e-mail address I would be happy to write the DA on 
behalf of Kattie. But again the most important thing is that the victum's 
family speak out and in support of Kattie; both to the judge and the DA.

From sfraves-owner  Sun Feb  5 20:46:39 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id UAA00828; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 20:46:39 -0800
Received: from netcom8.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA00816; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 20:46:35 -0800
Received: by netcom8.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id OAA10894; Sat, 4 Feb 1995 14:52:39 -0800
From: larryc@netcom.com (Larry Ching)
Message-Id: <199502042252.OAA10894@netcom8.netcom.com>
Subject: BSP: Venus ( Last Night )
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 14:52:39 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3706      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

In his original message , Ethan wrote:
> Date: Fri,  3 Feb 95 12:01 PST
> From: nrg@ultima.org (ethan miller)
> Subject: BSP: Venus Tonite...
> 
> Greetings all, tonite at Venus:
> Alex , Ethan , Mikey
> 650 4th St. @ Brannan     $5        Don't know about age issues.
> Should be fun :)     > take it easy      > ethan

 No lie about the "Should be fun" part! Since I got there early , I
was able to dance on a clean floor with lots of empty room to bop around 
in. Clean , smoke-free air , and great music from Ethan to start the
evening with.

  I had originally planned to go to Kundalini , but Ethan's post made 
me alter my plans - I would stop over for awhile at Venus , then cruise
past Kundalini (which I guess was at Caeser's at 3140 Mission).  

 Well, I almost lost faith in finding Venus! It was behind a humble looking
,well lit bar - the space was actually a restaurant , but with the chairs
and tables cleared away to open up a dance area. ( Unfortunetly , I didn't 
write down the name of the bar or the restaurant  but it's at the corner
of 4th and Bluxome , between Brannan and Townsend ). Access to the
restaurant was through the bar.

 Nice decorations - day-glo starburst mobiles , faux cloth columns that
surprised one with their hollowness , paper pyramids with dayglo flames
and the eye of god(?) on each face . The orange speaker bins with the 
yellow and green horned figures were familier - someone told me they
were from SPAZ. 

 The music coming from the speaker bins was excellent! After Ethan was a
DJ I don't think I've heard before - DJ Theta Bret (??? - Ethan , please 
correct the spelling of this if it's wrong ). He had an great collection
of hard spacey trance , marred only somewhat by the amps being overdriven
a bit. Despite the slight amount of fuzz , I was really getting into
the music. I would stop my dancing and just sit and listen to what was
being played.

 Now , if the party is being held in a venue like a bar or club , where
the proprieters make money via alcohol sales , I usually buy a drink
to keep them happy and to encourage then to have the party again - and,
hey , I like a drink every once and awhile! So , I ordered a screwdriver,
for that healthy orange juice and the relatively clean alcohol. I'm 
telling you folks this , so you know that I wasn't under the influence 
of anything psychedelic ...

 Anyway , after the usual effects of the screwdriver had worn off , I 
notice a nice spacey/tranciness that stayed with me throughout the time
I was there. At one point , I was laying on the floor near the wall 
behind the left speaker stack . As the music from the main stacks and
the DJ's monitors vibrated my head and body , I did some "arm dancing" -
moving my upper limbs to the glorious vibrations all around me. So
nice it was.

 Ethan cleaned up the sound by adjusting the levels during the second 
half of DJ Theta Bret's set. Even better! By this time , a lot more folks
had shown up. I believe the good Capt. Crunch was the second guest to
arrive , and then Video Mike , Chris (? - 1st DJ at the recent Atomic
Dog - damn, I wish I was better at remembering names ! ), and a bunch
of other folks.

 I finally left at about 12:45 , with the party seemingly well in progress.
I cruised past Kundalini , but with no parking space , tired legs ,
and possiblity of a crowded , smokey space, I decided to pass. Anyway , it
would have been another $15. SO , I went to Sparky's , ate , and drove 
back home to Sunnyvale.

 -------------------------------------

 My apologies to all the folks who were expecting me at Kundalini! I hope 
you folks had as much fun as I did!!os

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

 PS - What does "BSP" mean?

From sfraves-owner  Sun Feb  5 20:55:33 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id UAA01240; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 20:55:33 -0800
Received: from netcom8.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA01230; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 20:55:28 -0800
Received: by netcom8.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id FAA05725; Sat, 4 Feb 1995 05:41:29 -0800
Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 05:41:29 -0800
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199502041341.FAA05725@netcom8.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Venus
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

			Venus Report 
			============
			     By
			Cap'n Crunch
				    
I finally got the chance to check out Venus.    I'm amazed totally
with the energy and wonderful venue.   What really surprised me was
that so few people knew about it.    This was it's THIRD week at
this new venue,  and if you're looking for a great place to dance
to the high energy acid trance,   I would recommend you check this
out.   It's got MY seal of approval and it wasn't that smokey,
as long as people wouldn't smoke in front of the fan.

I estimate the venue could easily hold 150 high energy ravers,
with a bar in the front,  and the dance area in the back.

The venue is essentially a cafe,   although there IS a bar,  folks
under 21 are allowed in the back.    The cost is certainly a bargain,

The bartender is really cool,  and loves the energy and the business
it brings to his bar.    When I Asked for a coke,   he only charged
me a $1 for a HUGE class of Cola.

I told him that I would like to see 100 more ravers in here next week,
and he said "Great!".   So check it out,  next time you go out Fridays.

Without giving it's actual location (Call the Info line - 406-2124),   
it is not obvious when you approach this place,   but it is THERE,  
pumping out the most insane Hard Acid Techno Trance,  and a few more 
RAVE buzzwords thrown in for good measure.  :-)

When I arrived,  DJ Theta Blip was spinning the most insane hard acid
trance since Atomicon.    The SPAZ sound system,  although small,  provided
adequate audio energy into my brain.   Although I wasn't frying my brains
out,   I really went to a wonderful trancey state,  hopping around like
an idiot with a huge grin on my face for hours at a time,  or standing
in front of the fa to cool off.   :-)

Alex spun next,   and his music was a lot more varied,  but quite "different"
and certainly danceable.

Ethan finally went on,   at this point,  the BPM's were about 135-140
range,  and he put on the most insane trance I though imaginable...
I just couldn't get off the dance floor.    There was a voice inside
my head that said "Help!!  I'm trapped by this music,  and it won't
let go!",  so was bashed around by this music for what seemed hours
and hours.    Eventually,   the music started to fade,   the bursts
of music shifting between the speakers,   had me chasing the notes
all over the dance floor until they were ALL GONE!!

At that time,  dead silance,  and a reminder from the promoter,   "please
bring more people",  then we can stay longer,  till 6am or later....

So,  it's a mystry which rave I'll go to Sat night...  But without getting
an updated calander,   I'll have to check around wherever it is,  I'll
see you all there... Ready to Zap you with my luv phasers...

Till next time...  
C. Crunch

From sfraves-owner  Sun Feb  5 21:37:16 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id VAA02924; Sun, 5 Feb 1995 21:37:16 -0800

  (5.65c/IDA-1.5 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>); Sun, 5 Feb 1995 21:36:03 -0800
Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 21:36:03 -0800
Message-Id: <199502060536.AA26404@mail.crl.com>
X-Sender: davidmin@mail.crl.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Version 1.4.3
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: davidmin@crl.com (David Minuk)
Subject: Weekend report:  Kundalini and Kinetic's energy
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

It was another great weekend.  Kicked it off with Kundalini at Cesar's.
Upon entering, I was suprised to find myself being frisked by none other
than an x-roommate of mine, infamous bike messenger Jerme Spew.  He's as
unravey as you can get but a nice guy nevertheless as was the rest of the
security crew, refugees from 924 Gilman St., which is under renovation.
Security was led by Nondo, who has years of experience at Gilman as well as
raves.  Well done, I hope to see him doing more raves as he is retiring from
Gilman.
The room was done up quite well, the spacious room not giving the feeling of
visual overkill that I got at Kundalini's last party at the Troc.  Things
got cooking as a diverse group of people slowly filled the room.  Upstairs
was a chill room filled with happy, friendly people. 
As the crowd focused on the music, all differences were left behind.
Unfortunately, the party had to end at 5 due to hassles with Cesar's. The
music was good but at times didn't flow well, the prime example being when
Spun came on and mellowed things out a bit too early - perhaps an inevitable
result of the early finish.  Galen had preceded him with an eclectic,
energetic set.  Garth closed things out with a typically satisfying set.
After that, I headed out to Milton's Mountain (Twin Peaks) to watch the
sunrise. Quite a few people showed up to wait a few hours in the fog for the
fusion-powered light show by Ra Sol. I got to meet many people there-more
than at most "real" parties.
Saturday, I checked out All Together Now by Kinetic in West Berkeley.
Although plagued with problems, the energy of the crowd put this house party
over the top.  The floor was bouncing with dozens of energetic young ravers,
unfortunately causing the records to skip.  They were able to ameliorate the
problem but it persisted through the night.  It was also quite stuffy
although a few of us were able to get some ventilation in.  Overall this was
the most intense party presented by Kinetic yet.  
I finally got to meet Brian Darkness, and he's really a great guy!  Don't
fear Darkness...
On Sunday, I headed forthwith and without delay (except for the big
explosion in the maze) to Kundalini's party in Golden Gate Park.  Yay!
Finally another party under warm sunshine (sometimes).  DJs were Travis,
Garth and Galen.  I only have to say that it was as good as any other party
there, which is pretty good, but I got an extra oomph of energy due to my
month-long cold being supplanted by Spring Fever!  
It was one of the all-around best weekends ever (though I am sorry I missed
Venus) and I'm looking forward to what looks to be many more incredible
weekends coming up.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
-----
David Minuk(davidmin@crl.com)
WWW:  My URL is ftp://ftp.crl.com/ftp/users/ro/davidmin/links.htm
Use a browser such as Lynx, Netscape or Mosaic.
Yeah, I have to use the ftp server, but it should work fine.

DEar Sfraves;

	Lastnight I went to All Together Now with Ptiger. It was a great
party; penty of really friendly people; good music(with the exception of
the record skipping everytime people got zealous on the dance floor). I
really had a great time, no security; $5 cover; good extra cirriualrs(wink
wink). I wish I could find more parties like this. It had a great vibe;
more like a house party than anything else. I met more people there in one
night than I have since I started going to raves here in Cali. It was
really cool; and I feel really good today despite the obivous
non-alcoholic hangover. One note to DJ's everywhere; if the dancers are
making the turntable skip; try one of two things. Move your table as close
to the wall as you can; even if you have your back to the crowd. The floor
moves a lot less close to the wall; for instance I'll use the diving board
as an analogy. If you stand on a diving board where its attached to the
ground and jump up and down; what happens; basically not much; there's
very little if no displacement of the board itself. But stand on the far
edge of the board and jump up and down; and you have a lot of
displacement. Also for about $10.00 worth of hardware you can suspend the
turntables from the ceiling. The second suggestion should be done before
the party starts. Now I know someone's going to say that I'm stating the
obivious; but last nite it wasn't obvious to the DJ's until I suggested
it. But again I will say that even with the skipping it was a great party
and DJ's did a fantastic job. I would recommend another one of their
parties to anyone; well maybe not; I can be selfish sometimes:). Also 
I've never seem so many arractive womyn in one place; I just wish I 
wasn't so terrified of them; hehe.

		Peace & Love
		aka Brian Darkness, LMT

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com
		Majornet:	Brian Darkness @LIB
		Worldlink:	Brian Darkness @LIB; Stop by and will chat
		Chatlink:	System #48; ditto
		IRC:		Channel #rave; ditto

		Net Person & Virtual Cybernetic Being
			(FUKENGRUVEN:)

Getting down and Wicked in San Francisco this weekend
=====================================================

By Cap'n Crunch

Well,   After Venus last night,   I decided to pull another allnighter
(Don't I Always!! :-)

Due to the calander not being updated,   I call Mark from Ameba who
informs me that WICKED was to happen in some warehouse somewhere.
So we stay home,   waiting for the info line to be updated,  and
chill,  listening to DMX,   dancing around.   After about 11 pm,
we call and learn it to be at 1015 Folsom -  Oh!  Goodie,  my 
favorite venue.

We actually didn't get there until about 1:30 am.   When we arrive,
things were really hopping,   with Thomas behind the turntables,
I immediatly headed for the chill zone and started stretching in
preparation for getting down on the dance floor.    I immediatly
wasted no time heading for my favorite dance spot.    Yowsa!!
the energy level was just what I needed...    Hopping around with
this big fat grin on my face.... Yow!!  my face hurts from all the
smiling I was doing. 

Then,  Jeno went on,   and literally tore the place to schreds.   By
about that time,  my mind was certainly out somewhere beyond the
galaxy.    WOW!!  It's getting easier and easier to get into the
"Trance state".    I danced Jeno's entire set before Markie went
on.

When Jeno finished his set,   I wandered around,  schmoozing will
all my friends.    As usual,  the vibe was nothing short of amazing
with this one exception.   There was this black dude about 5 feet
away,  threatening me if I get too close.

After a while,  Markie's music was drawing me towards the dance
floor,   which kept me there until things were over at 7 am.   My My!
how time flies when you're having phun.

After that,  we head back to Mill Valley for the $2 breakfast special
and chill until the Golden Gate Park rave.

This Sunday,   Kundalini is hosting a small rave from 1 - 5 pm at
the BandShell in Golden Gate park.    So we head out there to check
it out.    WOW!!  Galen was spinning when I arrived,   but I only
had 2 hours of dancing,  so my rave report will have to wait until
the music stops.    Galen did a most energetic set,   then when
5 pm came rolling around,   galen faded out what he was playing
into 5 seconds of dead silance,   then started up a slower tune
to finish off the event.    Then,   I fired up the Traveler
(My Powerbook) and started typing the floowing.

-------  Live report from the Bandshell --------------

Hi,   I am live from the bandshell.    Where the most awsome rave
put on by kundalini,   just ended.    Frazer Clark from the Zippies
is sitting here with me,    with a bowl being pssed around.

Frazer  typed the following....

The Summer of Love Part 2 Ambient Rave style began here today. 
The future community waas out with smiles, dncing and conspiring 
together to spread the meme world wide. See you all on the Peace 
Love'n Dance barricades!

---------

So,   this finishes off yet another insane weekend in San Francisco

C.  Crunch - Till next time and please keep the scene alive...

     WOW! Another great Wicked! As the Captain says himself, "As usual,  
     the vibe was nothing short of amazing "... Couldn't have put it better 
     myself. There were even MORE smiles and hugs and just a great sweaty 
     dance feel than the last great Wicked in November!

     Steamroller started going.... Whooo  hooo! Jeez, I dont think Ive seen 
     so many people there at 7am, even by Wicked standards! It's so hard to 
     go wrong at a Wicked these days... The music, the people, the vibe, 
     etc..
     
     I friggin' danced my head off on the stage, trying to match the beat 
     to my blinky light! It was great to look up onto the second floor 
     balcony and even see a ton of people raving their bums off up there.

Subject: 19th and P (Sacto)

I'd like to mention the coffee house at 19th and P in Sacramento.
It is a nice friendly place with ravey vibes and party info.

In preparation for skiing, I was obliged to drink way too much
Pabst Blue Ribbon in a midtown bar - then, of course, I got a bug to
go dancing. 

I was under the impression (from calendar) that there would be djs 
afterhours at this little cafe.  Around 1:30 I found people lounging 
and listening to ambient music.  I approach Tom (owner/raver) and
and ask if anything is going on ...

Tom explains that djs do "show up" usually around 3am and then tells
me about a house party.  He gets on his computer and digs out voicemail
number for Miah's Party (Bring Love!).  Off to a surburban house where
for a $1 there are djs in the living room, ambitious decorations,
a keg out back, and 30 or so people dancing and hanging out.  

It was more than I expected to find (Sacto's Fruit Garden)
but for some reason I was unable to stop talking about Newt Gingrich
and his CIA-like control of TV Guide.

Anyway, I really liked Tom's coffee shop !! 

As per usual, it's hard to leave town and not feel like you missed
something fabulous when reading the weekend posts - especially GG park.
I did get my sunshine body-rock fix on the slopes, though. 

Love Ya
Dave

Enhanced CD?...

>> Enhanced Audio or CD+ is a new CD Audio/CDROM format, essentially a mix of
>> the two i.e. it plays like  a regular CD in your CD Player but if you  drop
>> it in a MAc or a PC with a CDROM drive you get lots of cool extra stuff like
>> video clips, lyrics, whatever.  This has been possible for a while, its the
>> standard that's new and since its being backed by Sony and Phillips it looks
>> like it will happen.
>> 
>> phuture
>> 
>let me know too!  That sounds totally cool and I will be getting a new 
>Mac with CDROM at the end of march - why not start getting stuff for it, 
>right?
>
>Amy
>
If anyone wants a totally twisted enhanced CD-ROM, you might want to check
out a thing called BlindROM v0.9  It's total hackware, lots of graphics and
music and no directions; when you put it in your CD-Player, you get a few music
tracks that are all a little, uh, different. (Gabber with gregorian chants
layered on top, a techno-funk that uses sounds of someone getting slugged
as percussion...) It comes packaged with a magazine, (or the magazine comes
packaged with a CD-ROM) The magazine would be a back issue now, so contact

Mediamatic
Int. Antwoordnummer
CCRI Numero 11084
1000 PB Amsterdam
Pays-Bas

...If you want to check it out.
(Yeah, they like to mix languages.)

-Dave

"Look, credits went up 20 percent!"                     WoW!

"David, you're fired!"                                  wow!

David

KZSU's signal (90.1 FM) can be picked up in some places in
the city, just as I guess I'd estimate it can be received
from the bay on over to the tenderloin, but as you get much
further West there's a mountain in the way and you're out of
luck.  

It does come in up in Berkeley and over in Oakland, however.

| You also might be able to get different left-of-the-dial radio stations 
| my splitting your TV cable line into your receiver.  They may be on

Has anyone found KZSU on Viacom? That would be, huh huh huhuh, K00L!
Any other freakquencies we should check?

Viacom does carry KPOO (89.5FM), which I cannot get where I live (since
another station, KFJC, blocks it out). As tradeoff, KFJC (89.7FM) comes
in pretty well, and is a great station too. I've heard them play some
killer techno, acid jazz, dub, industrial as well as yer standard
kawlich radio fare. 

PS: I'm not sure when they're doing it, but KFJC is going to interview
interview local "Ambient" artist Robert Rich...

PPS: today is Bob Marley's birthday! So burn the chalice and give
thanks and praise! Why yes, thank you, that's Haile Selassie of you!

In-Reply-To: <199502051341.FAA25975@netcom2.netcom.com> from "D. M. Ilstrup" at Feb 5, 95 05:41:29 am
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 913       
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


For those of you with Macs and CD Roms, there is an interesting
(mindblowing under the right circumstances) CD ROM called
Head Candy. It's essentially a 5-track Brian Eno ambient set
with killer, full screen graphics. Reasonably powered Mac
required.

There are a set of diffraction grating glasses that come with
the cdrom and boost the field of vision from the monitor to
a 9 x monitor size.

Like so...   ________   where the xx is the original monitor
            |  |  |  |  (I use a 27" Sony television ) and 
            |__|__|__|  the other boxes are color-shifted
            |  |xx|  |  versions of the original image (due
            |__|__|__|  to the diffraction grating.)
            |  |  |  |
            |__|__|__|

A nice trip, to be sure. An alternate way of viewing is to
enjoy your favorite CD's along with your favorite substances.
The graphics tend to sync up with any techno music.

-mk

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 19:45:04 PST
Subject: Re: Headcandy
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Michael Kellner wrote:

>For those of you with Macs and CD Roms, there is an interesting
(mindblowing under the right circumstances) CD ROM called
>Head Candy.

I too *strongly* recommend the Head Candy CD. Its Mac only right now but for
you PC folks a version should be out early spring. You need at least a 2X CD
ROM drive. My old drive choked and sputtered trying to get the full screen
video and audio. I upgraded just for this CD and it was well worth it. Don't
expect the latest in interactivity but just kick back and enjoy. Very very
trippy even when totally straight. 

The prism glasses do create the most wonderful mirror images surrounding the
original in the center. Sometimes you see a 3X3 grid but sometimes more like
a 5X5.  The farther away from the monitor you are the more the images spread.
The other images are color shifted but spread out so you sort of see a 3D
image with the coloring a rainbow along the depth. I thought this alone was
too much but then discovered that if you view the monitor up close from the
side that the prism glasses create layers of the original image some inside
the monitor and some projected out front. You can seriously trip on this
stuff. Its almost dangerous :)

Only drawback is that I need headphones. My landlord upstairs complained
about the loud music early in the morning, my favorite viewing time...

It was developed here in SF by ION (south park). They actually did the
imaging first and sent it to Eno who added the music. I first saw it a
MacWorld in the Ambient Lounge area. I talked with the developers who filled
me in on the story, very friendly indeed. (are any on this list?).

You can order extra glasses from ION. This would be a great addition to any
event/gathering in the chill area, and as -mk mentioned the graphics tend to
sync up with any techno music.

Have Mac, will travel.

peace,
martin

I think what Jon Williams said in one of the DJ magazines recently is
true.  Jungle is hard to find in the US, and most of what is available
is crap.  The really terrific stuff is on dub plates (one or at best
a few dozen acetate copies) or on limited releases that are snapped
up in the UK immediately.  Jonah did a terrific ambient-jazz-jungle set
at Nag Champa which really indicates the scope and flexibility of the
jungle format. 

phred

>It was developed here in SF by ION (south park). They actually did the

Actually, the visuals are originally from a video disk, also called
HeadCandy, that was produced by Pacific Arts in LA, a Nesmith Enterprise.
The original music was by Michael Brown. I never heard it or saw this
original version, but the video disk version is probably much better
resolution. I did see the HeadCandy CD-ROM from ION and liked it a lot. I
only borrowed it for a few days, and still need to get my own copy. I saw
that the mail order catalog Dr. Mac has it for $29. Now that I finally have
a VCR, I wish it were a video tape, which would be smoother and better
resolution. There isn't much interaction in it anyway. Video feedback is a
wonderful thing.

peace, light, and reflection
|  |
8re8

greg@imaja.com            Imaja, PO Box 6386, Albany, CA 94706

Without any doubt, 95 has dished up some of the hottest parties this side
of the ocean and we are barely two months into it. The afteglow of Sundays
rave in the park is still with me, and I would love to see daytime rave
appearences all summer. Its time that we had our own Summer of Raving and
Loving. If not now, then when? If not us, then whom?

San Francisco is certainly the place that has both the history and the
responsiblity to make good on its promise of its patron saint St Francis to
spread love to all creatures great and small. Comming up, the 50th
anniversary of the signing of the UN Charter in SF -  What a chance to make
a massive impression on all the worlds people, lets create the hugest, most
splendidly exquisite summer of rave this year in SF that will bring smiles
to not only us ravers but to the all citizens as well. The birth of the
dawn of a new age begins on the left coast of America. And we are here.

We have the best communications system any rave nation could possess, the
raddest sound systems, and enough commitment to make good on any promise.
Wow did I say that?

-david

>  #     ##   ##    # #        # #    #     #     #   #   #

> +---------------------------------------------------------+
>                        -> EMA ALERT <-
>             News For and About the Members of the
>                ELECTRONIC MESSAGING ASSOCIATION
> ============================================================
>                 February 3, 1995 -- Number 18
> <---------------------------------------------------------->
>                   ***** SPECIAL ALERT *****
>  - Congress to consider making all system operators liable
>    for messaging content.  Bill would force employers to
>    monitor message content.              ACTION NEEDED NOW!
> <---------------------------------------------------------->
> 
> UNREASONABLE NETWORK POLICING PROPOSED
>    Yesterday, Senator Jim Exon (D-NE) introduced S.314, the
> Communications Decency Act of 1995, in the United States
> Senate.  In an effort to stamp out digital pornography, it
> makes all telecommunications providers doing business in the
> United States (from the telephone companies all the way down
> to offices that use LANs) liable for the content of anything
> sent over their networks.  To avoid the possibility of tens
> of thousands of dollars in fines and up to two years in
> jail, business owners would be forced to police their
> networks and monitor in advance all messages sent over them.
> 
> WITHOUT ACTION - COULD BE LAW IN MONTHS
>    This bill is substantially the same as the one he put
> forward last year.  He will offer it as an amendment to the
> pending telecommunications deregulation legislation in the
> U.S. Senate, which is expected to be enacted by July.  Last
> year, his amendment was adopted even though many thought it
> hastily drafted and poorly thought out.  Fortunately, the
> telecommunications deregulation legislation died.  This
> year, a more conservative U.S. Congress may be even more
> reluctant to challenge a "morality" amendment; and its
> legislative vehicle, the telecommunications deregulation
> legislation, stands a much better chance of passage this
> year.
> 
> ACTION NEEDED NOW
>    Action by the business community is needed now.  Please
> notify your corporate government affairs office and/or your
> legal counsel.  This measure could be adopted as an
> amendment to the telecommunications bill IN A MATTER OF
> WEEKS (or potentially added to any legislation pending on
> the U.S. Senate floor), if business does not mobilize
> against it.  S.314 will not stop digital pornography, but it
> could devastate the messaging business.  If you are
> interested in further information or are able to participate
> in lobbying efforts over the next few weeks, contact Sarah
> Reardon at EMA (see below).
> 
> ------------------------------------------------------------
> EMA ALERT is published and copyrighted (1995) by the
> Electronic Messaging Association.  Permission to reproduce
> and/or redistribute with attribution is hereby given to all
> EMA members.  For more information about anything in EMA
> ALERT, contact EMA via e-mail - use either X.400 (S=info;
> O=ema; A=mci; C=us) or Internet (info@ema.org) address,
> facsimile (1-703-524-5558), or telephone (1-703-524-5550).
> Any EMA staff member can be addressed directly via e-mail by
> using, for X.400, G=<firstname>; S=<lastname>; O=ema; A=mci;
> C=us, and, for Internet, <firstinitial><lastname>@ema.org.
> EMA's postal address is 1655 N. Fort Myer Dr. #850,
> Arlington, VA 22209 USA.
> 
> ----- End Included Message -----

Hi fellow dance-adventurers..

I just received this email from this person in Germany..
Can anyone help him/her out?

Subject: 'Techno Style'
To: ccat@netcom.com
Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 22:30:01 +0100 (MET)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Content-Length: 1343
Status: R


Hi Chris!

we are a few people working (and living) in the diffrent fields
of nightlife and dance-culture from Frankfurt, Germany.
Our various appearence include DJ ing - Clubs and Bars -, writing
(journalism) about music and events for diffrent papers/magazines,
graphic designgs, etc.

Our latest project is now almost finished, the book about 
Techno Culture: 'Techno Style' and it would be great
if you could help us with some infos to be included in it.
This project has grown bigger and bigger over the past months.
We think that now every important/interesting label is included and
we are almost proud, that Karl Bartos of KRAFTWERK will contibute
the foreword. 

The book will have a huge impact on everyone in the scene: Musicians, DJs,
Graphic Designers, Ravers, Photographers, etc... . For the purpose of 
information for the global community we like to include an appendix
with the best Clubs, the most important Record stores, Pirate (or other) 
Radiostations, www pages, etc. .

Could you help? We need your list for your local area or for any city
you know of. I personally think it is very important to have these infos
from around the world. We would like to have included: Name, adress, best
days + opening hours (Clubs) but if you only have one of these things it 
will do.

Thanks for your help

Jens

prewo@rz.uni-sb.de

        Reply to:   RE>FWD>please send info on S314

Dear Jack,

      As am I appalled!  Thank you for your concern.  At this point we are
suggesting that anyone and everyone (1) publicize the bill and its potential
ramifications and (2) innundate the Senate (& House) with letters, e-mail
messages, and phone calls to voice opposition and educate them on this issue.
   Following is a detailed analysis prepared by EMA's legal counsel that
specifies the consequences of such a terrible law. Thanks again!

-Sarah Reardon



- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
                                     ANALYSIS

         S.314, The Communications Decency Act of 1995
                     Introduced by Sen. Jim Exon (D.-NE)

                                 Prepared for the
                  ELECTRONIC MESSAGING ASSOCIATION
                                            by
                    James T. Bruce and Richard T. Pfohl
                               Wiley, Rein & Fielding

                                   February 7, 1995




I.     Summary

     On February 2, Sen. Jim Exon (D-NE) introduced S. 314, The
Communications Decency Act of 1995.  Sen. Exon's bill, which contains
provisions intended to curtail transmission of obscene, indecent, or
harassing telecommunications, is identical to an amendment to the Senate
telecommunications deregulation legislation which died last fall with the
conclusion of the 103rd Congress.  Although ostensibly extending existing
federal prohibitions on obscene or harassing telephone calls to other
telecommunications devices, these provisions could greatly expand prohibited
conduct and would potentially make employers, service providers, and carriers
liable for transmission of restricted communications.  The likelihood of
passage of the telecommunications deregulation legislation in the current
Congress and the likelihood that Sen. Exon will attempt to again attach his
language to such a vehicle makes the potential passage of the Exon language
quite plausible.

II.     Analysis

     Sen. Exon's interest in the issues addressed in S. 314 was reportedly
spurred by reports of electronic stalking on the Internet.  Sen. Exon stated
upon introduction of the legislation on February 2, "I want to keep the
Information Superhighway from resembling a red light district.  This
legislation will help stop those who electronically cruise the digital
universe to engage children in inappropriate communications . . . or
electronically stalk users of computer networks."  The Exon bill would
address obscenity on radio and cable television, but of particular interest
to EMA members are Section 2, on obscene or harassing use of
telecommunications facilities, and Section 5, which extends the Electronic
Communications Privacy Act (ECPA) to include digital communications.

     According to Sen. Exon's introductory statement, his legislation is
intended to "extend and strengthen" the anti-harassment, decency, and
anti-obscenity restrictions on telephone calls in current law to all
telecommunications devices.  The Exon bill would not, however, simply apply
existing law to new telecommunications devices.

     Because of differences between existing telephone technology and
telecommunications technology such as electronic messaging, the Exon bill
would potentially prohibit a wide array of currently allowed electronic
communications.  Furthermore, the Exon bill would broaden existing law by
subjecting transmitters, as well as the individuals who send obscene or
harassing communications, to criminal liability.

     A. Restrictions on Nonconsensual Indecency and
       Harassment

     Current law, as codified in Sec. 223(a) of the Communications Act of
1934, prohibits any "obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, or indecent"
communications by telephone.0  (Communications Act of 1934, Sec. 223(a) (47
U.S.C. 223(a))).  Sec. 223(a) also prohibits intentional harassment by
telephone, including by anonymous calls, repeated hang-ups, or repeated
harassing calls.  (47 U.S.C. 223(a)(1)(A - D)).  Finally, Sec. 223(a)(2)
prohibits knowingly permitting a telephone facility under one's control to be
used for such purposes.  The courts have interpreted Sec. 223(a) narrowly to
apply only to non-consensual or unsolicited telephone calls.

     The Exon bill would make two fundamental changes in existing Sec.
223(a), with potentially wide-ranging, and possibly unintended, consequences.
 First, the Exon bill expands the prohibitions on obscene or indecent or
harassing telephone calls to communication by all telecommunications devices.
 Second, the Exon bill extends the prohibition against making obscene or
indecent communications to "transmit[ting] or otherwise mak[ing] available"
any such communication.  (S. 314 Sec. 2(a) (emphasis added)).  In addition,
the Exon bill would raise the penalty for such violations from the current up
to $50,000 or six months in prison, to up to $100,000 or two years in prison.
 (S. 314 Sec. 2(b)).

     The Exon bill provisions would have a number of consequences for
electronic messaging.  First, unless the court-created limitation on the
scope of the Sec. 223(a) anti-obscenity and indecency provisions to
nonconsensual telephone calls is applied as well to all telecommunications,
the provision would prohibit all "obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, or
indecent" telecommunications, whether or not consensual.  Services or
carriers that transmit "or otherwise make[] available" such communications
would be liable.  Thus, the amended Communications Act would, on its face,
prohibit indecent communications between consenting adults.  This provision,
unless limited to nonconsensual communications as the courts have done with
regard to the existing prohibition on such telephone calls, is most likely
unconstitutional. Nevertheless, the legislative history of this provision
should clarify that the amended language is intended to apply only to
nonconsensual communications.1

     Second, the Exon bill restricts anyone from transmitting, "or otherwise
mak[ing] available," "obscene, lewd, lascivious, filthy, or indecent"
communications. (S. 314 Sec. 2(a)(1)(B)).  This goes beyond and is in
addition to the existing prohibition on knowingly permitting a telephone
facility under one's control to be used for purposes prohibited by Sec.
223(a).  The Exon bill expands the prohibition on knowing use of telephone
facilities to knowing use of telecommunications facilities.  (S. 314 Sec.
2(a)(2)).  The latter provision may prove troublesome if service providers
are deemed to "know" about the use of Bulletin Boards for or Electronic Mail
for harassment or indecent remarks.

     These provisions could have a chilling effect on electronic message
services, providers, carriers, or anyone else who could be deemed to
"transmit[] or otherwise make[] available" prohibited electronic
communications.  Thus, for example, if someone sent an indecent electronic
comment from a workstation, the employer, the e-mail service provider, and
the carrier could all potentially be held liable, and subject to up to
$100,000 in fines or up to 2 years in prison.  This provision also has
potentially chilling effects on electronic bulletin boards, discussion
groups, and basic electronic mail communications.  Although some service
providers regularly screen bulletin boards to ensure that no obscene or
indecent remarks appear upon them, the incredible proliferation of such
bulletin boards makes comprehensive screening practically impossible.2
Bulletin Boards on the Internet, and, potentially, electronic messages,
include numerous postings making racist remarks, arguing that the Holocaust
never occurred, etc.  All of these could conceivably be considered
"indecent," or annoying, abusive or harassing, any of which could subject
employers, services, and carriers to liability.

     It is questionable whether the prohibition on obscene or indecent
communications, even if limited to nonconsensual communications, can be
accomplished in electronic communications without chilling the First
Amendment. Electronic bulletin boards and discussion groups blur the concept
of intent:  anyone perusing bulletin boards or discussion groups on the
Internet has the potential to stumble, as if accidently stumbling into an
X-rated movie theater, upon indecent material.3  Such an encounter may not be
"consensual."  The Internet practice of "flaming" fellow users very
frequently involves use of indecency.  Any such flame, which is by definition
nonconsensual,4 would subject anyone who "makes available" the communication
(again, potentially including an employer, service provider, common carrier,
etc.) to full liability under this section.

     B. Restrictions on Commercial Obscenity

     The Exon bill would amend current law which is intended to restrict
consensual obscene or indecent telephone calls, such as dial-a-porn.  Current
law prohibits use of the telephone to make obscene communications for
commercial purposes, regardless of whether the maker of such communications
placed the call (i.e., regardless of consent). (47 U.S.C. 223(b)(1)).
Current law also prohibits making indecent communications available to
persons under age 18. (47 U.S.C. 223(b)(2)).  Current law allows common
carriers to avoid liability under the provision limiting indecent material to
persons over 18 by complying with F.C.C. rules5and by offering subscribers
the right to block access to indecent material.  The Exon bill would extend
these prohibitions to all telecommunications.  (S. 314 Sec. 2(a)(3)).

     By simply applying existing telephone provisions to telecommunications,
the Exon bill would again create problems due to the unique nature of
non-telephone telecommunications. For example, may a service or provider be
liable if it does not check the ages of all members of a household, and allow
a family to block access to members under the age of 18? Numerous electronic
bulletin boards on line contain indecent material,6 and indecent material may
spring up in any discussion group, or even when a rap artist discusses his
lyrics, or a record company puts a new release on line, as has been done in
recent months.  Because subscribers are required to pay a commercial fee
(beyond their basic subscription fee, which would presumably be analogous to
a telephone common carrier fee) to access these services, indecent material
on these services may subject providers to liability.7

     C. Expansion of ECPA

     The Electronic Communications Privacy Act (ECPA), codified in the U.S.
Code at Title 18, generally prohibits unauthorized electronic surveillance,
such as wiretapping of employees.  (18 U.S.C. 2511.  See Alderman v. U.S.,
394 U.S. 165 (1969)).  The Exon bill would add conforming language which
amends the prohibition on surveillance to ensure that it covers all
electronic communications, including digital communications.  (S. 314 Sec.
5).

     ECPA has been amended before to account for the evolution of technology.
 When passed in 1968, ECPA prohibited surveillance only of wire or oral
communications. ECPA was amended in 1986 to prohibit as well surveillance of
electronic communications.  Sec. 5 of S. 314 would ensure that all electronic
communications, including digital communications, are covered.

III.     Status

     The Exon language is substantively identical to the amendment to S.
1822, Senate telecommunications deregulation legislation in the last
congress.  It is anticipated that Sen. Exon will again offer his language as
an amendment to telecommunications deregulation legislation which is expected
to be introduced by mid-February.  Sen. Pressler, Chairman of the Senate
Commerce Committee, has indicated his eagerness to address the legislation.
Sen. Exon is a member of the Senate Commerce Committee.

IV.     Prognosis

     Last year, Sen. Exon's language was adopted as an amendment to the
telecommunications deregulation legislation even though many thought it
hastily drafted and poorly thought out.  Nevertheless, this language could be
adopted as part of the telecommunications bill in a matter of weeks or
potentially added to any legislation pending on the Senate floor.

     A coalition of groups assembled last fall to address the threat to
online services created by the Exon provisions. The coalition included
representatives of the ACLU, the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF),
America Online, Prodigy, ANS, CompuServe, and the Interactive Services
Association.

     The will of Senators to oppose such "morality" legislation, regardless
of how technically flawed, is always in short supply; in the more
conservative atmosphere of the 104th Congress, such legislation stands an
even greater chance of passage.



ENDNOTES

0     Courts have not defined precisely what constitutes indecency, although
they have held that mere offensiveness is insufficient.
1     Sec. 7 of Sen. Exon's bill, which requires that cable channels
"unsuitable for children" be fully scrambled for nonsubscribers, suggests
that he does not intend to prohibit indecent, non-obscene, consensual
communications. Sec. 7 does not prohibit such "indecent" programming as the
Playboy Channel, but merely ensures that it will be limited to consenting
adults.
2     This problem is compounded by the indefiniteness of the definition of
indecency.
3     The proliferation of such material on the Internet is evident in the
proliferation of bulletin boards devoted solely to sexual topics.  According
to a newsgroup list compiled by Digital Equipment Corp., the most popular
bulletin board on the Internet, after a bulletin board providing rules for
new users, is alt.sex.stories, which half a million Internet users log on to
each month.  The next most popular category is alt.binaries.pictures.erotica,
followed by the alt.sex discussion group.
4     One could argue, however, that the practices of logging on to the
Internet or entering a discussion group or bulletin board, constitutes
"consent," or waiver of the right to object, to whatever communications may
ensue.  The unresolved issue of consent demonstrates the difficulty of simply
applying existing obscenity or anti-harassment law governing telephones to
all telecommunications.
5     For example, F.C.C. rules require that companies require a credit card
for provision of services.
6     See supra note 4.
7     Although it might be argued that the basic subscription fee of on-line
services is analogous to a telephone common carrier fee, in this case the
carrier (the service provider) is providing both the basic communications and
the information services (i.e., the Bulletin Board). Thus the electronic
telecommunications carrier is analogous to both the telephone company and the
dial-a-porn operator for enforcement purposes.

 ----------
From: Glenn Fajardo (Starwave)
To: owner-nw-raves; nw-raves
Subject: Options Galore (was: c-u-c-me (where?) and More!!!)
Date: Wednesday, February 08, 1995 2:04PM
Priority: High

Options, Options, Options and the need to COMMUNICATE to people that options 
are available to them is exactly the point that I've been trying to make. 
 Everything that I've been involved with from the first NW FMR the previous 
year to the Choc-Lit Factory to Earthspace has been about trying to 
communicate to people that options are available to them.  What's that? 
 You're tired paying $20 to $30 at the door for vibe-less non creative 
parties?  Tired of super hyped flyers promising everything in the universe 
and leaving you nothing but a hole in your pocket?  Tired of having 
travelled 3 to 4 hours to a party you've been anxiously waiting for the last 
3 months  only to arrive at the party as it's getting busted?  Well... what 
options do we have?  Are we just totally left to rely on the winds of 
fortune and the "good" graces of shallow and superficial promoters?  Do we 
just say "fuck it, the police and the city just don't give shit about us 
"kids"?  But wait!  Wait a minute!  We have OPTIONS, don't we??  Well, let's 
see.  We can:

1. COMMUNICATE- Initiate dialogues with promoters  to help them look at 
OPTIONS for throwing cheaper (for everyone) parties. Just making the effort 
to communicate gets your ideas out there as an option.  If the promoters are 
not receptive, you also have the option to do it yourself. Communicate to 
the promoters, the governing bodies, other people including yourself, that 
you have other options and that you have the ability to seek out and create 
other options.

2. CREATE-Everyone has the ability,( or should I say option?) to create  and 
cultivate the avenues by which we can focus and channel the energies that 
nurture us and allow us to survive.  If you consider dance and music to be 
one of the manifestations of those energies, would it not be worth it to 
create and cultivate an environment that would be conducive to experiencing 
it?  I've yet to see voter registration booths and truly informative kiosks 
on a consistent basis at any of the events I've attended.  I think that it 
can only help to provide those kinds of things at parties.  If the promoters 
won't provide them, we all have the option setting them up ourselves.

3. EXTEND-Push those envelopes, kidz!!!  Look within and behold the wonders 
inherent in each of us.  We are all reflections of the universe around us. 
 Look beyond the patterns that you've been conditioned/programmed to follow. 
 Create your own patterns, extend and enhance the knowledge within you by 
learning as much as you can and then sharing the knowledge that you do have 
with other people.  Sharing knowledge is one of the most gratifying ways of 
giving to others that I have experienced.

I guess my point is we should EXPLORE the possibilities and options 
available to us.  Provide possibilities and options for other people such as 
having a low-tech AND high-tech information medium.  Imagine the 
possibilities...  but, I digress.

Peace y'all

Tigger

Subject: this fri in Santa Cruz
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Hello all...
I haven't been following the list as much lately so I'm not sure if 
these parties have gotten any mention before...
For the last couple of months in Santa Cruz we have had almost weekly 
parties in an old train station that was once converted into a 
restaurant, then to a nightclub then it sat empty for a year or so. 
Much Santa Cruz talent has been coming together for these parties- 
dj's Tom, Wool, Eric, Drew, Jason Hartley and myself(Christian)... 
computer visuals are often provided by Craig Larson...  
a really nice sound system by Randy Cone... and Andrew has been 
organizing and dealing with the business aspects... he has put in 
loads of time and hard work into this place.
There's been high energy, pumping and jumping turnouts each time that 
we all have come together. 

This friday (the 10th) it will be goin on... dj's Grame(La Paix) and 
Mars will be joining us, along with Eric and myself...  
I've never heard Mars spin before but word is that he spins hardcore!  
It starts around 11:00 pm and goes all night. $5 before 12, $7 after 
12 or $5 with flyer.  The voice mail number is 408.457.4955.

Love to have you all there!

James

On Wed, 8 Feb 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> 
> Additions to list recommended and welcomed
> 
Politely say "no" when someone offers you a quarter pounder with cheese.

WHY?

Because it takes 16 pounds of grain to make one pound of beef.  It only 
takes one pound of grain to produce one pound of bread.  So just remember 
how much of our resources you are helping waste every time you bite down 
on one of those greasy surprises.  btw, that doesn't begin to touch on 
the subject of all the toxic waste (cow shit) all those extra cows create 
for our rivers and lakes and other important waterways.  Think also of 
all  the people starving in Latin America becaus all of their land is 
being used to feed countries like ours beef that they cannot even afford 
to buy. 

well, gotta go, i'm off to cattleman's for a nice juicy one...

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Going away to the land of Oz
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well,  

It looks like the Cap'n will be leaving on 2nd Mar for Sydney,  to explore
the Australian rave scene and meet as many AusRavers as possible.
I guess I would call this a "Rave safari". 

I expect to take my flyer collection and do some serious trading,  as
well as trading tapes.

What would be Neat,   is for as many SFRavers to see me off on the
2nd of March.    My flight leaves at 7 pm,   and because it's an
international flight,   I have to get there by about 5 pm.

I know a lot of people will probably be working at that time,   but
perhaps a few of you SFRavers may want to have a small "Get together"
either in the afternoon,   or at the gate in the airport.    Or some
other arrangement by suggestion from the other SFRavers.   I think my
departure is on Thursday evening.

I will be met in Sydney by a delegation of AusRavers,   at which time
a picnic is planned,   then the Gay Day Mardi Gras parade that evening,
then on to Field of Dreams,  a big huge massive held at some sports
stadium.

Naturally,  I'll have internet access,   and plan to be putting out
reports on the rave scene over there.    While in Oz,   I'll still
be continuing with my job,   so I'll be earning $$ while over there.

Anyway,   I have left an open return,   and plan to stay between 1 to
3 months.

So,   don't know if I'll attend Wicked this weekend,   as I wanted
to check out Ravers In Wonderland.    I suspect that Wicked will be
very crowded,  as I am told it's the New Years Makeup party,  and
will be free.

Later...
C. Crunch

putting on da gloves! Snap! Snap! 

When will they realize that the more money and laws they throw at the
problem... well it's just going to be become an arms/bribery race  and

------- Forwarded Message

| Today I read in the Chronicle that the House began debate on "a far
| more controversial measure that would give the police more leeway to
| conduct searches without warrants, provided they are acting in
| 'good faith.'"  This was also worded in a separate section as "The House
| also opened debate on a contoversial plan permitting courts to consider
| evidence illegally obtained without a search warrant by police officers 
| who believed that their search was lawful."  This is exactly the kind of 
| Republican legislation I have anticipated for years (from back when Bush
| was president).  So, if this passes, which it probably won't (yet), you'll
| be subject to search and seizure based upon reasonable suspicion that you
| might be up to something reasonably suspicious. This section of the
| Contract on America, by the way, is part of the "Take Back Our Streets Act."
|
| Burrito Man

------- End of Forwarded Message

hey all,
 know that this post is late and all but just wanted to say that Kundalini
was much fun last friday.  i havent had more fun dancing in a bit and the
lighting setup that they had going was much cool, esp the lasers off the
mirrors across the room which caused them to go all over the place. 
	the only think that sucked for me was that at one point in the
night i overextended myself and felt a bit woozy. that was the first time
something like that ever happened to me since i started going to parties
2+ years ago and it scared and bummed me cause i really wanted to dance. 
  	oh well at least i got to finish the night with garth which was cool. 
the trip up to Twin Peaks was also much fun, and dancing and watching the
sun rise through the fog was rather beautiful :)

god, i love raves :)

doug ) ( doug@squsihy.com
