Internet: info@ema.org  X.400: S=info; O=ema; A=mci; C=us
     
============================================================

------- End of Blind-Carbon-Copy


From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 10 13:11:14 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id NAA01749; Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:11:14 -0800
Received: from B17.Catch22.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA01742; Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:11:10 -0800
Received: (from jchrysler@localhost) by B17.Catch22.COM (8.6.9/8.6.9) id NAA07657; Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:14:32 -0800
Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:14:31 -0800 (PST)
From: Jesus Chrysler <jchrysler@Catch22.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: New and Improved Music Review Service
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.91.950210131355.7648A-100000@B17.Catch22.COM>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Below is described a service that I offer, which I encourage you to use 
and contribute to, if you want.

You may http://catch22.com/~jchrysler, where I offer a review of artists
categorized (as best as I could) by the style of music.  Also, depending on
the contributor, there may be other information, such as:

1.A list of titles by said person(s).

2.A list of compilations they appear on.

3.Other works that they have something to do with.

4.Similar artists that they might be compared to.

5.More than one (hopefully) review of particular works of said artist or album.


This information is also available via email, by emailing a request to me of any
of the above given information.  My email address is given below.

I would like people to submit a review and information about albums they have
recently gotten (especially), or albums that they have gotten in the past that
they have liked.  To send such a review, it would contain the following 
information:

Artist, album/single name, and any mentionable (or unmentionable :) people
involved, or for compilations, a list of artists and the mentionable people
involved.

Any other information as to how to get the item, such as record label or
whatever.

Vague hint as to what kind of music it might be classified as.


And if you so wish to put the time into it, the following optional information:

Artists you would compare this one to, or artists that you would listen to with
this one.

Maybe something like: "This artist is a cross between..."

A brief description/review of the album/single.

A rating from 1 to 10, 10 being the best (in your opinion: music quality is an
opinion of course), of the album/single, which will be averaged in if there are
other ratings of the same album.

Anything else you might want to mention about this artist, or artists involved
in this single/album.

Some of your favorite artists, so that an idea of your tastes might be
ascertained.


The format of contributions can be however you want, and if you want signed, and
will appear exactly as given.

The email address to send to is:

			jchrysler@catch22.com
			or reply to this message.

Again, the Web page is at:
			http://catch22.com/~jchrysler

When you send me something by email, or in a comment from the Web server, I will
save your address unless you request otherwise, and will send you any new
information about artists that you request for.

Hope to be hearing from y'all!
			JC

PS:  unfortunately some of the information given to me previously was lost, so
if you have contributed before, please contribute again.


...While mascarading at night as the winged AVENGER!!!!
	LSD:  melts in your mind, not in your hand...

------- Forwarded Message

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:22:08 -0800
From: Dianna Bolt <dbolt@EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
Message-Id: <199502102122.NAA10235@hera.EECS.Berkeley.EDU>
To: eecsdept@hera.EECS.Berkeley.EDU

Subject: Is Apple Censoring A CD-ROM?
Author:  merholz@3sixty.voyagerco.com (Peter Merholz) at Internet-USA
Date:    2/9/95 12:51 AM


The following article appeared in the New York Daily News:

February 8, 1995.  (pg. 10)

APPLE'S BIG BYTE OUT OF HISTORY

Apple, the company that revolutionized the personal computer industry,
apparently thinks Newt Gingrich's Third Wave Information Age means
cencorship is back - especially when it comes to abortion and gays.

In a stunning move for a company long admired for its forward-looking
policies, Apple last week suddenly notified the producer of an acclaimed
American history CD-ROM that it was discontinuing shipments because of
complaints about mentions of turn-of-the-century abortion, birth control
and homosexuality.

After failing to get Voyager Co. - the producer of "Who Built America?" -
to delete the controversial sections, Apple informed the company on Jan. 31
that it was discontinuing shipments of the disc to public schools.

Apple's notice came only a few days after "Who Built America?" won the
American Historical Association's bienniel prize for "the most outstanding
contribution to the teaching and learning of history."

Since November, Apple has distributed more than 12,000 copies of the
Voyager disc, as part of its free software package bundled with new
computer shipments to public schools.

"Who Built America?" was a joint project between New York-based Voyager,
the leading U.S. publisher of CD-ROM discs, and the American Social History
Project at the City University of New York.

CD-ROM is the technology that combines text, photos, music and video into
one multi-media experience on a personal computer.  Like cd music discs,
CD-ROM discs can store immense amounts of information compared with older
methods.

Only a few minutes of viewing this disc shows you why Apple was at first so
enthusiastic.  With it, history comes alive.  You get not only a standard
text but original source documents, such as the complete video of "The
Great Train Robbery," the actual voice of William Jennings Bryan giving his
"Cross of Gold" speech, and survivors of the 1906 Atlanta race riot and the
1911 Triangle Shirtwaist factory fire giving you firsthand accounts of
those tragedies.

But in early January, Apple executives notified Bob Stein, chief executive
of Voyager, that they had recieved some complaints, the most troubling
dealing with citations of abortion, birth control, and homosexuality.

There was, for instance, the audio interview with Elizabeth Anderson, who
recounted how, beginning in 1910, she had had 12 abortions.

And the 1882 letter from a gay German immigrant explaining how he fled to
America from his native land after being arrested for a homosexual
relationship.

And the 1901 New York Times account of Murray Hall, a well-known Tammany
Hall leader who for 25 years masquereded as a man and was married twice,
though "he" was secretly a "she."

"Some people may not like the fact there was abortion in 1910, but you
can't deny it existed," said Steven Brier, the CUNY history professor who
authored the original two-volume "Who Built America" and then adapted it
for CD-ROM.

"It's unbelievable to have this project blown-off in this way," an angry
Brier said yesterday.

And for this to happen with Apple - long regarded by many as the most
creative and visionary of companies - is especially troubling.

I bought my first Apple 2E more than 10 years ago, and I came to believe
that Apple's healthy irreverence toward narrow-minded thought and arbitrary
authority was just the spirit that produced its pioneering innovations,
things like the Macintosh and the powerbook laptops.

It was Apple, remember, that not too long ago refused to build a new plant
in Austin, Tex., after the local government tried to penalize it for
providing medical benefits to same-sex domestic partners.  That time, Apple
stood on principal and won.

But now here was this public relations person, Carolyn Donohoe, giving me a
prepared statement late yesterday on the "Voyager issue."

Since the statement so clearly double-speaks for itself, I will quote it
extensively:

"It's not an issue of censorship.  However, Apple has recieved some
customer complaints.  As a matter of course, Apple continually reviews the
content of its bundles based on customer satisfaction and feedback.

"Currently, Apple is evaluating the bundle titled 'Apple Educational
Series: Elementary and Secondary Reference.'  To date, Apple has neither
formally notified Voyager nor made any public announcements about future
versions of this bundle."

With the November elections behind us, and with our nation's future being
increasingly shaped by a rabid history professor named Newt Gingrich, Apple
appears ready to join the cencorship posse, tossing its own once-proud
rebel legacy into the trash bin it helped make famous.

- -30-

The reason I phrased the subject of this email as a question is because I
don't feel right calling Apple's action censorship, but I do think Apple's
action to be utterly reprehensible.

If you would like to respond in an official way, please email:
michaels@voyagerco.com
He's handling this in-house.

- ------------------------
     Peter Merholz
        Voyager
http://www.voyagerco.com
- ------------------------







------- End of Forwarded Message

hi gary!

um, that's ravers in wonderland.  allen of ameba said the other day (or
was it mark?  sorry, i can't remember and credit where credit's due) said
you could get in for $15 if you wear a costume.  i think that's before
midnight...$20 after midnight.  i would go if it were cheaper, 'cause it's
at a club in berkeley kinda close to where i live. 

anthrax' advice: go to wicked tomorrow night!  but be sure to get there
EARLY because it will probably be jam-packed by midnight.  i am also very
pleased about the musical offerings for the evening.  my big kick right 
now is VARIETY VARIETY VARIETY, and it looks like that will happen...more 
so than at the usual wicked party, perhaps?

on that vein:  perfect evening includes rekkid spinners that do a set in a
solid, unmistakable style followed by someone else who does something
completely different.  i love that!  sometimes it works, sometimes it
doesn't.  but it does make you pay more attention to the music and what
the dj is doing with it.  maybe someday someone will write a graduate
thesis about dj's and raves and such and go on and on... but it
ain't gonna be me! 

love & kisses,

ann

Mime-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk

I'm sorry, I didn't take very well to the tone of this response.  "You just
gotta know where to look"?  OK, *where*.  Or is jungle going to turn into
another realm of exclusivity where only the *true* junglists get to know
about all the goodies.  Sheesh.

Now, look again at what I wrote about Jonah's set.  I said, *very* 
deliberately, that he played "ambient-jazz-jungle."  I used that term 
to soften the usual hyphen-encoupled kind of labeling (of which ambient-
jungle is just the latest) and to indicate what I felt was the wider
stylistic sweep of what he was playing.  I didn't say he played jazz
because at least in the traditional sense he didn't.  Read it again.
However, there's no reason that some types of jungle and some types of
jazz couldn't be mixed together quite successfully.  I put an old mid-70s
jazz track (what would now be considered "acid jazz" I suppose, sigh) at
the start of my promo tape and nobody thinks it's out of place.  It's
there for a *reason*.  

As for mixing jungle and other styles, normally I too prefer to hear
sets or groups of tunes that are stylistically consistent, but consistency
gets boring too after a while and the really good DJs know how to move
from style to style or genre to genre and use the transitions to keep
things interesting.  

And as for jungle itself, ok, what *kind* of jungle are we talking about?
Not everything out there sounds like 'Original Nuttah' or the new bad-bwoi
sound.  Those who have delved into jungle seriously know that it is a
remarkably flexible and resilient style and reaches across the spectrum
from jazz to ambient to house to hardcore for influences on its rhythmic
underpinnings.  There are house (or techno or rock or jazz or whatever
genre) songs I wouldn't play back to back even in the same set, and the
same goes for jungle.  In my opinion, the only thing that can hold jungle
back is the desire to stand pat among some jungle devotees.

I still strongly believe in the lessons of house music, and one of them
is that "no one OWNS house music" (or any other kind for that matter),
it belongs to all of us and we must let it develop as it should.  And
just to prove the point, I played a remix of 'The House That Jack Built'
to start my set in Portland last night, and I played a DJ Pulse track from
the Moving Shadow jungle-oriented label to finish.

]Nuff respect, c u in the future
phred

Just wanted to let SFRavers know who are interested:


Unfortunately,  Ravers In Wonderland  has been postponed until a yet to be
announced date.

The site that they were going to use has had it's permit revoked.  The
spaceowner told the party organizers that he had all of the necessary
permits, when reportedly he was actually running off of a "special
functions" provision of a recording studio permit instead.  It is
unfortunate that the spaceowner did not communicate to the party organizers
the level of risk involved with the site's stability before this happened,
or perhaps a usable backup site would have been found for tonight.

Since this did not happen, and a usuable backup site has still not been
found, the party's organizers have very reluctantly postponed Ravers In
Wonderland until a yet to be announced date.

You can call the party's voicemail number for updates on this situation in
the coming days.     Ravers In Wonderland    415-789-8522


For those of you who still want something to do AND are over the age
discrimination of twenty-one years, there is a Wicked happening
tonight in the city at 1015 Folsom.


Todd a.k.a. Infinity

P.S. -- I am not the same as "Infinitee", a new DJ who is involved in much
of the organizing with Ravers In Wonderland, (as I understand it).

	I'm not gay; but the more I hear about oppression against groups 
of people that live a different lifestyle the more I get affaird. When

eventually singled out for our various egocentric differences; whether it

where we must meet them head on; and not give an inch. I personnally have

From sfraves-owner  Sun Feb 12 18:10:27 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA26257; Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:10:27 -0800
Received: from netcom11.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id SAA26252; Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:10:23 -0800

	id SAA29512; Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:10:20 -0800
Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:10:20 -0800
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199502130210.SAA29512@netcom11.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: WICKED Weakend
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

WICKED Weakend
==============

So,   I go and check my Email,   only to learn that "Ravers in Wonderland"
got cancelled.     Oh!  Darn...   The only thing going (And a tough one
to beat) is WICKED at 1015 Folsom,  and the price cannot be beat...  It's
FREE.    This was touted as a "Make up" party to make up for the fiasco
New Years,   and the last WICKED,   which some people say were not the
typical WICKED parties.

Naturally,  we correctly assumed that it was going to be packed,  and it
was.    We get there about 10:30 pm (Early for WICKED standards) and
already,  there was a line.    Although it was reasonably short,  there
was no delays in getting in the door,   although being 21+,  the door
people had to check ID's.

I walk in,   and learn that only the downstairs area was open,   and things
were getting set up in the main room.    The front room was used as the chill
room,  and at the same time,  in the upstairs front section,  a private
party was in progress.

There were perhaps 40 people or so,  when I entered,   but it was filling
fast.    So,   after stretching,  in preparation for dancing,  I head on
downstairs in the basement to hear Harry Who kick things off,  to start
dancing my first set.    After a short "warm up" I decided to schmooze
around,   and socialize for a while until the energy level started to
pick up.   Say!!  whatever happened to all the pillows that used to
be at 1015 Folsom?    I only saw two of them!!

About  half hour later,   the main room opens up,   and Galen was spinning.
Great!!  So I pick my favorite spot,   and started to "Get down" to Galens
set.    As usual,  his variaty was brilliant,  and he took me on a pleasant
and unexpected trip.   By about this time,   there were about a hundred 
people on the main dance floor.

Later on,  Robbie Hardkiss did a live set,   and deviated from the usual
housey sounds into some rather complicated beats,   but it made for some
interesting dancing.

Usually,  when I'm out there dancing,   and I get a break in the beat,
I'll usually leave if I've been dancing for several hours,   so I went
back downstairs to learn that Markie Mark was behind the turntables,
spinning some higher energy trances than upstairs,   so I stayed down
in the basement (dispite the humididity and heat),   and danced a
considerable portion of Markie's set.

Didn't see quite that many SFRavers as I had expected,   but the usual
dedicated crew were always there.    Hi to Bill and Gaby and all the
rest...

Eventually,  there was a short break from the Boom Boom,  and I figured
that I should think about cooling down.   I head upstairs and do a little
exploring,   until I realized I was in that other private party.  

I quickly leave,   and head down in the main room.    HardKiss had just
finished his set,   and I think Josh went on next in the main room.

I decided to wait until Josh's set develops,   and head back downstairs
to dance to Markies set.   By about this time,  every surface in the basement
was soaking wet,   and lo and behold,    I see madison.    Actually,  she
saw me first and hugged and kissed me to death....   Man!  Can she dance...

Markies set was reaching critical mass,   as people were cheering and shouting
as Markie was taking us through all beat possibilities.   WOW!   dispite
the fans,   it was sweltering down there,   but I just couldn't possibly
leave until Markie let me go.   Eventually he did,  and I head back upstairs
soaking wet.   As Willy Wong pointed out,  I wear as little as possible
when getting down in hot sweltering places.   But,  lets be practical!!

Upstairs,   Garth had just gotten on,   and he put me into a most incredable
trance state of mind.   I felt as I was dancing,  that everything was floating
and moving in perfect harmony.   As one looked around,   there were people
packed on the stage,   up in the balcony,   all dancing like there was 
no tommorrow.   Good old 1015 Folsom was simply "Bouncing" around big time.

Things were so packed,   that security opened a few alternate doors,  to
make it easy for people to get around.   I would estimate about 700 mad
raving lunitics were getting down and wicked at 1015.

Garth brilliantly guided my trance state from one musical space to another.
I just couldn't stop dancing,  so I danced Garth's entire set,    perhaps
stopping no more then 2 - 3 minutes for water break,  and/or stretching
as the need arose.

After Garth,   Mark farina went on.    I left the dance floor until Mark
had a chance to develop his set,   and headed by the front door to cool
off and schmoose for a while.   I wanted this to be the longest chill 
period,   as it was about 5:30 am by this time.    

After about a 20 minute break from dancing (Kinda long for me),  I head
back to the main room to check on Mark.   I was somewhat dissapointed
in what his set was developing into,   so I head back downstairs to
discover that Jeno was literally GETTING OFF.    I quickly run upstairs
to tell Craig and Denese that Jeno was on downstairs.

Again,  I fell into a very pleasant floating trance state of mind.   Jeno
took me o a most pleasant trip,    playing a large variaty of housey
trancey material.

I head upstairs to cool off again,  and discover that Mark finally developed
his set.   Towards the end of his set,   he went into some really slow
dub stuff.

Heading downstairs,  I finished dancing Jeno's set until closing time.
When Jeno stopped,   I head back upstairs,  the daylight shining through
the skylight,  and people walking around in a daze.

So,  finishes yet another fine (And free) edition of WICKED....

Till next time...
C. Crunch

DC how I feel, but his S314 thing is scary!  

So I'm urging everyone to let them know! Here's an annotated list of who 
to yell at:

Senator Jim Exon(D-NE), the guy who wrote it.

Fax: 202-224-5213

and no, he ain't got no email. What's up with that? Some expert!

http://www.hooked.net/users/gmccann/freedom.html

PLEASE HELP PREVENT S314 FROM PASSING!!!

this bill can easily destroy everything that's been created, not only in our 
community, but the country as well.

friends, employers, professors, and just about everyone on my address list.

just maybe they'll get a clue and vote it down. If not.....

Love and respect,

Jonas

Subject: Richard Stallman: West Publishing seeks broad change in FOIA - for the worse
Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 23:52:50 -0800

Precedence: bulk


------- Forwarded Message

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 19:41:19 -0500
Message-Id: <199502090041.TAA16004@pogo.gnu.ai.mit.edu>
From: Richard Stallman <rms@gnu.ai.mit.edu>
Sender: gnu@ai.mit.edu
To: info-gnu@pogo.gnu.ai.mit.edu
Subject: West Publishing seeks broad change in FOIA - for the worse
Resent-From: info-gnu-request@prep.ai.mit.edu

Please read this information--it concerns a bill to give private
companies greatly expanded power over the use of information generated
for the government.  The apparent motivation is to perpetuate the
stranglehold which a single company, Westlaw, has obtained over access
to the records of US court decisions.

This bill is being rushed through the House, in what can only be an
attempt to evade public notice.  Even putting aside whether the bill
itself is a good one, such haste, for an issue which is not an
emergency, constitutes disrespect to the electorate.

The FSF is forwarding this information, which we received through the
CPSR and EFF.


Forwarded message:
From: James Love <love@essential.org>
Date: 7 Feb 1995 02:33:58 -0800

TAXPAYER ASSETS PROJECT - INFORMATION POLICY NOTE
CROWN JEWELS CAMPAIGN - Juris, Legal Information
February 7, 1995

We need help from everyone!!!!!!!!  Please distribute this
widely.  jamie love   (love@tap.org, 610/658-0880 or 202/387-
8030)


- -    Hearings set for today (Tuesday February 7) on bill
     containing special interest provision for West Publishing.
     Hearings will be held before the subcommittee on "Regulatory
     Affairs."

- -    House republicans have slated quick action on the bill.
     Subcommittee Mark-up is set for thursday and full committee
     mark-up is set for friday.  (Telephone and Fax numbers of
     committee members given below)

- -    House republicans introduce legislation with a section
     requested by West Publishing that will provide sweeping
     changes in federal freedom of information act, and prevent
     federal agencies from creating a public database that use
     the West Publishing page numbers to reference case law.

- -    The "West Provision" would also end its lawsuit with Tax
     Analyst, a Virginia publisher, who is seeking access to the
     Department of Justice JURIS database of court decisions in
     order to put the information into the public domain.  Tax
     Analysts alleges the JURIS database of court decisions are
     subject to FOIA and not protected by copyright.  A victory
     by Tax Analysts in this case will lead to a public domain
     database of federal court decisions.

- -    The West Provision in the legislation would extend far
     beyond West Publishing's struggle to maintain its grip on
     the market for legal information.  It would exclude all
     contractor generated records from the federal Freedom of
     Information Act.  Examples of databases that would be
     affected by provision would be the SEC's EDGAR database and
     the Department of Education ERIC database.

- -    Help needed in removing this special interest provision.
     Telephone and fax numbers for the Subcommittee on Regulatory
     Affairs are given below.

>From best we can determine, the so called "Paperwork Reduction
Act" bill was introduced late yesterday or will be introduced
early today.  We do not have a bill number yet.  There will be a
hearing on today (Tuesday February 7) before the "Subcommittee on
National Economic Growth, Natural Resources, and Regulatory
Affairs," more commonly referred to as the subcommittee on
"Regulatory Affairs."  Subcommittee Mark-up is set for thursday
and full committee (the apparently misnamed Committee on
Government Reform and Oversight) mark-up is set for friday.

A provision in this bill [Section 3518 (f) of the "Chairman's
Mark"] would do the following.

     If any person "adds value" to public information, the
     federal government would not have "any right to obtain,
     collect, acquire, disseminate, use or convert," the
     data, database or information product, or "any method
     used by the person to identify such resulting data,
     databases or information product," except "under terms
     that are expressly agreed to by such person."

This provision is being sold as a simple restatement of the law,
but that is a far from true (or more bluntly, a lie).  The
provision in the bill is so broad that it covers all contractor
performed work on behalf of agencies, and effectively exempts
contractor generated records from the federal Freedom of
Information Act (FOIA).  For example, since LEXIS "adds value" to
the EDGAR database by taking the incomming filings from the
government and putting them in a database, even if the government
had a copy of the database, it could not dissmeinate the records
without the consent of LEXIS.  Likewise, many databases, such as
the Department of Education ERIC database, are largely put
together by private contactors.  Indeed, if Oliver North had used
a private contractor for the White House email system, those
records would appear to be off limits to both FOIA and a
government supeana.  Moreover, the provison would apply even in
cases where the firm did not have a copyright or any other
protectable intellectually property right, a huge change in
federal law.

The provision would specifically apply to an active federal
lawsuit between West Publishing and Tax Analysts, over the
Department of Justice JURIS database.  West Publishing was a
contractor on JURIS, an online system run by the Department of
Justice, which contains several decades of federal court
decisions.  West Publishing is trying to prevent Tax Analysts
from obtaining copies of court decisions contained in the
government's JURIS database.  Tax Analyst believes the records
are subject to FOIA, and not protected by copyright.  If Tax
Analysts (fmi, Tom Field, 703/533-4400 or Eleanor Lewis 301/652-
3453) wins the law suit, which has been very expensive, it plans
to put the data into the public domain, creating a public
database of federal court decisions -- something that West
Publishing is fighting against.  Moreover, the West assertion of
its copyright of legal citations is being challenged in federal
court in New York by Hyperlaw, a small CD-ROM publisher (fmi,
Alan Sugarman, President, 212/877-1371, sugarman@panix.com).  If
Sugarman wins his case, the West provision would prevent the
Department of Justice from using the West citations in a public
database.


     WHAT CAN YOU DO?

We are asking people to send a brief message by fax the members
to the full committee, asking Congress to delete the special
interest provison for West Publishing.


               Committee on Government Reform and Oversight
                              104th Congress

Assets Project (TAP).  TAP was founded by Ralph Nader to monitor the
management of government property, including information systems and
data, government funded R&D, spectrum allocation and other government
assets.  TAP-INFO reports on TAP activities relating to federal
information policy.  tap-info is archived at ftp and gopher at
essential.org and cpsr.org.

Subject: free wicked
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 01:05:27 -0800 (PST)

sunday feb 12

i decided to set out early so that i could be sure not to wait in a long,
long line FOREVER in order to get into the free wicked at 1015 sat night. 
sure enough, not long after i arrived a nice fat line evolved behind me as
i waited to get in, circa 10:30.  but around 11 they started letting us
in.  as far as i could tell, nobody after that had to wait long at all.
silly me for thinking i had to get there early.  but i guess the wicked
crew know how to promote, by now. 

the mood was festive and excited. curiously, during the evening, it never 
seemed to get too crowded.  i had always heard over and over about how 
jampacked wicked's get, but this one was beautiful.  just the right # of 
people, i thought.  that is, there was always a place to stand, sit or 
dance as the mood hit. 

in the main room galen started out playing some new stuff, more 
"intellectaul" as someone put it, than his very lively, housey sunset 
sets from last summer.  i enjoyed it very much as it stimulated my 
mind as well as my body.  after that, i'm not sure who played, because i 
hightailed it into the front room because i wanted to hear darkhorse, who 
delivered evolved, beatiful, and very sexy "ambient," a genre of techno 
which defies definition, mysteriously.  

following darkhorse was another dj, who unfortuntely i can't tell you 
much of because i was roaming between the basement...strong beats...and 
the main room..more strong beats.  i was just then  starting to hear more 
hipswiveling housier rhythms and such in this music and was aboslutely 
loving the experience.  

because my psyche was only minimally enhanced i had to chill
out...starting around 3 or so (i know the time thanks to my brand new
indiglo watch, kudos timex megacorp) and that's when robbie hardkiss
started up in the front room..the i suppose ambient space.  his flow was a
little off (but it worked!), perhaps, i thought, but i liked very much the
music he played.  his style offers a shot at transcending the ordinary,
and i felt that i was glimpsing a possible future listening to his set. 
a dream, a good idea, a new twist on a musical theme, these things get me 
going without fail.

the folks at this party, howver, were what made my experience something i
will remmeber with fondness for as long as my brain holds up.  everyone
that i talked to was unabashedly friendly and fun.  and i also want to
say: do you people realize how incredibly fabulous you look when you dance
(or stand around, or whatever...)?  i guess i don't get out
much...(!)...but seeing such expressive, ecstatic dancing, (in the ambient
room (!)),and from EVERYBODY, was a treat for my soul. 

So thank you wicked, for a wonderful evening.

love,

ann

Hiya All,

Yes, non-rave galore ... I was shocked to see the thing about Apple censoring
anything due to sexual orientation since they are usually so open about things
like that. In this case I think the media has overrun the issue. I forwarded 
that message to an <unnamed>, very high up there and got the following response:
__________________
Date: 13 Feb 1995 09:34:14 -0700
From: "XXXXXXXXXXX" <XXXXXXXXXXXX@msgate.apple.com>
Subject: RE: Dianna Bolt: Is Apple Censoring A CD-ROM? (freedom, not rave-rel)
To: "Randall Wright" <randall>
X-Mailer: Mail*Link SMTP-MS 3.0.2

Hi Randall:

Good hearing from you, and I trust you're doing well. Thanks for sending me
the note about Voyager, but the facts are quite different. Apple has not yet
made a decision on whether to bundle this CD, and Voyager knows that. For some
reason, they have chosen to act out this scenario in the press, rather than
talking to us.

We have received a number of customer complaints, i.e., from school districts,
about this CD, and anytime that happens, we review our offerings. My sense is
that most of the complaints don't derive from the subject matter, but rather
relate to the fact that very young children can walk themselves through this
type of CD without adult guidance. Some of the descriptions of abortion (and
this seems to be the key issue) are rather graphic.

Hope this helps, and I hope to see you sometime soon.

Regards,

__________________________________

So, if this is the issue, I do agree that young kids should not be subjected to
graphic representations of abortion, etc. You should, of course, still feel 
free to hug your gay friends ... 8-) ...

Received: from [128.32.175.206] (gia2mac26.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.175.206]) by nature.Berkeley.EDU (8.6.9/8.6.9) with SMTP id LAA26691 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 13 Feb 1995 11:30:42 -0800
Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 11:30:42 -0800
Message-Id: <199502131930.LAA26691@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a lesson in death (not rave related, you buggers!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Some assorted ramblings, been a long time......

Mijos, last thursday the sun shone thru my skylight, illuminating my
cereal, and my chores fell off my mind and a trip to Bolinas materialized. 
Jenny and moi paired up with her rebel dogs, and the little red ball of
death (her b-mer) hurtled up hwy-1's curves towards a day in the sun and
wind.

                             And lucy on my tongue.

A perfect day, then it happened. A dead sea-lion, up on the high tide mark,
immersed in the sand. One of the dogs found it, and rolled oround on it in
ecstasy (go figure the canine pleasures!). And my understanding of it was
for the first time not touched by my grade school sentimentalism, instead I
understood the course of life, and the end is just that. I left a shell and
a colored stone near it, a reminder to myself and an offering the animal's
remains.

Not 5 minutes later, a seagull was found by the dogs, but it was still
alive. Injured, somehow, it couldn't fly, and stumbled and pecked in its
own defense. I ran and kept the dogs from damaging the crippled bird, and
as I picked it up, it knew I was no threat, that I had only the desire to
keep it from being mauled or drowned.

It sat in the sand, as I did, and we looked at each other for an hour. What
to do? The nature center was far away, and the bird was breathing heavy and
slow. I worked at one in Memphis, and this ird had no broken bones. They
would put it in a hot box and hope for recovery. But this bird had a wound
in its chest, looked like a buck-shot had pierced its sternum, and the
blood stained its feathers brown.

And I understood. Finally. We live our lives in denial, that we never age,
tie is our friend, we never die, it will happen to them, not to me.

This brid, this seal, live with death every day. They eat their fish, they
kill it, they go to the source. We use money. I got this paper, I give it
to the man at the counter, he sells me flesh. He in turn got the flesh from
someone else, for a lesser amount of paper. We seperate ourselves from the
source.

The bird, the seal, they know the source, and may become the source any
day. Like this day. They have no illusions, and they live with it every
second of their lives. Are they prepared?

The bird would not become a toy for all the dogs on this beach. The dogs
were contaminated by us, they were removed from the source. So I placed the
bird on a high point, hidden away from the dogs, but fully in the warmth of
the sun. It didn't try to run from me. It knew what I was up to.

It left this world safely and alone. Its own existence prepared it for this day.

A little boy walked with an older woman. Sometimes he would cling to her.
Sometimes he would run away and stare at the sea. As the wind died down, I
could hear him cry, sometimes he would cry in silence, no air left to
expell. This went on for an hour. Bad news, of some extreme sort, was being
dealt with. 

As I walked back past the seal, and saw where I left the bird, I wondered
what I will do when I am to leave. What will I do when I lose a friend?

I hope that bird told me enough.

Mijos, friday's 1015 (dubtribe, zendada,dakota): trip and a half!

Main room not set up yet, due to a hole in the floor, led me behind curtain
number 2, where disco and 80's rule! Lucky-star (Madonna) followed by Funky
Town, and gyrating hips powered by beer and collins glass cocktails.
Amusing to watch, but these guys were DRUNK. Tanked, pickled, blotto, and
very suburban.

So a frat boy sees my sailor suit and punches me in the arm (that male
bonding thing) and then lurches into the wall. People standing in the
doorway to the main room. People stumbling and pushing. Never has it been
so difficult to move around, let alone dance. Gringos can't handle their
liquor. Nuf sed.

A shame, I feel, to see Tracy and DubTribe perform for a crowd like this.
By 2 there was a mad rush for the bar, followed by the lay law (2am, alone?
Pick the closest body!) Not my cup of E :)
Reminds me why I hate clubs.The Doc was awesome, played a bunch of old,
predictable stuff, but hey, got my dancing fix. Followed by all-star
donuts, the hallmark of any good nite.

Wicked had an awesome chill room, good crowd, variety, same space, and
ins-n-outs. A marvel! Now, if we could work on that age thing......:)

Good to see some happy faces, and to spend my money on donuts and milk this
weekend.

Lotsa love,
 Milton and the E-Bee......

Hi Milton,

Thanx for sharing your experience with us.  It's been almost exactly a year 
ago that we here in the Seattle lost a good friend in a very tragic incident 
at the Choc-Lit Factory.  The bird's wisdom was presented to us in  a 
different light under different circumstances.  Yet wisdom is wisdom.  As 
hard as the lessons are at times, I remain grateful and in awe of the 
universe around us and within us.  I think that the relationship of your 
story with raving is not so far off.  We cannot fully appreciate/celebrate 
life without acknowledging death.  We cannot be truly happy without knowing 
sorrow.  Only through a balanced understanding of the positive and negative 
elements around us (and again, within) can we effectively channel the 
energies that we come in contact with into a pure expression of who we 
really are.

Peace

Tigger
 ----------
From: sfraves-owner
To: sfraves
Subject: a lesson in death (not rave related, you buggers!)
Date: Monday, February 13, 1995 11:30AM

Some assorted ramblings, been a long time......

Mijos, last thursday the sun shone thru my skylight, illuminating my
cereal, and my chores fell off my mind and a trip to Bolinas materialized.
Jenny and moi paired up with her rebel dogs, and the little red ball of
death (her b-mer) hurtled up hwy-1's curves towards a day in the sun and
wind.

                             And lucy on my tongue.

A perfect day, then it happened. A dead sea-lion, up on the high tide mark,
immersed in the sand. One of the dogs found it, and rolled oround on it in
ecstasy (go figure the canine pleasures!). And my understanding of it was
for the first time not touched by my grade school sentimentalism, instead I
understood the course of life, and the end is just that. I left a shell and
a colored stone near it, a reminder to myself and an offering the animal's
remains.

Not 5 minutes later, a seagull was found by the dogs, but it was still
alive. Injured, somehow, it couldn't fly, and stumbled and pecked in its
own defense. I ran and kept the dogs from damaging the crippled bird, and
as I picked it up, it knew I was no threat, that I had only the desire to
keep it from being mauled or drowned.

It sat in the sand, as I did, and we looked at each other for an hour. What
to do? The nature center was far away, and the bird was breathing heavy and
slow. I worked at one in Memphis, and this ird had no broken bones. They
would put it in a hot box and hope for recovery. But this bird had a wound
in its chest, looked like a buck-shot had pierced its sternum, and the
blood stained its feathers brown.

And I understood. Finally. We live our lives in denial, that we never age,
tie is our friend, we never die, it will happen to them, not to me.

This brid, this seal, live with death every day. They eat their fish, they
kill it, they go to the source. We use money. I got this paper, I give it
to the man at the counter, he sells me flesh. He in turn got the flesh from
someone else, for a lesser amount of paper. We seperate ourselves from the
source.

The bird, the seal, they know the source, and may become the source any
day. Like this day. They have no illusions, and they live with it every
second of their lives. Are they prepared?

The bird would not become a toy for all the dogs on this beach. The dogs
were contaminated by us, they were removed from the source. So I placed the
bird on a high point, hidden away from the dogs, but fully in the warmth of
the sun. It didn't try to run from me. It knew what I was up to.

It left this world safely and alone. Its own existence prepared it for this
day.

A little boy walked with an older woman. Sometimes he would cling to her.
Sometimes he would run away and stare at the sea. As the wind died down, I
could hear him cry, sometimes he would cry in silence, no air left to
expell. This went on for an hour. Bad news, of some extreme sort, was being
dealt with.

As I walked back past the seal, and saw where I left the bird, I wondered
what I will do when I am to leave. What will I do when I lose a friend?

I hope that bird told me enough.

> 
>smoke both of them at 
> raves...i love to smoke and dance at the same time
....i hate alcohol probably about as much as you hate 
> cigarettes, and true it does piss me off when it gets in my way at raves, 
> but shit--we've all got different reasons for coming to raves

Please consider that second hand smoke very directly jeapordizes the 
health of the people around you. Someone drinking alcohol near you 
will not very directly violate your health (of course the alcohol 
consumer's behavior might, but that's a different topic altogether). 
Unless the people arond your smoke have previously consented to 
breathing your second hand smoke, you are passively violating the 
health of those people around you. I think it's extremely rude...I 
even thought this type of thing was rude and unjustified when I was a 
smoker, so I'd only smoke in places where my smoke would not directly 
effect anyone around me...but then I had to realize that every smoke 
does have an effect on somebody because it contributes to the smog 
layer. and then I quit smoking for entirlely selfish reasons :)

>> >remember the *quality* of food you're eating is higher in 
>> meat than in grain; 
>
>If your value system is such that "quality" means "more protein"!
>
>(It seems to me that people who enjoy eating from the upper-emd of 
>the food chain sometimes need reminding that their values are not necessarily 
>universal)

Also, the higher on the food chain, the higher the concentration of
toxins, mutagens, carcinogens, caused by our somewhat lax
laws&practices on dumping and pollution.

Recently, for example, there were health department warnings that
people fishing in the SF Bay should avoid eating more than 2 fish per
month  due to dangerous concentrations of toxins.

Also, this is one of the reasons why you should never eat a tobacco
smoker.

I personally don't mind people smoking at raves, as long as they aren't
smoking tobacco. I would love to see more raves (also concerts, bars,
etc) where tobacco smoking was strictly prohibited and strongly
enforced.

The thing that I really hate about smokers is that they feel it is
their right to make you smell their putrid stench. And they get all
huffy and pissed off (as if their innate rights to be bothersome were
being violated) when told to smoke elsewhere, or when they're told the
law prohibits smoking in restaurants.

Someone posted...

>even thought this type of thing was rude and unjustified when I was a 
>smoker, so I'd only smoke in places where my smoke would not directly 
>effect anyone around me...but then I had to realize that every smoke 
>does have an effect on somebody because it contributes to the smog 
>layer. and then I quit smoking for entirlely selfish reasons :)

Niels says....

>Ahem!!  well said...   When I go to raves,   I have special medication
>I have to take that de-sensitizes me to the allergic reactions I get
>when near someone smoking.   It costs me anywhere between $10 - $15
>PER PILL.   I always try my very best not to get or intrude on anyone
>smoking,  so I very carefully try and select a safe place to dance/chill
>in a place not CURRENTLY occupied by someone smoking.   However!  If
>someone smokes under or near a fan or between me and the ventilation
>source,   I will not hesitate to ask them to move somewhere else.

When I plan to be somewhere for a long time,  I very carefully analyse
people around me who might be smokers.    I look for lighters,  packs,
or other telltale signs of tobacco smoking things.   I simply avoid
those areas.   It is when a smoker invades my breathing space,  is
what I normally object to.    Naturally,  they don't intend to cause
any harm,   they just don't realize what they are doing.   The real
bummer is that I have to take expensve anti-allergy medication to
counter effect the smoke.    It works very good.    I don't get sick
while in smokey room as long as I am able to breath fresh air every
20 minutes if possible.   Thus the need to go outside every once in
a while.   Unfortunately,  it's VERY EXPENSIVE...   about $10 to $20
depending on quantity.    I consume about 2 capsels for 4 raves.
Thats why I like consecutive raving... :-)  So, to all you smokers out
there,  us non smokers only want you to be more aware of where you
hold your cigerette.    Just a few feet can make ALL the difference.
Direct smoke causes me ITENSE PAIN if any gets directly in my eyes.

Nuff said, My $.02

:-)  

Please note....  I didn't bring up this subject....  :-)

Crunch

One handy hint for smokers that's obvious, but really works; use those 
pacifiers... it really cuts down on the amount you want to smoke.
\the only trouble is , when you finally do smoke you end up biting through
the filter which can be embarrassing, especially if you're in the middle of getting
a backrub :-). 

The real trouble is, once you start smoking at a rave, it's really hard to
stop, especially if everyone else in the group is smoking. The best solution
is to have an area that's either really well ventilated, or exposed to
the great outdoors. Babylon in Greensboro keeps the big fire-escape doors 
open, and has some couches and chairs nearby, but out of the escape route. 
Definitely a good place to go for those oxygen restriction moments.

\Oh, almost forgot... aparently ephedrine can also be used as an allergy 
medicine. Seems a bit of a waste though.

Simon // Coming to you from Cyberia, London's first online cafe, playing 
      // some rather dubious trance, but with pretty good Lattes

Subject: smoking

Precedence: bulk

Here are some interesting statistics about smoking and second-hand
smoke. They're from Larry Laudan's "The Book of Risks: Fascinating 
facts About the Chances We take Every Day" At the very end are a few 
tips for conscientious smokers. Enjoy!

SMOKING (NONSMOKERS MAY WANT TO SKIP TO INFO ON SECONDARY SMOKE):

Among men, smokers are twice as likely to die prematurely as nonsmokers.
More generally, if you smoke a pack of cigarettes a day, you run about 
a 70% greater chance of dying this year than nonsmokers of your age and sex.

The proportion of cancer deaths linked to smoking: 30%

Most prople (roughly 4 out of 5) who get lung cancer are smokers
or former smokers. All the same, most smokers and former smokers never
develop lung cancer. (About 1 in every 250 smokers or former smokers 
develops lung cancer each year.)

Among nonsmokers, men are 30-50% more likely to develop lung cancer than 
women. But among heavy smokers, women may run twice the risk of lung 
cancer that men do. (This latter claim is still contested by some 
researchers.)

Cigarette smokers have a higher incidence than nonsmokers of 
cancers of the lungs, larynx, esophagus, bladder, pancreas, kidney 
and lip.

Smoking two packs of cigarettes daily is 10 times more life 
threatening than usual levels of cigar smoking and 14 times more
dangerous than usual levels of pipe smoking.

Smokers are 1000% more likely to develop chronic emphysema and 
chronic bronchitis than nonsmokers.

White men and women smoke cigarettes in roughly 
equal numbers. Black men are 50% more likely to smoke than black women.

Those teenagers who try smoking are 16 times more likely to smoke
as adults than those who do not.

Women who smoke are likely to have menopause 1-2 years earlier 
than those who don't smoke.

Older smokers have a lower rate of Alzheimer's disease than nonsmokers 
of comparable ages.

A smoker is twice as likely to commit suicide as a nonsmoker.

The average american consumes 2500 cigarettes a year. Because most do not
smoke at all, the use of cigarettes among smokers themselves is more 
than double this figure. (doing the math: 2500/year=7.02 cigarettes/day;
so an average smoker smokes about 15-17 cigarettes/day).

Your odds of stopping smoking on the first attempt: less than 20%

Many smokers will attempt to stop but fewer than 50% will succeed,
even after repeated attempts.

Smokers who quit smoking before age 50 run 1/2 the risk of dying in the 
next fifteen years as those who continue smoking.

Longtime smokers who quit gain about 5 lbs. on average; 1 in 20 
quitters gains 20 lbs. 

The state with the highest per capita loss of life due to smoking: 
Kentucky. The state with the lowest loss of life: Utah, where fewer 
than one in seven adults smokes.

Men are most likely to smoke in alaska. women are most likely to 
smoke in Nevada. Although men are more likely to smoke than women,
Oregonian women outsmoke their male counterparts.

SECOND-HAND SMOKE

The risk that you will develop a fatal cancer this year caused by 
exposure to secondary tobacco smoke: 1 in 80,000. This is roughly the
same risk as that of dying from accidental poisoning.

Paraphrased: smoking tobacco is the second greatest causer of cancer in 
America. The greatest: poor diet.

Drinking two glasses of milk a day poses a greater risk of death 
from cancer than a lifetime of exposure to secondary smoking.

If you keep a pet bird at home, you are 500% more likely to get lung 
cancer than you are from exposure to secondary smoke.

Eating a smoked pork chop once a week is twice as likely to kill 
you as secondary smoke will.

If you are exposed to secondary smoke but eat green spinach once a week,
you are less likely to die of cancer than if you are never exposed to 
smoke and eat no spinach.

Driving a small car rather than a large one is much more likely to 
kill you than a lifetime of exposure to secondary smoke.

All of the following substances carry possible human carcinogens, i.e. 
they produce tumors in rodents when administered in massive doses.
(This is the leading method that both the EPA and the Center for 
Disease Control use to determine the carcinogenicity of substances.)  
Importantly, the carcinogenicity is not due to any additives or pesticide
residues; it occurs naturally in the substance or its production:

Bacon, booze, bread, Broccoli, Cabbage, Celery, Coffee, Colas, 
Cooked meats, Figs, Fruit, Milk, Mushrooms, Mustard, Parsley, 
Parsnips, Peanuts, Pepper, Shrimp, Strawberries, Tap water (chloroform from 
chlorine), Tea (herbal)

Food for thought-

Jocelyn

p.s. tips for conscientious smokers: don't smoke on the dance floor.
if there are ins and outs, take it outside-unless there's some 
other prohibitive element to going outside; e.g. unsafe area, 
secret, non-permitted location that prohibits loitering, an hour 
wait in line to get back inside. If you're going to smoke inside-
find the least trafficed area around the bar- smoke there. Find 
someone near the bar (not at- nonsmokers need water too) who is 
already smoking. chances are, the area is already clear of those 
who do not wish to be exposed. Lastly, if anyone who is not 
smoking is within an arms length of you, take a step over to him/her 
and ask him/her if it would bother him/her. Put your cigarette out in 
an ashtray or carry the butt (unlit) to a trashcan.

  OK, it's my turn on the soapbox... 
 
Niels P. Mayer wrote: 
 
>The thing that I really hate about smokers is that they feel it is 
>their right to make you smell their putrid stench.  And they get all 
>huffy and pissed off (as if their innate rights to be bothersome were 
>being violated) when told to smoke elsewhere, or when they're told the 
>law prohibits smoking in restaurants. 
 
  NO.  Despite recent restrictions on smoking, it is still legal to do so in 
clubs.  If you want no smoking in bars and clubs, get some signatures, put in 
some effort, and get a law passed.  In other words, get off of your whiny 
little ass, and do something about it.  No smoking in restaurants, fine.  If 
the community passes the law, I will abide by it.  Until then, in clubs, no 
dice. 
 
  When was the last time you mentioned to any event promoter, "Gee, we really 
ought to have some nice, ventilated room somewhere where the smokers can go 
and chill without feeling like second class citizens.".  Or has you attitude 
been, "Make them all stand outside in the cold and the rain and have them 
freeze their smoky little butts off.". 
 
  I try to be considerate about my smoking.  If there is some designated or 
preferred area where I can take my drink, and have a cigarette without 
bothering other people, I am happy to do so.  What bothers most smokers is 
when we are chastised, ridiculed, and harassed for doing something that is 
LEGAL to do, and when people want to make NO provisions for us to do so. 
 
  Remember, we live in a country where people shoot doctors for performing 
legal operations.  If it is legal, either change the law or shut up. 
 
BrainChild.

actually i think by going into a rave (or a bar or a club) you are

------------------

yeah, let's get real people, I generally assume that I'll be coming
into contact with (among other things) the unknown when I go out.  Sure
it's nice to avoid cigarette smoke and I agree that the smokers (I'm *not*
a smoker, except at raves, go figure, for some reason I really want to smoke
at raves...) should be considerate about where they smoke vis a vis proper
ventilation, etc., but I really have to wonder what planet you think you're
on if you're doing e and complaining about 2nd hand smoke.  Especially if
you're doing e every week or more, I'd say you're in greater risk from the
complex amphetamines than from cigarette smoke...  I hear the complaints
and I'd like to see people cooperate on it, but outlawing this or that; I
ain't with it.  I think that smokers *should* be considerate and smoke in
"the right kinds of places" (i.e. outside, or not where there's no ventilation,
etc.), but I wouldn't want to see "no smoking" at raves in general as I think
that's going too far.  just my 2...


*

tips for conscientious non-smokers: go dance somewhere else ;^)

I think sweaty guys with no shirts and a lack of deodorant are
dangerous to my health and if one of em starts dancing near me
I Move Somewhere Else ...

And if the whole place is filled with em I Leave The Party ...

Personally, I think ravers and housey folks are about the Most 
conscientious smokers you'll find anywhere and all this preaching
is being directed at the choir ... 

Under most circumstances we All know that so 
much space is gonna be Shared so all this health concern
is a Mute Point - you're there by Choice - it boils down to how well
we respect each other In That Space.  There is no respect if you adopt
some bullshit moral high ground about who should move cuz of who's
behavior is the most harmful.  We're talking strictly about an
issue of personal comfort at a party - what have you done to
make yourself comfortable before you decide to share your
problems with me?

i used to drink
 i used to smoke
  i used to dance the hoochy coo

I've never seen uptight non-smokers in a huff at a hiphop
party ... maybe there's a lesson there about Vibe and Respect 
Dave

Howdy People,

For those that couldn't get through the other day to order "The Premierian
Estates,"  the Funk Junkies informed me that you can now order 24 hours at
1-800-291-3014 Visa/Master. This tape will still be offered for $9 including
shipping.

For those who don't know, "The Premierian Estates" is an album collection of
11 rave/house/disco/funk groove released in Illinois by my newly formed label,
Black Raven.  This album recieved good PR and sales and I'm offering the
remaining copies to anyone whose interested in hearing some good Chicago dance
music.It is availiable on Digalog-cassettes only...

About me, I was raised in the Chicago house and new wave scene and specializes
in creating funky groove tracks that utilizes secret experimental techniques
passed on to me by many of the legendary Trackmasterz in the Windy City. My
style of music can be best describe as Lil Louis type tracks with a New Order
atmosphere....

If you like, I'm still willing to FTP some .au samples of this album to your
site and hopefully, I can get them archived at hyperreal.com soon....

Please e-mail me if you wish to mail-order or have any questions....

Peace,
Zheam

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: megatrip@best.com (David Dei)
Subject: Smoking the Status Quo
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

here's my 2cents on the smoking thing.

(and let the record state that I'm not a smoker)

Way back in the 50s, the US conducted a number of above ground nuclear
tests that managed to distribute radioactive plutonium into the earths
atmosphere. Turns out, that the best way to absorb plutonium is via the
respiratory system. So without our consent, a large part of the population
were exposed to significant amounts of radiation. Couple this with the
airborne introduction of other radioactive products as a result of -
uranium mining, poor safety controls (for instance in one case a couple of
rusting barrels o' plutonium remained outside one facility for years
increasing atmospheric radiation levels over new york state), accidentl
releases, scheduled radiation releases and degausing from powerplants and
such like.

We end up in the situation today, where the liklihood of lung carcenomas
has been significantly increased.  Now it is relatively easy to see where
this is heading - increased liablity by the Federal government for
instances of lung cancer, except for one problem: cancer does not carry
with it a flag saying "i was made by this particular carcinogin" So we see
the rise of attempts to pin the increase in cancers on other factors in the
population - hence the idea of "secondary smoke" as if this one single
factor should be responsible -, as one epidemologist working on pollution
control told me, "its the stuff you can't see that's the problem"  Of
course, the interesting thing is this - Smokers are more likely to get lung
cancer, as their resporatory systems are already stressed. I investigated a
story once regarding the effects of increased air pollution and asked a
state health official who it was that would most likely be affected: his
answer - the very young and the very old and those with a pre-exhisting
lung condition.  Couple this with the fact that kids nowadays have a
greater likelhood of being born with asthma and bronchial problems, and we
have all the makings of a great skapegoat - the tobacco industry. The point
that I am making is not that smokers are to blame, but that this is a
secondary catalyst for health and allergy problems in an already stressed
invironment. One has only to thing of the WW11 generation smoking 100s of
cigarettes a day without filters or low tar/low nicotine and living to ripe
old ages to wonder if there's something wrong with the humans circa 1990?

Another  unnerving prospect of all this anti-smoking stuff is the likelhood
that smoking itself will be banned causing all pot-smokers to stick out
like sore thumbs - then the mere lighting of something and toking on it
gives the cops reasonable cause for arrest - without the hitch of having to
first establish that its marijauna being smoked - imagine being spotted by
an infrared telescopic sight smoking in the privacy of your apartment -
doors gets broken down and the police arrive - yep its america post-1994
(Orwell was only out by ten years)

-david dei

            megatrip@best.com

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Dear Sfraves;

	With all the talk about smoking I just had to tell you all about
how I quit smoking cig's in 1982 and never went back. I will celabrate 13
years this September. I quit cold turkey; almost. At that point in my life
I was smoking both cig's and other substances(wink wink) ok weed;  for
those who didn't fiqure it out. I wanted to give up at least one of them
and since I didn't get much head satisfaction out of tobacco cig's I
decided that they where the one to go. I was smoking about a pack of
Marboro Red's a day; and at that time cig's were approaching a $1.00/pack.
First I said to myself that I would never pay a $1.00 for a pack of cig's;
I also did it before I started college; because I knew the pressure of an
engineering cirriculum would only tax and tempt me to smokem. So while
over summer break; one day I just put them dowmn and never went back. So
whats the secret; when I just couldn't stand it anymore; I mean when I was
absolutey nuts after putting it off and putting it off; thats the urge to
smoke; I would smoke a joint. It worked; the key is that when you get the
urge say to youself that; I'll wait an hour or a half hour and then smoke
a cig. Most of the time just by putting it off I would either get busy doing
something or forget about it.  But I always knew that if it just got to
bad; that I could smoke a joint.  Also; for at least the first six months
you can't even smoke one. If you have to smoke; smoke a joint; it helps
will the craving and it gives you a reward for not smoking a cig; a very
nice reward if I do say so my self. Also; don't get drunk; your resistance
will drop like a rock if you drink and you will me right back where you
started smoking cig's for what are they now $2.75/pack. God; I can't tell
you how glad I am that I quit;  and no I don't smoke grass continuously; I
only smoke occassionally for obbvoius reasons. It changed my life in a
positive way; and I wish each and evryone of you good luck. Also; when you
quit get rid of all your ashtrayes and cig reminders; this is also
helpful. If your tring to quit be kind to youself; go out and get a
massage or a good meal; love and reward yourself; look in the mirror and
tell youself that you are a great and wonderful person because you have
quit for x number of days.  Affirmations are very important; write them
down and put them on your bathroom mirror; and if you fall be kind to
youself as well; you are human and you are allowed to make mistakes; just
pick up where you left off. if you have no one in you life to tell you
that your wonderful let me know because I'm wonderful and your no
different than me; so I'll tell ya. WE ARE ALL FANTASTIC AND DESERVE LOVE
AND A GOOD LIFE SO DON'T POISON YOURSELF WITH CIG'S; ARE MAKER DIDN'T MAKE
TRASH;  THE HUMAN BODY IS A FANTASTIC LIVING THING; YOU ARE YOUR CELLS;
EACH CELL IS A BASIC LIVING ORGANISM. So love yourself and again if you
can't let me know; your worth it no matter what anyone else said's. I 
know this in my heart without ever having met you because again your no 
different than me; and I'm wonderful.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		   aka Brian Darkness, LMT

		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

Received: from taz.hyperreal.com by get.wired.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA28734; Tue, 14 Feb 1995 16:58:25 -0800

From: Mike Wertheim <mw@ultraviolet.com>
X-Sender: mw@taz.hyperreal.com
To: sfraves@ultraviolet.com
Subject: Ultra Violet Recordings
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950214165528.26719A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I know that commercial postings are in general frowned upon, so I am
only going to do this once.  I figured this might be of some general
interest to sfraves because we are providing an incredibly inexpensive 
way to get some local San Francisco techno.

This is the introductory edition of the Ultra Violet online newsletter.
Future editions of the newsletter will be *much* shorter than this first
edition and will not be posted to sfraves.  To be added to our mailing list,
send mail to mw@ultraviolet.com and we will add you.  We will send out a new
newsletter whenever we have new releases to announce (every few months or so).

Contents of this newsletter...

	Ultra Violet Recordings WWW home page
	Who We Are
	Submitting demo tapes
	The Ultraviolet Catastrophe (re-release of "The Trip" 12-inch)
	Deluxe (release of Deluxe 12-inch and full-length Deluxe CD)
	URB Magazine review of Deluxe CD
	Mail order Ultra Violet CDs for only $9.99 each


--- Ultra Violet Recordings WWW home page ---

If you have access to the World Wide Web, check out our UVR home page,
located at "http://ultraviolet.com/uvr/".  The home page contains most
of the information from this newsletter, plus graphics and audio from
our upcoming releases.


--- Who We Are ---

Founded in 1994, San Francisco-based Ultra Violet Recordings was
formed to release high-quality, technologically-innovative electronic
music.  The label carries compact discs, vinyl 12" singles and
select integrated media products.  Ultra Violet seeks to showcase
the talents of artists who compose complex psycho-acoustic listening
experiences.  From dance to ambient, and dub to experimental, UVR
spans a vast sonic spectrum.

Ultra Violet Recordings is a collaboration between former Ultraviolet
Catastrophe members Mike Wertheim and Jeff Taylor.  In addition to
co-founding UVR, Mike was also responsible for starting Twitch, the
successful techno remix service.  Jeff Taylor, too elusive to interview,
was once quoted as saying, "Yes, I am Pink."


--- Submitting demo tapes ---

If you would like to submit a demo tape to UVR, please mail it to us at
this address:

Ultra Violet Recordings
945 Taraval Street, Suite 303
San Francisco, CA  94116
USA

Demo tapes will not be returned.


--- The Ultraviolet Catastrophe ---

The Ultraviolet Catastrophe (UVC) was a three-person studio project,
consisting of Jon Drukman, Jeff Taylor and Mike Wertheim.  UVC released a
chart-topping 12" single called "The Trip" on Twitch Records in the spring
of 1992.  "The Trip" was re-released in 1993 by Hardkiss Music, with remixes
done by Jon Williams.  The Ultraviolet Catastrophe also did a number of
remixes for Twitch Remix Service in 1992 and 1993.

The Ultraviolet Catastrophe disbanded in 1994.  Jon went on to start up his 
own studio, while Mike and Jeff went on to form Ultra Violet Recordings.
Jeff is currently creating music under the name Deluxe.

Ultra Violet Recordings has re-released the original Twitch version of
"The Trip".  Here is the catalog information for "The Trip"...

	Ultraviolet Catastrophe - "The Trip" (vinyl 12" single)
	catalog number UVR-01-01-1

	track	time	bpm	title
	A1	7:30	125	"The Trip"
	B1	8:30	125	"Trip Harder"

Rumor has it that some new remixes of "The Trip" are planned for release
on Ultra Violet later this year.


--- Deluxe ---

Deluxe is the solo project of former UVC member Jeff Taylor.  Ultra Violet
has released a full-length CD by Deluxe, titled Let the Magic Flow.  Ultra
Violet has also released one 12-inch single from Deluxe, titled "Futura".

Here is the catalog information for "Futura"...

	Deluxe - "Futura" (vinyl 12" single)
	catalog number UVR-02-02-1

	track	time	bpm	title
	A1	7:48	128	"Futura" (Deluxe mix)
	A2	7:21	122	"Eluxtria" (CD mix)
	B1	6:26	128	"Futura" (Young American Primitive mix)
	B2	7:02	129	"Futura" (Deluxe Mindfuck / Exist Dance mix)

(The printed labels on this 12" are incorrect.  The labels list the 
B-side tracks in reverse order.)

Here is the catalog information for Let the Magic Flow...

	Deluxe - Let the Magic Flow
	catalog number UVR-02-01-2 (full-length CD)

	trk  time  bpm	title
	1    8:30  128	The Dark Beautiful
	2    6:00  128	Futura
	3    8:16  128	Snowcrash
	4    7:45  100	Sapphire
	5    5:57  100	Diaphanous
	6    8:04  100	Into the Stone Age
	7    6:33  122	Eluxtria
	8    5:28  129	Cinnamon
	9    6:00  129	Freestyle
	10   5:57  100	Words from the Melting Heart

	total playing time:  68:30


--- URB Magazine review of Deluxe CD ---

>From URB Magazine, Issue #39.  Review by Tamara Palmer.

Deluxe - Let the Magic Flow (Ultra Violet Recordings)  

Deluxe is the first full-length solo project from San Francisco's Jeff
Taylor, a man otherwise known for his work in the trippy trio The
Ultraviolet Catastrophe and for the standout track on Silent's From Here to
Tranquility compilation, "Diaphanous" by The Dark Beautiful.  A long time in
creation, Taylor's opus is a tribute to the many musical influences that has
shaped his life, from dub to electro, and from advanced electronic head
music to the perfectly structured pop songs of Stock-Aitken-Waterman.

All of these genres and more are explored on Let the Magic Flow, making for
a very elastic, free-form work as a whole.  A piece never lingers in one
spot for long and always flows into the next track.  For the club-oriented
minds, there are two tracks in particular that stand out.   "Freestyle" is
for the harder techno crowd and "Eluxtria" is much more playful and housey.
Though these are geared towards the dancefloor, most other tracks are
intended for a more private listen.  Even in the more personal setting, the
moods are forever conflicting.  "Futura", for example, is aggressive and
robotic with its vocoded sounds, while "Sapphire" is gentle and melodic with
a passionate male vocal.  The most finely crafted track is called
"Snowcrash" which is at times chilling yet always driving in a Kraftwerkian
sort of fashion.

Deluxe's strength is found in the determination to probe varying types of
sounds within a structured, contained unit.  There is a sense of progression
in each track, which is not always a common trait in electronic music.
Enlisting the talented help of artists such as Young American Primitive and
Exist Dance's Mike Kandel for remix treatment on the album's singles, Deluxe
surrounds himself in good company.  He is earning his place there.


--- Mail order Ultra Violet CDs for only $9.99 each ---

You can mail order Ultra Violet CDs from Noteworthy Music.  Noteworthy
sells Ultra Violet CDs at the incredibly low price of $9.99 per CD,
plus postage.  (The postage charge to deliver one CD within the US is $2.65
for US Mail Parcel Post or $3.75 for US Mail Priority Mail.)

There are three ways to order...

- To order CDs electronically through the WWW, point your Web browser at
  "http://www.netmarket.com/".  You need a credit card to order CDs via the
  WWW.

- To order CDs over the phone, call Noteworthy Music between 8:30 am
  and 6:00 pm Eastern Standard Time.  In the US or Canada, dial toll free at
  800.648.7972.  Outside of the US or Canada, dial 01.603.883.9551.  You need
  a credit card to order CDs over the phone.

- To pay by check, make your check payable to "Noteworthy Music" and mail it
  to:
	Noteworthy Music
	17 Airport Road
	Nashua, NH  03063
	USA

  If you pay by check, we recommend that you call Noteworthy first to confirm
  that your order is in stock and to confirm the amount that you are sending.

It is not possible to order Ultra Violet vinyl releases from Noteworthy.
All Ultra Violet releases (both CD and vinyl) are available by mail order
from Soundworks Records in San Francisco (phone 01.415.487.3980).

Retailers can order Ultra Violet releases from Pacific Collective
Distribution (phone 01.415.864.4981).  Retailers can also order
Ultra Violet releases from other distributors -- including Watts, Edie,
Silent and Caroline -- but Pacific Collective has the lowest prices.

	id AA04331; Wed, 15 Feb 95 10:09:07 PST

 Wed, 15 Feb 1995 10:09:57 -0800 (PST)
Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 10:09:56 -0800 (PST)
Subject: KNAC is going off the air
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Message-Id: <01HN2OXKEMQA008OT6@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com",EDEN1::IN%"socal-raves@ucsd.edu"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

this is definitely non-rave related.

it is, tho, important to anyone who believes in freedom of music!

KNAC, pure rock 105.5 in Long Beach, is going off the air at 2pm today,
  after nine years of playing music that the more pedestrian, yuppified,
    playlist-oriented radio stations have abhorred.  they were first to
      make metallica a major radio presence, they debuted alice in chains,
        and basically played any record which had an "explicit lyrics"
          tipper gore label on it; at KNAC those were considered badges
            of honor.
long mimicked by stations all over the country, KNAC persisted and led
  the pack of heavymetal/hard rock stations, never straying into the
    classic rock dinosaur vein, or the computer-programmed playlist.
      KNAC t-shirts can be spotted at clubs in europe and japan, their
        bumper stickers are displayed prominently on cars all over LA.
the point i'm trying to make is that this is one of the LAST TRUE
  INDEPENDENT voices of music on the airwaves, unfettered by coporate
    greed and unblindered by "politically correct" social mores.
we are ALL losing some of our freedom today.
  we are ALL losing some of our freedom today.
    we are ALL losing some of our freedom today.
      we are ALL losing some of our freedom today.
        we are ALL losing some of our freedom today.

|_|\_\_| \_|_| |_|\____|


remember those letters; they're as important as the bill of rights.

Dave Scruton

From: jocelyn@hal.com (Jocelyn Cordell)

Here are some interesting statistics about smoking and second-hand
smoke. They're from Larry Laudan's "The Book of Risks: Fascinating 
facts About the Chances We take Every Day"

>If you are exposed to secondary smoke but eat green spinach once a week,
>you are less likely to die of cancer than if you are never exposed to 
>smoke and eat no spinach.

Here's the answer: The smokers should get together and set-up a spinach
stand next to the DJ.

;^)

Tony

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: Ambient Jungle (ROBERT RICH)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502151622.A3115-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Dear Sfraves;

	Lastnight which was Valentine's day I went out to see Robert Rich
Live. I didn't know anything about him before I went; but I was very
pleased at what I heard. He was really good; he started off each new song
by playing what looked like some type of electronic flute; pretty neat. 
He would play several notes and then do things with those sounds to create
a very daring; intellectually stimulating, & moving ambient soundscape. I
didn't stay for the whole show because it was Tuesday Night; and I was
sick with that vicious resilient bonchitis that going around. I wish I had
though because it was really cool; I was just able to float along with the
music in and out of some pretty heavy thought processies; very
stimulating; with out drugs!!!!!! If I'd had more money I would have even
brought a CD which they had for sale over in the corner. It was my first
time at 650 Howard Street; not a bad venue; however it was freezing the
guy at the front door kept the door open the whole time; not very cool or
energy efficent. Also Robert Rich play a string instrument which was like
a guitar only that it was flat and lying on a table; some pretty awsome
sounds out of it; he also had a Korg 01W + 2 other keyboards. For $7.00 it
was a pretty good show; at least what I saw and heard of it; the visual
portion wasn't bad for slides; and what looked like either CTHUGHA or
Fractal INT stuff on the monitors pretty tight all and all. I would
recoomend that if he comes back into town; that he would be worth checking
out; the audience was a real melting pot of people; races; ages and
musical genres. I'll give it :):):) out of 5 smiley faces; just kidding;
hehe. 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		   aka Brian Darkness, LMT

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com
		Majornet:	Brian Darkness @LIB
		Worldlink:	Brian Darkness @LIB; Stop by and will chat
		Chatlink:	System #48; ditto
		IRC:		Channel #rave; ditto

		Net Person & Virtual Cybernetic Being
			(FUKENGRUVEN:)

		"The earth is a womyn and she will rise"

				Libana from Fire Within

no no no no no, but they are really really sorry--the problem was that 
the berkeley aquatic park was being patrolled by a cop car--law 
enforcement officials made it very clear to those of us trickling into 
the area early (3:30 or so maybe 4 i don't know) that the area was off

that never happened, and last i heard they're thinking about trying again 
tonight, and i have no idea where but i'm pretty skeptical of anything 
being pulled off at the aquatic park anytime in the near future.  the 
first cop car seemed to be on some sort of regular patrol (not in party 
busting confrontation mode), and the ones that came in later to help ask 
us to leave seemed pretty determined to get rid of us quickly and 
efficiently.  oh well...so once again the powers that be are against 
us...i doubt anything will happen tonight, but if it does, enjoy it for 
me, because i've got shit to do tomorrow and can't spend another night 
moonsearching.  :) jessica

Well, it finally happened last night.  After being run off by the 
authorities for being in the Aquatic park after closing, an making a 
series of phone calls.  We found out where the Party was at.  It turned 
out that after being run out of the park, everyone went to CB's loft to 
play some tunes.  I had a wonderful time.  Garth, Markie and Thomas 
played one for one for a few hours,  keeping a wonderful groove for 
everyone to enjoy.
