Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 13:48:12 -0800 (PST)
>Subject: Mexico news from IGC
>
>
>     2. Soldiers and police are arresting and torturing
>     civilians.  The village of Rosario Ibarra, in the
>     municipality of Ocosingo, was occupied by the Federal
>     Army on February 11, during which time soldiers
>     threatened and tortured various members of the community.
>     A representative of the community, who was not
>     identified, was reported to have had his arm cut off.
>     The soldiers also threatened to kill the children of the
>     women in the community if they refused to give
>     information about the EZLN.
>
>     3. In the community of Guadalupe Tepeyac, in the
>     municipality of Las Margaritas, the military violently
>     evicted people who had taken refuge in the medical
>     clinic.  These people were under the responsibility of
>     the International Red Cross (ICRC).  The ICRC was also
>     expelled from the zone, violating the Zona Franca
>     agreements signed in 1994.
>
>     In Guadalupe Tepeyac, hundreds of armored vehicles and
>     soldiers, supported by helicopter gunships, arrived in
>     the area February 10 and took up positions in
>     Aguascalientes, site of the first National Democratic
>     Convention.  This same operation was repeated in the
>     villages of La Garrucha, Champa San Agustin, Santa Lucia,
>     Monte Libano, Taniperlas, La Union, and others.
>
>     5. In order to isolate the zone completely, the Federal
>     Army imposed a military encirclement, reenforcing the
>     rearguard with heavily armed military roadblocks which
>     prevented the international and national press and
>     observors from entering the zone.
>
>     Due to the current situation, CONPAZ makes an urgent call to
>send faxes and telegrams to the Mexican government authorities,
>demanding the following:
>
>     a) A complete halt to the military operations that began
>     February 9.
>
>     b) A reinitiation of the negotiations and dialogue in
>     order to find a peaceful solution to the conflict.
>
>     c) Respect for the physical and psychological integrity
>     of the civilian population trapped inside the military
>     encirclement.
>
>     d) An opening of the military encirclement so that the
>     press and observors may be allowed to enter the zone of
>     conflict in order to verify the situation of human
>     rights.
>
>     e) The investigation of the denunciations made against
>     the Federal Army, punishing according to the law those
>     who are responsible of any crimes, in order to prevent a
>     repetition of the military impunity which has continued
>     to violate human rights throughout 1994.
>
>     Faxes and telegrams should be sent to:
>
>     Dr. Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Leon
>     Presidente de Mexico
>     Palacio Nacional, Mexico D.F.
>     fax: 011-522-515-4783
>
>     Lic. Esteban Moctzuma Barragan
>     Secretario de Gobernacion

>Topic 577       MEXPAX/URGENT ACTION
>oso     reg.mexico       7:58 AM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>From: Dennis Dunleavy and Karen Sauer <oso>
>
>>From mexpaz@uibero.uia.mx  Mon Feb 13 17:46:02 1995
>
>
>Urgent Action #1
>February 13, 1995
>
>Since President Zedillo's declaration on February 9th, which broke
>down the political means of resolving the Chiapan conflict and
>launched campaigns by the Federal Army and the PGR (National
>Attorney General's Office) to apprehend the leaders of the EZLN,
>the following events have occurred:
>
>1. The detention of an undetermined number of people in Mexico
>City, Chiapas, the State of Mexico, and Veracruz who are accused of
>being Zapatistas.
>
>2. In February 13th press releases, the EZLN announced the bombing
>of the outskirts of the communities of Morelia and la Garrucha, as
>well as military maneuvers in zones under Zapatista control,
>starting on the 10th of this month.
>
>3. A raid on the CONPAZ offices, an outstanding Non Governmental
>Organization in defense of human rights in Chiapas.  The raid
>occurred at 1:30 a.m. on February 10th in San Cristobal de las
>Casas.
>
>4. The entry of federal and judicial troops into 11 villages in the
>state of Chiapas.
>
>5. JORGE SANTIAGO SANTIAGO, Director of the NGO "Economic and
>Social Development for Mexico's Indigenous Peoples" (DESMI), is
>among the individuals who have been detained.  Mr. Santiago is
>widely known for his work on development projects to benefit
>indigenous people in the state of Chiapas.
>
>6. The campaign to discredit Bishop Samuel Ruiz, accusing him of
>concealing the guerrilla forces.
>
>7. The campaign of unfounded accusations against priests and
>religious laypeople, academicians, and leaders of NGO's and social
>organizations linking them to the EZLN's Subcommander Marcos.
>
>For these reasons, we request URGENT ACTIONS:
>
>The following are proposals suggested by different political and
>social organizations;  please adopt those which your organization
>deems appropriate.
>
>
>A) Directed to Mexican authorities:
>
>Dr. Ernesto Zedillo Ponce de Le"n
>President of Mexico
>Palacio de Gobierno, Mxico, D.F.
>Fax: (52-5) 271-1764
>
>Lic. Esteban Moctezuma Barrag n
>Secretary of Internal Affairs
>Secretaria de Gobernaci"n
>Bucareli 38, Mxico, D.F.
>Fax: (52-5) 546-7388
>
>Demanding the following:
>
>1. Say no to war and a cease of warlike actions of the Federal Army
>in the conflict zone.
>2. Rejection of the accusations against the EZLN and its leaders as
>lawbreakers, and recognition of the EZLN as a political force which
>is a necessary mediator for peace.
>3. Urge the Mexican President to respect the individual guarantees
>of the population living in the conflict zone, as well as to
>respect the guarantees and human rights of the men and women who
>have been detained.
>4. A cease to the hostilities of the Mexican Federal Army and the
>Attorney General's Office against the civil population, social
>organizations and non-governmental organizations.
>5. Reestablish the dialogue between the parties through
>intermediation by the CONAI.
>6. The withdrawal of police and military forces from the conflict
>zone and full respect for the civil population's individual
>guarantees.
>7. Cease the detentions and persecutions of social and political
>activists, and exercise respect for the physical and psychological
>integrity of the detained individuals who we consider to be
>political prisoners.
>8. Respect for the individual guarantees of all Mexican members of
>non-governmental and social organizations who have insisted upon
>reinitiating political dialogue between the federal government and
>the EZLN.
>9. The immediate release of Jorge Santiago Santiago and all other
>individuals who have been detained, given that their constitutional
>and human rights have been violated.
>10. In the case of continued military offensive activity, insist
>upon full respect for humanitarian rights during a state of war,
>based upon the international accords signed by Mexico.  Support and
>strengthen the presence of the International Red Cross Committee
>and of international observers in order to avoid a generalized
>state of violence in the region and in the country.
>11. The need for serious political reforms that allow the country
>to advance in building true peace.
>12. In the context of Indigenous Peoples' Decade, demand the
>respect for the human and constitutional rights of indigenous
>peoples in the state of Chiapas and throughout the country.
>13. Declare that the neoliberal model does not work in countries
>where the majority of the population suffers from extreme levels of
>poverty, given that this model only serves to worsen the situation.
>14. The recognition of the representatives of the CCRI-CG as
>political mediators of the EZLN.
>15. Say no to Amnesty as a precondition for dialogue, unless it is
>a product of negotiation and political agreement.
>16. Recognize the authority of the Mexican Congress, and its
>capacity to generate proposals to resolve the social and political
>demands of the state of Chiapas and the country.
>17. Demand the resignation of Roberto Roble Rinc"n as Governor, in
>light of the clear crisis of governability in the state of Chiapas,
>as a necessary step to advance along the lines of dialogue and the
>construction of peace.
>18. Demand that Lic. Antonio Lozano Gracia, the Mexican Attorney
>General, be removed from office and formally charged for violating
>the Constitution and the human rights of those who have been
>detained inasmuch as neither the PGR nor the Federal Army are
>authorized to suspend the civil population's Constitutional
>guarantees.
>19. The defense, respect and strengthening of pastoral work which
>Don Samuel and the San Cristobal diocese carries out in option of
>the poor.  And, the end to persecutions and harassment of pastoral
>agents.
>
>B) Internationally
>
>1. Request the commission of a special envoy from the United
>Nations to document the numerous human rights violations which the
>Mexican Army and the Attorney General's Office have committed in
>Chiapas and throughout the country.
>
>A special envoy against torture
>United Nations Human Rights Center
>Fax: (41 22) 917-0123
>
>2. Request that the UNESCO II Indigenous Assembly for Peace,
>currently meeting in Paris, send a delegation to the state of
>Chiapas to ensure that indigenous people's human rights are being
>respected.
>Fax: (331) 45-46-93993 and 45-67-4021
>
>3. Insist that the governments of all countries declare themselves
>in favor of peace and the search for a political solution to the
>conflict, as well as respect for the demands made here in point A.
>
>4. Send delegations of international observers composed of
>outstanding members of NGO's, Human Rights centers, governmental
>bodies, etc., from each country.
>
>5. Form Committees in Solidarity with Mexico in each country, in
>order to establish a permanent relationship for communication and
>coordination.
>
>Written by ESPAZ
>
>This document was written based on declarations made by the
>following organizations: Centro de Derechos Humanos M.A. Pro
>(Miguel Agustin Pro Human Rights Center), Centro DDHH Francisco de
>Vitoria (Francisco de Vitoria Human Rights Center), CONPAZ
>(Coordinator of NGO's for Peace), ESPAZ (Civil Space for Peace),
>Red Nacional de Organismos Civiles de Derechos Humanos "Todos los
>derechos para todos" (National Network of Civil Human Rights
>Organizations "All rights for all"), Centro de DDHH Fray Bartolom
>de Las Casas (Fray Bartolom de las Casas Human Rights Center)
>
>
>Conf?
>

>Topic 578       EMERGENCY DELEGATION TO CHIAPAS FEB
>p4p     reg.mexico       9:27 AM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>EMERGENCY DELEGATION TO CHIAPAS
>FEBRUARY 19-26, 1995
>
>JOIN IFCO/PASTORS FOR PEACE:
>"TIERRA Y LIBERTAD" EMERGENCY DELEGATION TO CHIAPAS, MEXICO
>
>On February 9, 1995, Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo went on
>Mexican national television and issued warrants for the arrests
>of Subcommandante Marcos of the EZLN and four other Zapatista
>leaders.  He ordered the Mexican Army to occupy the state of
>Chiapas in an intensive manhunt for Marcos and others.
>
>For the people of Chiapas these actions were no less than a
>declaration of war, not only against the Zapatistas but against
>the civilian population as well.  Chiapas is under siege, though
>the Mexican government claims it is only a "police action" in
>pursuit of "criminals."
>
>Bishop Samuel Ruiz of San Cristobal, who has served as a mediator
>and negotiator between the Mexican government and the Zapatistas,
>has issued an urgent plea to internationals to come to Chiapas to
>bear witness to the historic struggle currently unfolding.
>
>It is imperative that the peace and justice community here in the
>U.S. support the grassroots movement in Chiapas in this critical
>moment.
>
>As a delegation member, you will meet with Bishop Samuel Ruiz and
>other leaders of the grassroots movement, attempt to visit
>indigenous communities and other areas of conflict, and bear
>witness to the actions of the military.  Your role as an
>international witness is critical to the ongoing struggle for
>justice in Chiapas.  Be part of the solution.
>
>Itinerary:
>February 19         Travel to Chiapas via Mexico City
>February 20-25      Tour of Chiapas from base in San Cristobal
>February 26         Press conference & meetings in Mexico City
>                    Return to U.S.
>
>           COST - $450.00 from Mexico City
>FFI contact Pastors for Peace 612-378-0062
>
>APPLICATION
>
>DELEGATION DATES:  FEBRUARY 19-26
>
>

>

>COUNTRY OF CITIZENSHIP

>

>

>
>
>1. Do you have any special health problems, including but not
>limited to allergies, disabilities, psychiatric disorders?
>If yes, please explain:
>
>Participants must plan to arrive in Mexico City by 1:30 pm CST on
>February 19. The flight to Chiapas departs from Mexico City at
>4 pm and arrives in Chiapas at 5:20 pm. On February 26, the
>flight leaves Chiapas at 5:50 pm and arrives in Mexico City at
>7:10 pm.  Most participants will depart from Mexico City to the
>US on February 27.  Please make travel arrangements to and from

>Topic 579       Petition for Mexico
>web:gccwat      reg.mexico      12:37 PM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>February 12, 1995,     Montreal
>
>To Whom it May Concern:
>      This last week Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo decided to
>restart the war in Chiapas.  The Federal Army's forces are entering
>Zapatista territory   with detention orders not only against the
>Zapatista leadership,  but also  against the opposition and the
>civil society.  During a meeting on Sunday  February 12, we decided
>to collect the peoples signatures as well as those of  well known
>Canadians and non-governmental organizations as part of a  strategy
>to stop the war.  We ask your organization to sign the following
>letter and to make it known to other organizations with which you
>may be in  contact with.
>        Sincerely,
>The Mexico Solidarity Network
>The Quebec Committee for Human Rights in Mexico
>The Concordia Latin America Committee
>
>P.S. Please send us your names before February 19
>     by fax to (514)343-6215 (attention Oscar Hernandez)
>     by email to oscarh@physics.mcgill.ca
>     or by post to 4293 de Lanaudiere, Montreal, QC H2J 3N8
>     If you have any questions don't hesitate to call us at
>     (514)529-0813
>
>
>To the President of Mexico Ernesto Zedillo:
>To the Ambassador of Mexico in Canada, Sandra Fuentes:
>
>We lament the use of war as a mechanism of  dissuasion and as a
>solution to  the conflict in the state of Chiapas, and we consider
>it necessary that the  Mexican government respect the international
>accords that oblige States to  search for peaceful solutions to
>disagreements.
>
>We ask for :
>     1)   an immediate cease fire
>     2)   a stop to the arbitrary detentions of the political
>          opposition
>     3)   the search for a peaceful solution that takes into
>          account the opinions of the Transitional Government in
>          Defiance of the state of Chiapas, the Zapatista Army of
>          National Liberation, and the different points of view of
>          civil society.
>
>With the hope that peace and harmony can reestablish themselves in
>Mexico,  the people and organizations signed below wish to thank
>you beforehand for  your time and attention.
>
>c.c  Primer Minister Jean Chretien,  President William Clinton
>
>Conf?

>Topic 580       ESPAZ, URGENT ACTION
>laneta:pueblo   reg.mexico       1:25 PM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>To all our friends in the various networks,
>
>On Feb 9, the official Mexican news agency Notimex, issued a wire
>saying that I, Carlos Heredia, had studied with Rafael Sebastian
>Guillen Vicente, the man presumed by the government to be
>Subcommander Marcos.  The truth is that I knew Guillen when we were
>both children, but have had no contact with him for twenty years.
>
>I would like to thank all of you who have been calling and sending
>messages of support for Equipo Pueblo and myself.  I talked with
>Attorney General Antonio Lozano yesterday morning and asked for an
>official statement from his office clearing my name from any link
>to their investigations on Chiapas.  He agreed, but I'm still
>waiting for such a statement.  I also have put a call into
>Secretary of the Interior Esteban Moctezuma, because it was the
>official Mexican government news agency which first mentioned my
>name in a 9 February wire.
>
>Equipo Pueblo is working closely with Espacio Civil por la Paz
>(ESPAZ), a coalition of 13 national NGO networks, to stop the
>harassment of NGO leaders and work for peace with justice and
>dignity in Chiapas.  We are especially emphasizing the cases of
>Bishop Samuel Ruiz and Jorge Santiago, director of DESMI, a Chiapas
>NGO that does development work in indigenous communities, who has
>been arrested and sent to a maximum security prison near Mexico
>City.
>
>In a separate letter by ESPAZ we are asking you to take concrete
>action both with your governments and in addressing the Mexican
>government.
>
>Mexico, D.F. 14 February, 1995
>
>To: The international community of NGOs and popular groups
>From: Espacio Civil por la Paz (ESPAZ)
>
>Dear Colleagues:
>
>We would like to thank you for your demonstrations of support and
>solidarity to date.
>
>We would like to ask you to take the following actions:
>
>1. Please send a fax to the Ministry of Foreign Relations of your
>respective country and your Ambassador to Mexico, asking them to
>pressure your country's embassy in Mexico City to agree to receive
>a delegation from ESPAZ sometime before February 20 if possible.
>
>2.  Send a letter to the Mexican Embassy in your country asserting
>your support for a political solution to the Chiapas conflict and
>for peace with justice and dignity.
>
>3.  Carry out public demonstrations for peace on February 20.
>
>The International Relations Commission of ESPAZ:
>
>Foro de Apoyo Mutuo (FAM), Convergencia de Organismos Civiles por
>la Democracia, Colectivo Mexicano de Apoyo a la Ninez (COMEXANI),
>Colectivo de Accion por la Juventud, Frente por el Derecho a la
>Almientacion (FDA), Red Mexicana Frente al Libre Comercio (RMALC),
>Coalicion Mexico, Movimiento Ciudadano por la Democacia (MCD),
>Academia Mexicana de Derechos Humanos (AMDH), Promocion de
>Servicios de Salud y Educacion Popular (PRODUSSEP), Grupo "Rosario
>Castellanos", Grupo ANADEGES, Despacho de Orientacion y Asesoria
>Legal (DOAL), Equipo Pueblo, Centro de Estudios Ecumenicos, Centro
>Antonio de Montesinos (CAM), Grupo de Educacion Popular de Mujeres
>(GEM), Centro Operacional de Vivienda y Poblamiento (COPEVI),
>Centro Nacional de Comunicacion Social (CENCOS), Servicio,
>Desarrollo y Paz (SEDEPAC), Servicios de Informacion Procesada
>(SIPRO).
>
>Conf?

>Topic 581       NCDM anM/Pastors for Peace: Emerg.
>moonlight       reg.mexico       1:34 PM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>  EMERGENCY INTERNATIONAL DELEGATIONS URGENTLY NEEDED
>
>Mexico is conducting a genocidal war, at the behest of
>US political and economic interests. The EZLN has
>reported bombings of two towns and the murder of
>children as well as murder and rape of women.
>Testimonies of detainees held illegally by the Mexican
>government describe the use of vicious and brutal
>torture, including beatings, electrocution, sexual
>assaults, asphyxiation, and death theats.  Throughout
>the country the government is conducting a witchhunt to
>round up any and all opposition-- over 2,700 arrest
>warrants have been issued in Chiapas alone.
>
>Along with fighting against the war here in the US
>through mass mobilizations, press coverage, human
>rights investigations, and pressuring political
>officials, the National Commission for Democracy in
>Mexico is making an urgent call for emergency
>international delegations to go to Chiapas immediately.
>As evidenced by the cry from the EZLN's CCRI-General
>Command to the world--Don't leave us alone-- as well as
>calls from Bishop Samuel Ruiz and Rebel Governor Amado
>Avendano for international observors, there is an
>urgent need for US citizens to help build pressure to
>end the bloodshed, torture and arrest campaigns.  US
>MILITARY ATTACHES ARE ALREADY IN CHIAPAS. WE, THE US
>PEOPLE DEDICATED TO THE STRUGGLE FOR GENUINE DEMOCRACY,
>JUSTICE AND FREEDOM, MUST MAKE OUR PRESENCE FELT TOO.
>
>To assist people who can go, the National Commission
>for Democracy in Mexico is working with Pastors for
>Peace, who currently have a delegation in Chiapas and
>have also called for emergency delegations.  Pastors
>for Peace have a long history of experience in
>developing delegations and caravans in support of
>international struggles for peace with dignity.
>
>Pastors for Peace can help anyone wanting to go with
>logistical questions, both in terms of preparations for
>the trip and contacts in Chiapas.  They can be reached
>by phone at 612-378-0062 or email <p4p@igc.apc.org>.
>
>WE URGE ALL COMMITTEES AND INDIVIDUALS TO SEND PEOPLE
>TO CHIAPAS IMMEDIATELY.
>
>
>
>
>
>Conf?
>

>Topic 582       INFORMATION WANTED!
>moonlight       reg.mexico       1:36 PM  Feb 14, 1995

>                   PLEASE POST ALL ACTIVITIES!

>With the mass media blackout of the Mexican/US war against the
>forces struggling for democracy in Mexico,  both in Mexico and
>the US, we must create our own means of communication. This is
>imperative not only for building the movement in the US, but also
>for ensuring our compa$eros in Mexico, that THEY ARE NOT ALONE!
>
>Therefore, PLEASE POST ALL POSSIBLE WRITTEN MATERIALS (PRESS
>RELEASES, REPORTS ON ACTIVITIES, ETC.) REGARDING YOUR ACTIVITIES
>TO FIGHT AGAINST THE WAR IN MEXICO on electronic mail.  If you
>know of groups who are participating in the movement who do not
>have access to email, please have them fax one copy of their
>materials to our office  (915-532-8382) and one copy to the
>Houston Committee's office (713-926-2786).  We will be compiling
>these materials and trying to post daily reports to the email
>system.

>Topic 583       MEXICO: AI statement on Chiapas
>hnaylor reg.mexico       1:40 PM  Feb 14, 1995
>
>From: Hilary Naylor <hnaylor>
>
>Amnesty International USA
>304 Pennsylvania Ave SE
>Washington, DC 20003
>
>14 February 1995
>
>                      STATEMENT BY AMNESTY INTERNATIONAL
>              REGARDING CURRENT DEVELOPMENTS IN CHIAPAS, MEXICO.
>
>Amnesty International is seriously concerned about current developments in
>Chiapas, Mexico, following the detention of alleged members of the Zapatista
>Army of National Liberation (EZLN) on Wednesday, February 8; and Mexican
>President Zedillo's February 9 detention order of people alleged to be leaders
>of the EZLN.
>
>The detention order was followed by Mexican army incursions into the
>municipalities of Larra<i'>nzar, Simojovel, Morelia, and other areas on
>Friday, February 10, and a restriction of access into the zones of conflict
>

From sfraves-owner  Tue Feb 21 19:11:04 1995

From: Sami Khoury <red@hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Jungle at The Jungle?
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.91.950221191034.22418A-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> > For some bizarre reason, Jungle is gaining a lot of support down here in
> > Texas, especially in Houston, so I hear more of it than I care to.  The
> 
> >From what i know about houston, and friends who live there, breaks (and 
> now jungle) have *always* been a part of the scene there.

That's true.  As raving goes, I was weened on Acen and the like :)  In 
fact, I still *love* the old school breaks from 91-93.

> > Junglists are *very* fanatical about jungle, and will fight to the death
> > with anyone who questions jungle as the *ultimate* dance form.
> 
> this is *definitely* not typical.

No no, given his locale, he is correct on this point.  I spent many 
evenings with the Houston rave crew this past summer, and for most of them 
jungle is definitely their cup of tea and not much else.

As far as the dance style goes, though, this is a pretty subjective 
thing.  You really can find this funky "half speed" groove beneath of the 
chatter, and some of the more swooshy, layered, "musical" jungle is 
definitely a head trip.

	Sami

From: Brian Darkness <brianvan@liberty.liberty.com>
Subject: DIGITARIA (GOOD BUT NOT $25)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502211725.A19326-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>

Dear Sfraves;

	I went to Digitaria Saturday night; it was a good time; I mite 
even say great; because I got to do bodywork/massage on people; and 
didn't have to pay to get in. The music was great; the people were the 
greatest; and all of the rooms were well done. But I'm sorry to say that it 
wasn't worth $25 bucks. Area 51 had much more to offer and was only 
$15.00. Area 51 had three rooms compared to Digitaria's 2. Area 51 had 
really good lasers; I don't even remember seeing any at Digitaria; the DJ 
line ups for both were comparable. Digitaria did have a live performance 
going on; but I really wasn't aware of live perfomers; maybe I was two 
stoned but; it wasn't appartently obvious or I didn't really feel their 
presents there. I can appreiate both the pro's and con's of a performers 
presents being appartently obvious; with the exception of the $25.00. 

	Another small note about Saturday night; was that i tried speed
again for the first time in 15 years.  The speed thats I used to do a long
time ago was better by far; it was a lot more unstable; meaning that it
would melt with hummidity if you weren't careful handling it. The speed
here in Cali seems to be a lot more trippy like Riddlin. I didn't like it
and would tell people to say away from it. It made me hal-lou-ci-ate
(spelled ponnectically); the images weren't very nice and if it wasn't for
some hydrocodone(Vicodin/Lortab/Lorcet) I proably would have ended up in
the hospital. 

	Hydrocodone Bitartrate is a semi-synthetic codeine narcotic analgesic 
which is currently used for relief of  moderate to moderately severe 
pain. It as most narcotics are habit forming. This drug for me makes me 
clammer and more alert; it knocks most people out; but with most drugs I 
get a paradoxical effect from them. Speed usually mellows me out and 
makes me less alert. I think this drug is wonderful; but its almost 
impossible to get it from doctors; I have found ways to get mostly 
anything I want from medical doctors; but don't ask me to tell you how. 
Like a hack my secrets are not forsale or available; you just have to go 
out there and make the same mistakes I did. Sorry but i do this to 
protect myself; because like most computer secrets once they are well 
known they are useless. I will say that; if you are a good actor; and you 
known a lot about pharmagology, and antomomy/phisology; and you present 
yourself to these people with an appropreiate converatve image that thats 
75% of it. You can get anything you want from a doctor just my giving them 
the right answers. I believe that these substances should be available 
without a prescibtion; but this will never happened because thew AMA owns 
to many congressmen and women, Good luck in your travels if you attempt to 
do this. It is illegal in some state to go to a doctors office looking 
for meds when there nothing wrong with you so be careful.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		    aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE

Dear Sfraves;

	Saturday night I went to digitaria. This night was different that most
nights for me because this time I brought my massage table a long with my
massage therapist hat(slang). I got there around 8:30pm and started
setting up the massage table in the chill room. I was finishd aroung
9:15pm and took my first client at 10pm. It was sooo nice once again to
touch and bring awareness into people's bodies, hearts and minds.  The
biggest and best surpise of all was that most of my clients were men. I'm
not gay;  but if you are a male massage therapist homophobia is a big
problem. I can only speak for myself and I guess a lot of other ethical
massage therapist's that its not about sex; its about respecting,
honnoring, trusting and worshipping the human body, mind and spirit. 
Celabrating even thought we are separtate; that we can come together for 
a brief period of time; and give each other uncontintional love; 
understanding and awareness. To touch and hold each other ina way that is 
respectful of the other person's boundries; while still providing them 
what they need; to sing, cry and learn together connected by touch. 

	The mear act of you or myself reaching out and touching another 
person; whether with clothes on or not; puts pressure on the surface of 
the skin; which also in turn brings heat to that area. The pressure also 
pushes clogged lymph and waist products out of the area and into the 
bodies drainage system, and with removal of the pressure fresh blood and 
nutrients come into to feed that particular areas cells. The heat thats 
transfered from one body to another makes our skin or connective tissue 
more liquidified; means that cells like macrofases; part of the bodies 
immune syustem can move around a lot easier. For example the human bodiy 
is like at least 70% water. So were sorta like fish tanks; only instaed 
of having glass walls we are wrapped with connective tissue. So if you 
have your hand on someones head; you are in also direct contact with their 
feet; via the coonective tissue. The fish in the tanks are the cells 
...eg macrofases, T4 cells, lymphocytes ..etc. Its really cool stuff and 
I kinda go off on it sometimes. So just my touching someone you actice or 
facillate there immune system. Think about that next time you touch someone. 

	I believe that everyone should go to massage school and learn 
about this stuff; I thing in general we would have a society that is 
healthier, happier and less needy. Touch is sooo important;we as beings 
get soo little respectful, loving touch in our lifes. So my massage work 
is very scared to me.
	
	Well bak to Digitaria; i charged the following rate scem for
events only. The first 5 minutes are free, with every minute after the
frist five is at the rate of $1.00/minute with a minum of10 minutes. I
wouldlike to formally make myself available to promoters in the future; 
or I will just show up at the event like I did on Saturday. Look for me
and my massage table a lot in the future. I'm trained and certifed in 1st
Aid by the America Red Cross and have Gestalt Therapy based counseling
skills which are avilable at no charge. So if you see me there and need
someone to talk with, or have an emergency medical issue please do not
hesitate to approach me with these issues, I welcome them and because I
have this training feel compelled to help.

From sfraves-owner  Wed Feb 22 12:18:09 1995

From: Sea Of Sin <cindy@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199502222018.MAA25709@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: not at digitaria but..
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 12:18:06 -0800 (PST)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3550      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well I didn't go to to Digitaria, because I was in Columbia/St.Louis, MO
this past weekend.:) 

I basically stayed around Columbia on Friday night because majority of 
the people were too tired to drive to St. Louis after Graham/Wally/Clint's 
radio show. Plus I was pretty tired from the plane ride. So we rented a small 
sound system and played records all night long at the Interplane (Clint, Kuri,
Robi, Wally, Graham = Tan Pants Gang :)) house. For those of you who don't 
know what Interplane is, it's basically a mail order business for 
techno/ambient music.  

I had a great time despite what happened on the 
party on Saturday. I went to FUK - The Midwest Tour of Plastikman. The 
event was held in a downtown warehouse in St. Louis (a 2 hour drive from 
Columbia). They were actually  selling smart drinks at the party (I 
haven't seen those around here in a while) and plastikman merchandise 
(I forgot to go back and get some *doh*).

When I walked on to the main dance area, it was COLD. Dancing helped a 
lot, though it was hard to dance to people who couldn't mix. I mean, these 
were BAD mixes. I couldn't believe the djs would go from house to tweaky acid 
in one mix. I know they were trying to be diverse, but it just didn't work out.
The first DJ that was on when I got there continuously had train wrecks (or as
the Innerplane crew would say it, "shoes in a dryer"). The highlight of the 
evening was Plastikman and when Richie Hawtin came back to spin later on 
in the early morning. Plastikman was AWESOME. During the middle of the 
set, the cops came in and said we couldn't dance. The promotor of the 
party had all the permits (including the portipotties), but apparently there 
was something in the contract about dancing. Anyway some people left, the 
promotor wanted to keep the party going so she asked people to sit on the 
floor. Since we couldnt dance, we could listen to music. Later on we were 
able to dance, despite being stopped again an hour later. This time the 
captain was coming down. There was also rumours floating around that some 
task force was in town and that is why so many parties lately have been 
getting busted. Plus the promoter from That Girl Productions, NEVER gets 
her parties busted. I guess there is always the first time, even though 
you have permits, etc. But I admired the promotor for trying to keep the party
going despite the harassments.


The ambient DJs and the chill room was excellent despite
it being so crowded. I really got to sense an interesting "diverse" crowd
in St. Louis. There was the rave kids, the frat boys, the people dressed
in suits that came from a near by yuppie bar, and of course the
"rednecks." (I hate putting labels on people, but it's the best way to
describe the people who were there). I still can't get over the distance
that people drove out for the rave. One group of people we (Interplane)
was from Michigan. The people I met there were really nice. However we are
lucky to have so many good parties within a 5 mile radius. 

I had a great time while I was there thanks to Wally Winfrey for being a 
great host. And I have to thank Mike Brown for coming down from Ohio. And 
thanks to everyone else (Robi, Clint, Graham, Kuri, etc.). (Sorry I got you 
guys sick:() 


--

From: Michel Battaglia <mikebee@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: Jungle at The Jungle?
To: Joe Rice <ambient@netcom.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <v01510100ab6fc815ce64@DialupEudora>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502221644.B2764-0100000@freenet3.scri.fsu.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> I've heard some jungle that's basically sped up breakbeat (time-compressed
> or doubletimed hip-hop drum loops) and some that uses some really original
> syncopated drum programming that's one step further removed from breakbeat.
> The only stuff I've liked has fallen into the latter category.
> 
> Joe

It all comes fromthe same source...the newer programmed stuff (actuall 
not all that new...artists were programming their own beats as far back 
as '91...listen to Sonz of a Loop Da Loop Era's "Far Out") is just an 
evolved version of the old-school 'breakbeat' house music...I think both 
has its merits and am very excited about the new school (more on the 
intelligent 'breaks' tip than the ragga 'jungle' tip)...

The record to check out now for a fantastic introduction into the 
so-called 'intelligent breaks' genre is Omni Trio's _The Deepest Cut_ 
(whichis being domestically released with a different title)...This album 
pretty much has nothing but recent breaks classics on it (as Omni Trio 
have been at the forefront of the genre for awhile)...eat it up!

mikebeeeee

On Tue, 21 Feb 1995, Vladimir Katz wrote:
> 
> acshully, according to XLR8R, now they've got this stuff called 
> Timestreching where they can speed up any tempo and keep the pitch at the 
> same level.  That way the voices sound normal and not all wierd.
> laters!

Timstretching has been around for *years* Back to '93 with Rufige Cru's 
'terminator' and even before then...but even still..Current breaks 
('jungle')tend to rely less on found vocal samples and more on sampling 
their own vocalist and manipluating the vocal as they please, sung at the 
same tempo as the song...

mikebee

On Wed, 22 Feb 1995, Michel Battaglia wrote:

> The record to check out now for a fantastic introduction into the 
> so-called 'intelligent breaks' genre is Omni Trio's _The Deepest Cut_ 
> (whichis being domestically released with a different title)...This album 
> pretty much has nothing but recent breaks classics on it (as Omni Trio 
> have been at the forefront of the genre for awhile)...eat it up!
> 
> mikebeeeee
> 
I just received a promo from Sm:)e Communications of an Omni Trio LP 
called "Music for the New Millennium."  Although it does have some good 
drum programming and song structures in line with what I'd call 
"intelligent" breaks, the production on the LP as a whole is still 
lacking in the eye-opening surprises I look for in music that is dubbed 
as "progressive" or "intelligent."  But it's still miles better than, 
say, Moonshine's latest jungle offering.

>>Matthew J. Corwine, mcorwine@hyperreal.com
>>Resonance Magazine, 206.344.1857
>>http://hyperreal.com/~mcorwine

WE ARE EVERYWHERE has been a slogan in the gay/lesbian community for a long
time, but it has *also* been a slogan among Deadheads for at least the last
decade.  My friend Bob who lives up in the Oakland hills is one of a group
that has been distributing WE ARE EVERYWHERE stickers at Dead shows for
years, I wouldn't doubt they've handed out a couple million of them, since
I see them everywhere like tollbooths on the Bay Bridge :)

phred

agencies of airfare that's about $550.00 to $650.00 roundtrip for 20 or 
so people. I called today to find out how much it would cost for one 
person and it was about the same. Either these's a miscommunication

Sami - "red@taz.hyperreal.com" wasn't on the mailing list but 
"red@hyperreal.com" was, so I added the former to the list of extra aliases.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 18:03:29 -0800 (PST)
From: Sami Khoury <red@taz.hyperreal.com>
To: sfraves@taz.hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Jungle at The Jungle?

> > For some bizarre reason, Jungle is gaining a lot of support down here in
> > Texas, especially in Houston, so I hear more of it than I care to.  The
> 
> >From what i know about houston, and friends who live there, breaks (and 
> now jungle) have *always* been a part of the scene there.

That's true.  As raving goes, I was weened on Acen and the like :)  In 
fact, I still *love* the old school breaks from 91-93.

> > Junglists are *very* fanatical about jungle, and will fight to the death
> > with anyone who questions jungle as the *ultimate* dance form.
> 
> this is *definitely* not typical.

No no, given his locale, he is correct on this point.  I spent many 
evenings with the Houston rave crew this past summer, and for most of them 
jungle is definitely their cup of tea and not much else.

As far as the dance style goes, though, this is a pretty subjective 
thing.  You really can find this funky "half speed" groove beneath of the 
chatter, and some of the more swooshy, layered, "musical" jungle is 
definitely a head trip.

	Sami

Check out the prices on Virgin Atlantic - you should be able to do a lot 
better than that. It's $300 round trip from New Jersey, and that was 
booking the day before I left, with no saturday stop-over. They also have a 
direct flight from SFO to LHR. 

You can get good prices on Virgin through STA travel. I've never used the 
SF branch, but the number is (415)-391-8407. Virgin has the best economy 
class of any airline around (they have seat back tvs with loads of 
different channels and movies; on some aircraft they even have nintendos. 
Oh, and they used to use ProGen as the title music for the TC channels. 

If you're lucky, and get bumped to Upper Class, they even have a 
professional masseuse to give back and neck rubs...

Simon

To: raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502221932.A26082-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

	This is a message for all those who give a damn that 
 rainforrests are being clearcut in Northern Canada to make Pacific 
Bell's CA. phone books out of the trees.

	Clayoquot Sound is 650,000 acres of rainforrest on Vancouver 
Island.  A giant timber comp. called MacMillan Bloedel turns 48% of the 
timber into paper pulp.  PacBell uses about 20% recycled fibers in their 
phonebooks, although they claim anywhere from 90-100% recycled fibers.  
This is bullshit and everyone should know it.  I volunteer for CalPIRG, a 
student public interest research group that is putting severe pressure on 
PacBell to stop buying pulp at the expense of 1700 year old trees.
	If you wish to help put the squeeze on PacBell from the comfort 
and safety of your living room, call toll free 1-800 894-Bell.  Ask them 
how much of their phone books are made of recycled fibers and demand that 
they stop using trees from MacMillian Bloedel.  

	For all those in the Santa Cruz area, we are going to storm the 
PacBell palace on March 14.  CalPIRG, Earth First, and Greenpeace members 
will be there picketing outside the PacBell building off of Pacific Ave. 
in downtown Santa Cruz.  Support is needed and encouraged.  

Feel Good.  Do something.  Thankyou.
love Jake.
Oh yeah, if you got questions call CalPIRG in Santa Cruz at 408-459-4649.

> help
> 

Never before has one word so singly summed up the frustrations of a
generation and a planet in need.  This is not a request for information. 
This is the voice of a tired and weary spirit needing a hug.  His planet is
being destroyed in the name of hambugers and phone books and fuel to keep
the generators of death going; feeding the gnarling mouths of this political
machine that has taken over our mother.  A machine that fears the freedom it
was set up to protect.  Fearing so much, as to launch witch hunts, and
propaganda campaigns, ever watchful for the next sociological scapegoat that
they can ban in the name of the guilty souls who can't blame themselves for
what they've done.

So please, won't you listen to this cry?  Please... help.

Peace/Love/Soul
solarvibe

hey everyone. 

  went to the jungle weekly thing last night.  it was cool all in all got
there aroudn mindnight.  the first dj i heard was all drum and bass and
had the sound pushed up too high so it was distorting and his selection
was rather boring but the next dj, some lady spun some phunky toonz that
was good, and ocean who was spinning at the end before i left at 2 was
rippin stuff up. 
   all in all a cool crowd rather into it.  seemed to be about 1/4 - 1/2
people who go to parties there and the rest either from other musical
backgrounds or just there to check it out.  but cool over all. 
   if you wants to check out jungle id definately suggest checking it out. 
peaz

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 08:18:20 PST
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9502231618.AA03981@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: HeadTravel
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

If you have or are planning to get a CD-ROM drive and would like
to have a memento of the 1993 - early 1994 SF rave scene, I
highly recommend picking up Headtravel.  I found it at Tower, for
the price of a regular CD.  It contains over 45 minutes of music
(which you can play in a regular CD player) and a lot of images
of SF raves and flyers.  

The visual component is quite nice.  You get a multislide show of
our scene while the music plays.  The images go by pretty fast, but
you can click on them to freeze and zoom.  This also places you in
a mode where you can move a slider that will take you through the
images one by one.  The images are slanted towards Wicked FMRs,
especially the last few at Bonnie Doon.  But other parties are
represented as well.  Lots of familar folks, though I didn't see
many SFRavers.

Another mode gives you a 10 minute movie, which is mostly computer
graphics, but then changes to moving videos of parties, people
dancing, panoramas of SF, etc.  Very nice.  Another mode basically
takes you to some advertisements and the story of Wicked.

The music is pretty good too; nice bleepy techno/ambient from local
artists, though ironically, it's not the stuff that usually gets 
played at the parties shown here.  

Lee
___________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )   lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Subject: News talks about communities like SFRaves
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 14:51:32 GMT
Message-Id: <9502230821566376@tigerteam.org>

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

Here is Newt Gingrich describing some of the most important aspects of
SFraves....

--------------------------------------------begin excerpt---------------

It really, historically, is a very romantic country. You can't be
American without having romance in your heart. I mean, if you grow up
as a cynic, it's very hard to sustain the magic that's American. But
part of the conclusion I reached, oh, maybe 22 years ago, reading
Daniel Boorstin's work on the Americans, is that as important as the
mountain man is -- and you remember "Jeremiah Johnson," which is a great
film, and again, a very useful introduction to a real authentic American
-- there were very few mountain men. There were very few people who went
out on their own in the woods. The most common American pattern was the
wagon train. Wagon trains are collective enterprises. They are us
getting together. A wonderful scene in "Witness" where they have the
barn-raising. The community comes together. America is about
individualism, but it's about an individualism which then voluntarily
creates communities, which is the thing De Tocqueville is stunned by,
that here you have this enormous freedom. Does the freedom lead to
anarchy? No. The freedom leads everybody to get together.
But they get together voluntarily and they create the community they
want, and now in the electronic age, you can live geographically next
to 60 different people, not know many of them,
and then you can reach out to the people you want to create an
electronic community with by telephone, by fax, by computer, and you
suddenly have an extended family of lots of people, some of whom you've
never even met, but you were really excited knowing each other. So it's
the individual then merging into community. And one of the
characteristics of it is that idealism in the community draws the
individuals together. It's not rampant individualism. It is
individualism lived out idealistically within a community.

-----------------------------------------end excerpt--------------------

from lecture 2 of the Renewing American Civilisation course, which is
available at Newt's World Wide Web page:

http://www.pff.org

respect to all,

Ken
ken@macshasta.com

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199502231832.KAA16531@netcom7.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Atomicon #2,   yet another one
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Atomicon,   yet another one
===========================

  Well,   this Friday was yet another Atomicon.   So we head out to 
our favorite map point to pay our $5 and get our hand stamped and 
directions to yet another insane Atomicon.    Just before I left,  
I logged into my new account at "sysx.apana.org.au" to verify that 
I have an internet provider in the land of Oz,   but right away,  
formost on my mind was getting to Atomicon.

  When I arrive there were about 80 dedicated hard acid ravers,   
and for the SF Scene,   where hardcore is literally non-existant,   
I really look forward to dancing the faster BPMs.   Oboy!!  Can't 
wait until I get to Sydney where its ALL fast.

  Anyway, I arrive during DJ Mars set,  and as usual,  he was 
tearing it up BIG TIME with the most amazing acid trance since Goa 
Gil at Megatripolus.

  Afterwards,   expecting some rip snortin Hard Core,   we get a 
more Housey sound from a DJ I haven't heard before.    He went all 
over the place,  as I tried to determine what direction his set was 
heading,   but as soon as think he is heading in a certain 
direction,  he just does something unexpected.   At first,   I left 
the dance area ad chilled,   but eventually,  his set stabilized as 
the energy level was increasing,  and more and more people were 
dancing.    I thought the transition to the slower beats was a 
pretty good idea to get in touch with those not used to the faster 
stuff.    I was expecting to hear some Gabber,   but that never 
transpired.   Sigh!!   I was dissapointed!!   I think Stone went o 
after that,   but his set disn't have the right amount of energy to 
keep me around,  so I left about 5:15 am or so,   and headed back 
to Mill Valley to smoke bong hits all morning long until the Cafe 
opened up for breakfast.

All in all,  DJ Mars set was the highlight for me,  as I was in 
Kandy land trancing BIG TIME.

Till Digitaria....  Keep on raving....

========================
       Digitaria
========================

It's now Saturday,   and the big massive scheduled this time is 
Phuture Digitaria at the Richmond Civic Center...   One of my 
favorite venues.

We get there about 11 pm,   lines were very long,   but moving 
fairly quickly.   After about a half hour wait,  we finally got in.   
Security was by Lyons Security (Pretty good folks),  and after the 
usual search through my fanny pack,   we were all let in.

It was a lot more crowded than area 51,   and when I arrived,   DJ 
Dan was about to start spinning.    His set developed quickly as he 
introduced us to some newer music a lot more trancey than DJ Dan 
normally spins.    My head was already prepared for the music,  and 
I wasted no time getting on the dance floor,  after scouting 
around.

Just before Dan went on,  Graeme was spinning Jungle,  but (sigh!) 
it only lasted about 20 minutes.    Jungle music still hasn't 
cought on here as much as anywhere else.

After dancing MOST of DJ Dan's set,   I decided to walk around,  
checking out the other attractions.   I noticed the video was OK,   
but no lazers like Area 51.    Boy!!  It was sure crowded,  Great
vibe!!   Gave me the oportunity to tell everyone about my trip to 
the land of Oz.

After a while,  I headed back to the main dance area,  to check out 
Josh Wink.    Naturally,  I danced most of Josh's set,  although he 
wasn't spinning as much Acid Trance as before,   and he naturally 
played the "Ha Ha! laughing song",  as just about everyone else 
these days.    Sheesh!!  although the song is quite a hit,  almost 
all the DJs in the area now play it.

DJ Keoki went on after Dan (I think - although my brain was pretty 
much mush by then,   as I was dancing pretty hard,  totally 
trancing out.    WOW!!  This guy was awsome.   It's really great to 
hear new talant in the mainstream,  although it's reported that 
Keoki was from New York.

At around 6 am,  Jeno went on.....  As usual,  I wasn't at all 
dissapointed,  as the energy level just got upped a few notches.   
WOW!!   Already 7 am (expected closing time),  and yet thousands of 
people are still around.    After learning that the rave was to go 
on until 8 am,   my smile facter went up even more,  as I was 
bouncing around like a crazed lunatic with a big fat smile on my 
face. 

The SFRave facter was pretty high,  and hello to all those that 
attended.    Annyway,  8 am came all too quickly,   as Jeno put on 
his last song,   I pulled out all the stops and danced like there 
was no tommorrow.

Anyway,  Phuture (Digitaria) was pretty good,  but hardly worth the 
rip off price of $25 ( $20 if you got there in line before 11 pm,
and was luckey enough to be handed a flyer.

Till next time,  Keep the scene alive....

C. Crunch

    Yeah! Digitaria was a pretty sick party. Yet, to pay 25 bucks to get in a
party that wasn't as crazy as Area 51? My reply is: "PHUCK THAT!!!" I only
payed $20 ta get in, but I still regret it. If ya saw the head count at
Digitaria, you would think they would make a phuckin' mint with $10 each.
    Tha only reason I would go to another party that costs $25, is if all my
friends went.....yet that would be a BIG maybe. People ask, "Why do people
charge so much money just for one party?" I'd say, "Because people like us
will pay THAT much." So for that next time, I urge all ya cool cats ta think:
Is it really worth it to pay $25 for a party when I could go to a smaller
party (wit' friends) and have a good  time just tha same? Plus, ya save
cash.....nice. :)

Adios....
jor.dee....

turned into nerve and collect.

Thought I should mention: Ravers in wonderland lost their space 2 weeks
ago, when they were the only all ages party in town. They built their party
line-up around their space, and lost it 2 days before the party.
Rescheduled for this friday, folks. Is it the only "big" all ager?

Now they got Ceasar's latin palace. These boys lost 2 thousand bucks just
because of the postponement. Ceasar's costs a lot. I think they will be
lucky if they break even, given the bad luck. Ceasar's is the site of the
last Kundalini and Organic.

But they are doing this party out of love, and I hope it works. It is ALL
AGES, you can reach it by bart (short walk) and there is plenty of parking
around it, and they will throw more parties in the future, usually with a
theme (like this one, alice in wonderland:). These people respect you, and
may need some of our energy to pull it off.

Just so people know, when yer party gets cancelled or postponed, some of
the DJs want to get paid, anyway. And then paid again for another date. I'm
sure they are worth it, but never believe they're in it for love, after
that. My friends found that out recently, to the tune of 2 thousandie, the
hard way, the cold hard cash way, and many people who have done other
parties learned the difference between love and profession with some of
these djs. I don't want to ruffle any feathers. Professional is
professional, these are the terms that the "big" guys set to book them. You
can love somebody, or you can sell your love. I have no problem with DJs
getting paid, maybe they all should, but when someone is hurting due to
something REALLY BEYOND THEIR control, I feel it is callous of someone to
come up and say "hey, bud, you owe me $400. too bad yer losing money."

I just feel that this is what "kills our scene". You can blame speed, kids
from san jose(yes, I've heard this sed at parties!?), 14 year olds on E,
cool world, cops, etc, but what it boils down to is that the love is often
not there. 

Long live friends and family. Thanx to Ethan, Bryce, Deaks, Tracy, Galen,
Solar, Ronan, and especially to everyone who jumps up and down and screams
and cries and hugs and grabs and loves and smiles and dances and cares and
makes me feel as happy as a new born pup. That's what this is all about. 
                          No people, no party. 
So my new fuck list:
Fuck  police sanctioned abuse of power
Fuck permits/extortion
Fuck paying for granting a DJ the PRIVELEDGE to spin before our people.
They should be begging (many are!:)


Milton and the E-Bee(who went to future nonetheless. Go figure...)

From sfraves-owner  Thu Feb 23 13:39:45 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id NAA16422; Thu, 23 Feb 1995 13:39:45 -0800
Received: from tribe.tribe.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA16406; Thu, 23 Feb 1995 13:39:39 -0800
Received: from [199.35.172.107] by tribe.tribe.com (5.64/A/UX-3.00)
	id AA11459; Thu, 23 Feb 95 14:57:21 PST
Message-Id: <v02110105ab72ab151d63@[199.35.172.107]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 13:41:13 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: matt@tribe.tribe.com (Matt Stevens)
Subject: Promoting business (was re:ravers in wonderland make-up)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

At 12:47 PM 2/23/95, medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU wrote:
>Just so people know, when yer party gets cancelled or postponed, some of
>the DJs want to get paid, anyway. And then paid again for another date. I'm
>sure they are worth it, but never believe they're in it for love, after
>that. My friends found that out recently, to the tune of 2 thousandie, the
>hard way, the cold hard cash way, and many people who have done other
>parties learned the difference between love and profession with some of
>these djs. I don't want to ruffle any feathers. Professional is
>professional, these are the terms that the "big" guys set to book them. You
>can love somebody, or you can sell your love. I have no problem with DJs
>getting paid, maybe they all should, but when someone is hurting due to
>something REALLY BEYOND THEIR control, I feel it is callous of someone to
>come up and say "hey, bud, you owe me $400. too bad yer losing money."

One thing we need to remember is that some DJ's have to live off of the
money they make spinning records.  When I say live I mean pay rent, eat,
buy records (a very big expense!), etc.  And so these DJ's must book
themselves in a way that allows them to make enough money to cover the
basic expenses involved in living.

If you book a DJ and then call them the evening of the party to tell them
it has been cancelled you have effectively ruined that DJ's chances at
making money that night.  Therefore I think it's a bit harsh to
automatically jump on a DJ for wanting to get payed even if he doesn't
play.  You as the promoter are paying the DJ not to spin elsewhere, and
even if your party doesn't happen that DJ still is not spinning anywhere
else.

Cancelling a party days or even weeks ahead of time is another situation;
and deserves to be treated differently depending on the amount of time left
before the party.

Throwing a party is a lot of work.  You must be willing to accept the
responsibility that comes with it.  When you organize a party you ask that
a great number of people give you their energy in return for something from
you.  Whether that something be money, love, happiness, or some other
object of life you must be willing to deal with everyones individual
expectations and the hassles that come when expectations aren't met.  It's
rough, and there's a lot of pitfalls and people who aren't up front about
things, but you have to realize this and prepare for the worst.

I'm not saying you shouldn't trust people to come through for you when
you're planning a party; I'm just saying you should recognize the pitfalls
and consequences involved and be prepared for them.  Each scene has it's
own, and each promoter has their own way of dealing with them.  That's what
makes a party unique (and what sets a good promoter apart from the crowd),
being able to recognize where the potential for trouble exists and
directing energy and scrutiny towards that area.

Thanks for listening, and remember to thank your promoters.
--
matt

From: bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com (Brian McGonigle)

Milton sez:

>I have no problem with DJs
>getting paid, maybe they all should, but when someone is hurting due to
>something REALLY BEYOND THEIR control, I feel it is callous of someone to
>come up and say "hey, bud, you owe me $400. too bad yer losing money."

I gotta respectfully disagree wid my buddy Milt.

For your consideration:


DJ X dj's for a livin. No other job. He's good and people pay to see him.

Dj X is asked by A to play at their party. 

DJ X sez:

"sure! $400. Is that cool?"

A:
"Ok... we'll pay u $400!"
DJ X:
"Cool.. it's a deal!"


B is also throwing a party. S/he calls DJ X.
"Wanna play at my party Sat Nite, huh, huh, huh???"
Dj X:
"oops.. sorry.. gotta play at 'A's party."
B:
"Well pay ur $400 fee"
DJ X:
"Sorry.. really.. I told 'A' I'd do theirs"
B:
"Ok.. well try DJ Y.. c'ya"


some time goes by... :) It Sat Nite.



DJ X gets ready for 'A's party. A calls up...
A:
"We lost our space, man, do we still have to pay u"
DJ X:
"sure"
A:
"Thats not fair..."


Well...Econ 101 class.. it's fair :)
DJ X lost out on $400 from 'B' because he stuck to his contract.
It's called "opportunity cost", Milton,  me oul' flower. 
Group 'A' needs to know the risks of throwing a party.. running a business etc.
Ya gotta pay for the food even if no one comes to ur restaurant...:)

hugz

brian

Simply Done is the best party 
I have been to in a long long time.
Feeling a bit omniscient - i'll just refer to it 
as the Most Fabulous Weekly on the Planet.
I am, actually, at a loss for words...

Extract of House People
100% Superstars

Mr Hardkiss played the first non-bullshit set I've heard from him.
It was really good.  I don't know who played next - maybe Mark Farina.
I have not been connected to a dj like that in ages.  This party took
off around 1 or so.  You could call it old school but that is a load of
crap, in my opinion.  A party like that is timeless.  It is all times.
A seemless connection with every peak moment in the entire history
of, well, whatever the hell you wanna call it ...  
It is really really really fun
I was Worked 


Oooooohhh Sweeties!  I Have Some Sugar for You !!
Pacific is doing the One Off of my dreams this Saturday - 
The Fat Albert gang has hooked up with my school girl sweetheart 
Nancy Drew and I WANT IT TAG TEAM  - Can you feel the subsonic feedback 
loop we have going here??  Throw Down.  Spread the LOVE.

All of the events this week look pretty good, but Atomic Pig and
the Come-Unity anniversary are the sure shots.  Some things to
note in the weeklies are the reopening of Big Heart City (Mixx),
Roger S at the Sound Factory, and the reopening of Pure Space;
plus my personal faves - the Gardening Club on Mondays
and Simply Done on Wednesdays...

Special thanks to Sun Kim for several of the listings this week...
keep 'em coming, everyone!

    ----------------------
==== THE SFRAVES CALENDAR ==================================================
    ----------------------

Thursday, February 23rd - reopening of Mixx
        836 Mission (Big Heart City).  9:30pm-4am, 21+, $4 w/invite, $8 w/o

Friday, February 24th - Out-a-Sight (by The People)
        Markie Mark  Jeno  John Howard  Galen  Spun
        and somebody from that Hardkiss Family
        415.995.9622

Friday, February 24th - Ravers in Wonderland
        Jeno  Dutch  Carlos  John Howard  Jon Williams  Thomas  Simon
        Tony Fader  Kid Irie  DJ Infinitee
        Live Performance by Darwin Chamber, Visuals by Synergy
        415.789.8522

Saturday, February 25th - Mo Funk
        Slide 5 + DJs Marques Wyatt, Miquel, Charlotte, Dani, Jackal
        76 Minna St.  415.522.3830

Saturday, February 25th - Spread Love
        John Howard  Charlotte  Galen  Solar  Kallum(UK) + a hardkiss
        278 11th St.

Sunday, February 26th - Atomic Pig
        Ethan  Galen  Phred  Dubtribe (Maybe) and Guests
        4p-midnite, east side of North Parking Lot @ Oakland Coliseium
        FREE!, Sound by SoundVision

Wednesday, March 1st - Come/Unity 4th-year anniversary
        Jeno  Simon  Garth  +  Jason  DubTribe
        1015 Folsom, 415.241.8815

Friday, March 3rd - Jazid Up 
        DJ Smash  Miquel  George  Thomas  Terrence Toy (LA)
        Record Release Party for Fat Jazzy Grooves #10
        278 11th St., 10p-5a, 415.905.8811

Saturday, March 4th - Basics
        Tony  Jon Williams  Brad  Ethan  Spun  Josh
        415.522.3994  415.905.9629

Friday, March 10th - Harmony
        DJs Tony  Simon  Doran  Trent
        visuals by Mark, ambient by Dionysus Dreams
        408.486.9591

Friday, March 17th - Catastrophic Planet "a journey of funky vibes"
        Gabe  Liquid  Jam N J  DJ Dan  Carlos  Q Bert  Graeme
        Chill Zone: Zee  Johnny K
        Lasers by Kevin, Visuals by Eyezmind, Sound by Fantasy Direct
        Glow Toys by Glowtech
        415.939.2468  209.991.4726

Friday, March 17th - Reflective Records and Clear Records present
        Black Dog, Velocette, Spacetime Continuum, Single Cell Orchestra
        + DJs Mark Broom, Jonah, Thomas
        415-241-1560

Saturday, March 18th - Equinox party - details to follow

Saturday, March 25th-26th - Tribal Future, on the Russian River
        details to follow

        and r-pos.  $3, 21+ the elbo room, 647 Valencia.

        415.560.5314   510.667.4151   408.388.3883

        1984 Old Oakland Rd.  408.428.0329
        [2/23 - John Howard, Loren]

        [2/23 - Jeno, Josh, Spun, Tracy]

        KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills

> from san jose(yes, I've heard this sed at parties!?), 14 year olds on E,

I don't understand what the rave community has against us "kids".  I'm a 
14 year old raver, and it really sucks not being able to go to most of 
the really sic raves around here.   I mean if the only reason is so that 
alchohol can be served than that is just B.S., nobody needs booze to 
rave!  i am the Kid in the above description (except I'm not from san 
Jose).  I think many more parties should be open to all ages!
Just my 2 cents worth.

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995, Vladimir Katz wrote:

> If a song izz really really good and a lot 'o' people like it, then 
> what's wrong with it getting played often??  

It will die out fast. It realy sucks to have this commercial sorta
charting going on within this music. 

"Hey man, have you heard the new Madonna? It's number one on the KMEL charts!"
"Yeah, Dj Pierre played it 18 times in one night. It's the record to have,
gotta get it."

"Can you beleive Jeno played that MC Hammer trak last night. Man that
record was played out weaks ago."
"Awww, Jeno's wack man. I heard he didn't even buy that Madonna record.
He's still playing progresive-christian-gabber, he don't even have any
power-pop-jungle-noise."

		dj Unknown

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995, medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU wrote:

> Just so people know, when yer party gets cancelled or postponed, some of
> the DJs want to get paid, anyway. And then paid again for another date. I'm
> sure they are worth it, but never believe they're in it for love, after
> that. My friends found that out recently, to the tune of 2 thousandie, the
> hard way, the cold hard cash way, and many people who have done other
> parties learned the difference between love and profession with some of
> these djs. I don't want to ruffle any feathers. Professional is
> professional, these are the terms that the "big" guys set to book them. You
> can love somebody, or you can sell your love. I have no problem with DJs
> getting paid, maybe they all should, but when someone is hurting due to
> something REALLY BEYOND THEIR control, I feel it is callous of someone to
> come up and say "hey, bud, you owe me $400. too bad yer losing money."

Very well said Milton. Unfortunatly this has been going on for along time
now. There's the Djs point of view that their scraping for money already &
they could have gotten booked somewhere else if they would've known your
party wasn't going to happen, but promoters often lose lots of money when
something goes wrong & are not able to throw more parties. I personaly
don't beleive it's possible to rely on Dj'ng to pay the rent & still be
playing for the love of it.
	josh

I agree.. If a DJ didn't charge the promoter, the promoter will probably
do the same thing again.. My experience with some rave
promoters is that they have this incredibly cavalier attitude about
people who work for a living..

pay him.. esp since he lost other engagements..

Any court would feel the same way.

Dear Sfraves;

	I was reading Milton's rave and kinda have to agree. The scene is 
about music not about performers or DJ's. The music must come first and 
should come first and of course the people all of us. If you are a 
promotter and don't have a lot of money to invest don't hire big name 
DJ's, or you risk haveing what happned to Milts friends. Whether you have 
big name DJ's or not; people will come for the music not the DJ's; at 
least thats what I come for; I never know or care for that matter or 
spinning up there; I'm there for the music, my friends; my frieneds that 
I haven't met yet; to dance and particpate in a celbration of love life 
and the pursuit of happiness which to me = LIBERTY. Even if you didn't 
have any "DJ'S" if you throw a rave; people are going to come for the 
music; what and who is a DJ anyway someone who has a lot of really cool 
records and knows how to mix them. Its about the music; I image if you 
ask most "DJ's" this they will say that the people Us aren't here to see 
them; there here for the music. Thats what I thought it was about. For 
someone to make money at spinning records; in my opionion they should 
consider that a wonderful gift that all of us give to them. I'm not 
saying that there isn't any talenet or skill in what a DJ does; there is 
because I couldn't do what they do in a very c-he-sive way. But then 
again look at Goa Gill?. ITS ABOUT THE MUSIC PEOPLE!!!!!!!! THE MUSIC!!!!!

		pEACE & lOVE fROM acROSS cYBERSPACE

Dear Sfraves;

	Being a kid is realy tough. I remmeber not being able to go 
concerts because I was to young. It really sucked then and I image it 
really sucks know. The problem for most older people is thatkids do 
things(not that older people don"t) that seem to be really crazy, cruel, 
and dumb. The difference that when older people do it  we go to jail; so 
the numbers of instances that these unfortuate things happen are 
slim; with kids the damage gets done and theres no one to hold 
responsible. Liablility is another problem if something happenes to a kid 
at a rave; most of the time the parents sue the promoters; and win; for 
something that the kid did; and ended up getting hurt in the process. 
Which usually ends up with that particualr promoter going to jail or 
spending the rest of his life paying out of his pocket for something the 
kid did. It doesn't seem very fair if your the promotter to have to be 
legally responsible for someone elses kids; but throw an all ages thing 
and something happens to Bobbie; even if its Bobbies dump high fault and 
look who gets the blame. There nothing wrong with being young and there 
nothing wrong with being old and wanting that separttion. Another concern 
is of course that womyn/girl you end up talking with that tells you she's 
18+ and you take her home only to find the cops knocking on your front 
door at 7AM and thats when you find out she's only 17 and guess what 
buddie your going to jail. Doesn't seem very fair does it(scarcassitically)
So these are just some of the reasons why there is a saprtation between 
the peopel under 18 and over 18. Beleieve me you will understand. ina few 
years.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace(Yes I do Mean IT)
		    aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE

		Internet:	brianv@liberty.com
		Alt. Internet:	brianvan@liberty.com

> about music not about performers or DJ's. The music must come first and 
> should come first and of course the people all of us. If you are a 

The DJ's invest their money to purchase the records to play at the raves 
which you run to in order to meet those precious friends of yours whom 
you don't know.

> big name DJ's or not; people will come for the music not the DJ's; at 

Now who in the hell goes to a rave *solely* because of a particular DJ's 
presence, except for the most stylin' of club kids?  The fundamental 
mistake you've made is that you're *separating* the DJ and the music.  I 
went to Digitaria because (among other things) I knew Josh Wink would be 
there and I know that he plays good stuff.  The 'people' you are speaking 
for, if they have half a brain among them, will come for the music and 
the DJ--promoters try to get big name DJ's precisely because they bank on 
this concept.

> I never know or care for that matter or spinning up there

Then you deserve the next shitty party you attend.

> Even if you didn't have any "DJ'S" if you throw a rave; people are 
> going to come for the music;

Who is playing the music, smart guy?

> what and who is a DJ anyway someone who has a lot of really cool 
> records and knows how to mix them.

It took me three days of practice before I could pull off a decent beat 
match.  A DJ is precisely what you said.  A lot of really cool records = 
a lot of money invested.  Knows how to mix them = practice.  Geez, think.

> in my opionion they should consider that a wonderful gift that all of 
> us give to them.

Oh my god, you are so completely full of shit.

I understand the need and desire for community, and the elimination of 
barriers, and the want to come together, but I refuse to expect anyone to 
put on a party for free, or render their services for free, so that I can 
forget about the effort involved in putting it on.  When I go to free 
ones, you can bet I donate when asked, because when I leave and go home 
to sleep, someone else has to stick around and clean up.

	Sami

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Dear Sami;

	The reason were all part of this; I feel anyway is the music; not
the DJ's. No one told them to invest their money in House, Techno and
Trance records; they did it for the love of the musical genre. When this
genre of music first appeared there were no Josh Wink's and Pierre ...etc
just the music, the machinces making it, and the people creating it. I
will still stand by my statement saying that I go for the music, and have
never been to a "shitty party". The music and the people at the party
make the party not the DJ's; they are just the individuals who play the
music for the people. In the end the people decide whats played not the
DJ's; if a DJ were to start spinning trash; then the people at the party
would either tell him through body language ie not dancing, or verbally eg
the DJ sucks, play something else. Anyhow the music has always been
there to do what it does for me, no matter were I'm at, who I'm with, or 
for that matter who's spinning it. I think people put to much emphazies on
who's spinning rather than on who's created the music, how many people can
you walk up to on the scene and ask; who's that, that so and so spinning;
and get an accurate response, Rather; everyone seems to know who's
spinning though. Go fiqure; shouldn't the credit at least go to the people
who created this fantastic music, rather than who's cueing it up. 
If you remember the Cd Frequencies by LFO; they start out my saying: 

"House"
"What is House"
"Technotronic, KLF, or something you live in"
"To me House is Phuture Pierre Fingers Adonis etc"
"The Pioneers of the Hypnotic Groove, Brian Eno, Tangerine Dream, 
Kraftwerk, Depeche Mode, & The Yello Magic Orchestra"
"This sound is deadicated to you"
"House"

I don't here them mentioning any names of DJ's; though I'm sure they are 
indebited to a few. For if it wasn't for the DJ's spinning this new 
music in clubs; chances are that it would never have reached the point it 
has, but the DJ's still had to love the music in order for them to spin it.
It makes me annoyed that hardly anyones knows who created this music and 
I feel unless we honnor the creators; not the DJ's who spin it; this genre 
will go by and by. Because unless there is new input into the genre the 
DJ's will have nothing new to spin. 

	Sami I'm not saying anyone should put on a party for free; I think
you took a lot of what I said out of context. The point or my 2 cents
worth of the whole thing was the DJ vs The Music thing. I'm not 
separtating them; I just giving my version of what I feel is an important 
reality check here. Emphazises not separtation.

	If you going to quote me; please include the whole paragraph or
sentence where appicatable; not just the stuff so you can make your point.
I see you didn't mention the stuff about Goa Gill who doesn't beat match;
who just plays records.  Parties cost money there no doubt in anyones mind
there; if Miltons friends had to pay the DJ's even though the venue was
cancelled I would have had an impromptto house party somewhere at the last
minute and at least gotten my moneys worth eg gotten the DJ's who
requested to be paided to spin there. I don't like it when I hear about
anyone working hard to put something together for the benefit of all and
at the last minute due to things behond anyones control it going flatt. It
was unfortuate and my heart goes out to those guys. The world needs more
compassion Sami and I practice what I preech. 

	I see and am sorry we disagree; but to say that "I'm completely
full of shit" is wrong, for I speak from my heart, mind and soul, and am
not stating facts to be measured in true false. But stateing how something
makes me feel. You are not me; and not in my psyche; so to make that
statement I feel is inappropreiate behaviour for someone on the staff at
hyperreal. I have taken offense to your statement that I mentioned earier.
I don't mind critizium and in fact welcome it; its part of how we grow as
beings; but I draw the line at profanity and character assiation. I'm
sorry that you choose such strong words to make your point; I think it
could have been done in a much less offensive way. Anyhow people who know
and love me know that I do mean well; and have a heart of gold; so I bid
you well and hope than when we eventually meet; that we both will be able
to do it with a smile and a hug. Goodnight Sami & pleasent raver
dreams....:) 

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		    aka Brian Darkness, LMT/BSEE

I must disagree with Brian Darkness minimizing the role of the DJ. They 
are crucial to a party. Yes they play other peoples music but mixing is 
an ARTFORM. Try beatmatching on a huge system and really creating a deep 
groove, its not as easy as you might think. Records also cost alot of 
money and DJing for a living is hard work. A party is a collective event 
and everybody's energy is important. I am not one to make DJ's into rock 
stars but they are definitely integral to a good party and thriving scene.

ronan

From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 24 02:35:20 1995
