From: "JMRTNKO! please stand by..." <martinko@netcom.com>
Subject: DJ fees
To: ezzevvravess <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502240126.A26574-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, life may not be about economics, but when money starts changing 
hands, it becomes business. 

The DJ vs. musician argument can go on forever, but if you compare it to 
the movie industry, I don't think most actors write their own lines 
either. Yet on the average, actors make quite a bit more than 
screenwriters. The DJs are the performers, and if it really didn't matter 
who was at the turntables, I guess noone (promoters and attendees) would 
mind if their names were just left off of the flyers and info lines. 
Obviously it does matter. Like an actor, a DJ is hired half for their 
performance and half for their reputation. A big DJ can give an otherwise 
unknown party a dose of credibility. And with 'no info til the day of the 
event' and a field of homogenous flyers a DJ is often the only way to 
distinguish one party from another. Whether they spin or not, they 
deserve something for that.

How much they deserve would be a large thread in itself. I don't know the 
conventions for performing artists, but I do know that a 'kill fee' is 
pretty standard in the graphic arts. If a client terminates a project in 
progress, they are usually responsible for paying for any work already 
completed (with a minimum of half the original fee). Sounds fair to me, 
though like I said conventions for performers may differ.

jmar.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 24 03:52:41 1995

To: martinko@netcom.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re:  DJ fees
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey, why is this even an issue?   If the party gets busted, almost always
the promoter has already collected 80% or more of what they're going to
collect otherwise.  With rare exceptions, the money is never refunded.
I say this as an unhappy customer of the "last" Chemistry, whose organizers
took my $20 for a party I never even got inside.  The DJs make the deal,
buy the records, practice, show up on time, give up the opportunity to
play other events, and someone expects them NOT to get paid?  Get REAL!
If there isn't an explicit agreement on a "kill fee" because of a bust
or whatever, the DJ should be paid 100% of the agreed amount period,
no questions asked.  This is and should be SOP.  DRC told me about
being booked in both Portland and Atlanta last year, and though she
didn't get to play in either place for different reasons, she got her
fee plus the agreed expenses.  That is how it should be.

phred

From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9502241704.AA19408@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: DJ's vs Music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Brian Darkness insists:
> I'll even for the sake of clarity just say that there is not enough
> emphais on the creators of this music in the scence; leaving the DJ's out
> of it totally. But I will still stand by my friendly point. I don't know
> that many people aside from the DJ's who at a rave can hear a song and say
> oh thats LFO, Moby, 808 State ..etc, this includes myself. I feel that we
> are not honnoring the people who create this music; thats all.

I have a little problem with this "honor-the-creator" concept.  At a
rave, we experience music that is mixed and presented in a context that
completely transcends any one  "creator".  How about all the samples 
that come from other "creators"?  How about the technology that makes 
the music possible?  The recording engineers?  The party's sound system 
and the people that tweaked it for us?   

How do we "honor" all these creators?  It's simple.  We dance our asses
off and share our joy and give some money so that *everyone* who helped
make the *whole* thing possible will do it again.  

ps. Brian, the "sacred" art of massage that you so eloquently described
enables you to get into parties for free, after which you charge $1 a
minute (1st 5 free).  But DJs should spin for free?  Hmm.  Likewise, you
readily admit that even *you* don't know who the "creators" of the music
are.  Y'know, I bet that many professional DJs are as idealistic as you
are about the music.  But as we know, one of the most difficult things
in life is trying to live up to our own ideals.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com   (   ( ((truth-love-energy))  )   )   lee@hyperreal.com

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 09:10:09 PST
From: bmcgonig@pacific.abbotthpd.com (Brian McGonigle)

To: brianvan@liberty.liberty.com
Subject: Re: DJ's vs Music
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


otay... my last word.. :)

pick ur favorite 20-30 cuts from this/last year.
play them one by one..turn the records..pop in the cds etc.
note the gaps of silence btw songs!

what happens? 
Well at least for me.. pretty good music..but the intros to these songs
weren't that good.. and some sorta wimp out at the end.. and that silence
btw songs.. that really sux...no groove.. no crescendo..no "Ill take u there"

now let a good DJ take those same cuts... (I know all this is hypothetical)
and it's different... 
s/he mixes out the crummy intros...
s/he builds a vibe (no silence)...
s/he "takes u there" 

Now.. thats given that u can even get those favorite cuts. 
Any fool can buy 808 State at Tower...
but try buying some Atom/Astral Matrix/Trilogy/Robotman anywhere!!!
If ur "all digital" like Brian Darkness.. u cant even get tham at all..period.

imho, the music is the egg/sugar/butter...
but the DJ's make the cake. And some cake can taste good.. and some cake
can taste bad!

hugz

b

90% in agreement with you crunch.  We arrived at 12:45 or so, 
unfortunately missing the jungle set in the beginning and arriving well into 
acid set.  Nice change of pace from the housey vibes at Kommotion that 
nite.  Anyway, hard acid was just what I needed and Atomicon dished it 
out.  Unfortunately, they closed up at 5:00 or so, a little too soon for 
me.  What Atomicon needs is is Atomicon #3: more people, more visuals.

hard acid.  Unreal--

'til next time,

>From anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl Fri Feb 24 10:34:26 1995
Return-Path: <anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl>
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 10:45:47 +0000
From: The Anarchives <tao@asynca030.nist.gov>
Subject: Torture & Repression in Chiapas
To: jterpstra@trentu.ca

/* Written  4:09 PM  Feb 18, 1995 by moonlight in igc:reg.mexico */
/* ---------- "Torture Testimony (Eng.Jorn.2/16)" ---------- */
La Jornada, Thursday,
Feb. 16 pg.1, 39
*We are not Zapatistas*
*Testimonies of the Tojolabales: We were tortured by the
Mexican Army
 
Oscar Camacho Guzman, correspondent, Comitan, Chiapas, Feb.
15
 
Mario Alvarez is 40 years old and Alfredo Santis Jimenez is
33.  Both are Tojolabales indians and they are denouncing
the same act: "We were tortured by the Mexican Army."
 
"When the Mexican Army came into Chiapas," they explain,
"they detained us and then they kidnapped us.  From Friday
until Monday. In Tuxtla they put bags on our heads, they
beat us, they shocked us, they asphyxiated us.  Here are the
marks, all over our bodies.  They beat us until they made us
sign some sheets with knowing what they said, and then they
let us go, saying that if we talked they would return and
kill us.
 
Alfredo Santis and Mario Alvarez gave their testimonies on
Tuesday night, in the office of the Independent Center of
Farmworkers and Peasants (CIOAC), here in Comitan, where
they say they returned after being gone for four days.
 
Luis Hernandez Cruz, leader of CIOAC in Comitan, gave them
housing, denounced the acts to the mass media, demanded
justice and criticized harshly the president, because "a
military solution in Chiapas was not correct, as it is
causing persecutions and violations of human rights."
 
Alfredo Santis Jimenez speaks Spanish; Mario Alvarez
doesn't, and he gave his testimony with the help of an
interpreter.  Both agree; they both give an account of the
same events. Both of them "dared" to speak because even more
than the fear they have, they "do not want this injustice to
happen to others."
 
Mario as well as Alfredo Santis stated that they were
detained on Friday at the Chiapas collective farm, when they
were returning from work on the Nuevo Momon collective farm
to their respective communities. They also stated that in
Tuxtla they could see another "four or five" detainees and
that they also heard that among the detainees was "an
elderly man" whom they were saying had killed Coronel Hugo
Manterola in Nueva Mormon on the day that the Mexican Army
entered the conflict zone.
 
Continuing the testimony, taperecorded and filmed, of
Alfredo Santiz:
 
"We were working, over there on a small piece of land, and
when we got to the Chiapas collective farm, the armies (that
is what the indigenous call the soldiers of the Mexican
Army) were already there, and there they stopped us and
arrested us."
 
"They took us in an Army car to Comitan, spread eagle,
without our knowing where we were going.  They put a
military cap on us, a military vest, and they took us
covered with mud, inside the car.  From there we went to the
headquarters, and they made us spreadeagle again. They took
off our clothes, pants, shirts, everything. They put us
spreadeagle, and they put him spreadeagle on top of me, like
a cross."
 
"Then, They put us back in the same car that they had taken
us out of, and they took us to the military airport.  There
a doctor came and checked us to see if we had any illness. 
After the doctor checked us, a soldier came and took notes,
without our knowing what he was writing.  When he had
finished writing, he made us put our fingerprint on it.  It
was five or six pages.  
 
>From there, once we signed the papers, they put us in a
helicopter, to go to Tuxtla.  They took us on our knees,
with the soldiers, and once we got to the airport, they gave
made us spreadeagle. They called someone at the military
headquarters so that an army car would come and take us to
the headquarters.  Within a half an hour it came and they
took us again spreadeagle.
 
Then getting to the headquarters they put us spreadeagle and
they told us that I should prepare myself and that my
companero would go with them.  He was the first one to be
tortured.  I heard him yelling and then one of the torturers
came out to talk with me.
 
     "Now you have to tell me some things and if you do not
tell me the truth, you will have to stay here.  You are
going to tell how many Zapatista soldiers there are in the
collective farm, who are the Zapatista leaders, how many
arms they have".
 
What is one to say, that I am a member of CIOAC.
     
     "And what is this CIOAC" he asked.
 
"It is an orgnaization that works on projects for the
community" I told him.
 
     "No, no it isn't.  You have tell everything you have
seen regarding the EZLN, you have seen those of the EZLN."
 
I don't know anything, I told him.
 
     "Well, if you don't want to say, if you do not want to
talk, wait a minute.  Soon I am going to come back for you,
there you will tell me."
 
If you want me to do something, well kill me, but I am going
to tell you that I don't know anything, I told him.  About
10 or 15 minutes later, they came to get me. When I went in
where my compa was, he was hanging from his hands, with a
hood over his face, badly beaten, and they had taken off his
clothes, his pants, he was completely naked."
 
     "Now you see how things are", he told me, "if you do
not tell how many Zapatistas there are in your collective
farm, that's what we are going to do to you."
 
Sirs, what am I going to tell you; I don't know anything.
 
     "Well if you're not going to talk, lie down face up",
he told me.
 
Then he brought a chair that had an iron bar underneath, and
he put me face up, and he put the chair's iron bar over my
throat. Then one of them, the fattest one, came and sat on
the chair. I couldn't breathe.
 
     "You are going to answer my questions", he told me.
 
But what am I going to say, I told him.  He sat down again.
What am I going to say if I don't know anything. We aren't
Zapatistas.  Then when I was recuperating a little, he sat
down again. Then he brought a nylon bag, and he put it over
my head, tied it tight, and cut off my air.  I fell.  I kept
opening my mouth because I wanted to breath and couldn't get
any air. Then he covered my mouth with his hand, and then I
fell, and he picked me up again.  Then I saw him go for some
buckets of water, and then he threw them on me, all over,
and he went to connect an electric cable. He said:
     "Now yes, you are going to answer my questions".
 
Then he put his leg in my stomach, and on my head, but it
was when he put the electric cables on my private parts, on
my head, that I lost my mind.  With such torture that he did
to me, I tell you, then yes, yes the Zapatistas came to us,
because of the torture.  I told him that I am Zapatista,
even though the truth is I'm not a Zapatista.  But I told
him there were some who came to visit with us, with such
pain.
 
And he asked me what kind of firepower they had, did they
have 60 high power weapons.
 
I don't know, I told him.
 
"Why the f--- not"
 
And he put the cables on again, and he brought a knife. He
scraped our bodies, and he brought some pliers, and he
squeezed our tongues. He squeezed my tongue with the pliers. 
He told me he was going to pull out my molars. And that's
when I told him again, yes we have arms, a few small high
powered arms, but for war."
 
"No, how the f... are they not for war, if this weapon that
they have is for killing somenone. How the f...not?
 
And again he tortured me and asked "Where are the caves
where they hide the weapons?  How big is it?, Is it big or
small?
 
And I didn't tell him, and he put the cables on me again,
everywhere he wanted to, and then I told him that there was
a small cave where we hid the weapons, but it was because of
the torture and it wasn't the truth. And a federal Public
Minister told me he was writing it all down.  And from there
he told me:
"And the cathechists, how many cathechists are there. 
You're not going to say that there aren't cathechists.  What
do they say in the churches? What do they say during their
sermons?
 
"The cathechists carry out the word of God..."
 
"How the f... are you going to deny that the cathechists are
the ones giving the bad ideas to those who join the
Zapatistas and who say the government is bad, is rich.  Tell
me it isn't so."
 
And then he tortured me again.  He stuck his knife like
this, here, here and here (in the chest and back).  Then I
told him yes, that the cathechists sometimes look for the
parts that say that the rich are the enemies of everyone,
that they are rich and that whoever gets authority, as the
government, they always want all of the power.
 
"Then I have some names of cathechists and if you don't tell
me if you know any of them, I am going to kill you here with
a pistol."
 
"He put a large pistol like that (he said pointing to his
temple) and he had three names of cathechists.
 
"This Gregoria is from there?"
 
I don't know him.
 
"How the f... don't you know him?  This Guillermo is he from
there?
 
Yes
 
And this Roberto?
 
Him too, and like that I continued talking, because of so
much torture.  Well then he took notes again, and now I've
said everything that he asked me. He put me face down again,
and I thought it was because he was going to let me go. Then
he put the electric cables on me again. He put them here
(with one hand pointing to his buttocks and the other to the
high part of his back).
 
And that's when I began getting bent back, doubled
backwards, because of the electrical shock.  Then he put me
face up again, and he put coke in my eye. He filled it with
coke, and I couldn't see. Then I cleaned it out.
 
"Wipe your eyes" he told me.
 
I was face up, like this, and he had the knife like this,
and he stopped.  He had it high above me, and then he let it
go towards my eye, but it didn't hit me.  It came that
close, that close (right next to his head).  And he did that
five or six times; he'd hold it up high and then let it go,
but it never hit my eye. And that's how we were tortured. 
Then from there since I had said so much under torture, they
took us out, and they had written down everything I had
said."
 
"You have to repeat everything again." he told me.
 
"And I said it all again, and sometimes I forgot something,
because when you lose your mind, you can't remember what you
said. Then I would begin my statement again, but I missed
some of it."
 
"You are going to tell or I will put these on again."
 
"Then I struggled, struggled to remember, and I asked him to
help me a little because I just couldn't do it.  I was
really bad off, and so it was partly his statement and
partly mine.  Then after everything was stated, three others
came.  There are three of them who do the torturing.
 
"Now we are going to let you go free.  We are going to let
you go.  You have made your statement.  You helped us a
little.  But if you go and tell anyone that we have tortured
you or beaten you, if tomorrow we find out that you are
talking with anyone about being tortured, we are going to
bring you back here.  What you are going to do, if anyone
asks if you were beaten, or if anyone hit you, you are going
to say no.  You aren't going to tell anyone."
 
No, no I'm not going to tell, I said.
 
"Are you thirsty?" he asked me.
 
"Yes, yes I'm thirsty", I told him; I was really f...
 
Do you want a soda?, he asked me.
 
" Yes, and then he gave me a soda, a coke, but I couldn't
drink because of the pain here (pointing to his throat). And
about an hour later he came back again.
 
"Why are you sad? Why do you look like that? What's wrong?"
he asked me.  " Why the long face?"
 
"It's because I am in alot of angina and fire in my mouth."
 
"Why" he said
 
"I don't know. Maybe because I don't have a jacket nor
anywhere to lay down, just my poor body like this," I told
him.
 
"No one hit you? Are you being treated well? Have you
eaten?" he asked.
 
"Yes"
 
"That's what you have to say; if not, they going to get you
again."
 
"In the morning he came again early, " How are you?  How's
your angina?"
 
"It's bad. I couldn't eat. I hurt alot, because it's very
cold.  Just like that he came back every hour or two. Not
always the same guy.  Sometimes the one who tortured me;
sometimes a soldier came to ask how I was, if I was well, if
I was being treated well.  And that's how I was handling it.
It didn't matter that I was hurting here and here, and above
all my tongue, so much that I couldn't talk.  That's how we
spent Saturday and Sunday. After awhile a soldier came and
told us:
 
"Just wait awhile.  Now they've given us the order to kill
you. Just wait a little while, and we're going to kill you."
 
"Ay! We got sad again, and sometimes we cried.  What were
our children going to do?  But the day went by, and then
Sunday night the federal Public Minister came and said that
they were going to bring medicines. But it wasn't until
early Monday morning that they brought us the medicines, but
it didn't ease the pain.
 
And then the Public Minister read to us what we had said. 
And he said that they weren't going to torture us anymore.
And a little later they let us go.  They give us 30 pesos
for the bus, and they told us not to tell anyone, because if
we did, they would bring us back..."
 
(translated by Cindy Arnold, volunteer National Commission
for Democracy in Mexico)




Radio Germany: Mexican Police Use Torture - 2/21/95
17800khz 6:00 AM EST
Transcript follows:
 
     In Mexico, it is reported that police used torture on four
of seven people arrested two weeks ago on suspicion of being
linked to the indian rebels in Chiapas.
 
     The Mexican Human Rights Commission says that all seven
were forced to sign confessions.
 
     It was reporting on 24 complaints received since President
Ernesto Zedillo ordered an offensive against the rebels in
Chiapas state on the 9th of this month.
 
     The Commission alleges that the five men and two women
arrested in Varacruz were not even allowed to read what they are
claimed to have confessed.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 24 11:08:37 1995
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) id LAA18776; Fri, 24 Feb 1995 11:08:37 -0800
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.10/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA18767; Fri, 24 Feb 1995 11:08:33 -0800

First of all i need to say that i agree with *everything* that Sami said. 
My points are below.

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> 	The reason were all part of this; I feel anyway is the music; not
> the DJ's. No one told them to invest their money in House, Techno and
> Trance records; they did it for the love of the musical genre. When this

but *where would raves be without them*? It took dj's like Paul Oakenfold 
and Danny Rampling to *bring the music to the people*..You would have NO 
RAVE and NO MUSIC. If English DJ's hadn't brought Chicago acid house from 
Ibiza back to the UK and start playing it...There would be NO RAVES and 
you'd STILL be dancing to sub-disco crap as if it were still 1985.

> genre of music first appeared there were no Josh Wink's and Pierre ...etc
> just the music, the machinces making it, and the people creating it. I

But you would NOT HAVE HEARD *ANY OF IT* if the DJ's didn't PLAY IT. You 
*WOULDN'T* have. it's simple. This music started in clubs and parties, 
played by DJ'S. the rave scene has always revolved around DJ culture! I 
LOVE it! I *am* a dj! It's about loving the music and wanting to share it 
with others! but when you're spinning - you come to a point where you 
either have to 1)start getting paid or 2) stop dj'ing, unless you're rich.i
can't afford to be buying records to keep up. maybe *you* can...

> will still stand by my statement saying that I go for the music, and have
> never been to a "shitty party". The music and the people at the party
> make the party not the DJ's; they are just the individuals who play the
> music for the people. In the end the people decide whats played not the
> DJ's; if a DJ were to start spinning trash; then the people at the party
> would either tell him through body language ie not dancing, or verbally eg
> the DJ sucks, play something else. Anyhow the music has always been
> there to do what it does for me, no matter were I'm at, who I'm with, or 
> for that matter who's spinning it. I think people put to much emphazies on
> who's spinning rather than on who's created the music, how many people can
> you walk up to on the scene and ask; who's that, that so and so spinning;
> and get an accurate response, Rather; everyone seems to know who's
> spinning though. Go fiqure; shouldn't the credit at least go to the people

Man what can i say but that you really have no clue, and no respect for 
the people who take time and money to bring you good music. I agree that 
the music is the thing - but you don't get it. The DJ"s role is 
*invaluable*. It is *your* responsibility to know the music. i go to 
parties and see kids who have no clue what the music is...and it's up to 
YOU to seek out who does the music. I do it, other kids do it, other dj's 
do it, but most ravers do NOT do it, including you it seems, and that's 
the sad part. It's what i hate about raves today - the kids don't know 
the music anymore, and that's cause the make NO EFFORT TO. The DJ gives 
you all this incredible music and no, credit won't be given until you 
FIND OUT WHO DOES IT. How the hell do you think that records sell so much 
when the only play they're getting is by DJ'S (ahem) in clubs? people 
actually take the time to FIND OUT WHAT THE RECORD IS, thus making money 
for the people who made it (as well as recognition). YOU HAVE NO CLUE.

see peple getting off on their track!

My agents report Brian Darkness said:
> 	Point well taken; please read my response to Sami in DJ's vs 
> Music should give you some insite into what I meant.

see? you are completely missing the point. its not "djs VS music", the djs
are an integral part of the music!! who's gonna play it, if not djs, huh?
you? well then i guess you are a dj.

listen, if you've never done it, you dont know the incredible amount of work
and investment of $$ it takes to put together a set. you can't just walk into
a store and drop a wad of cash and expect to walk out with a wicked crate, it
takes literally YEARS of going to the stores, maybe twice a week or more and
listening to TONS of crap. then there is the hours and hours of practice, and
its sure not just learning to beatmatch, sequencing is far more important as
Goa Gil showed you. you think he hasn't spent alot of time thinking about how
the tracks will go together, trying to take you on a journey? and let not
forget the fact that at an average price of $10 a single (and you only play
one track off each single, price may vary depending on your blend of domestic
and imports:) for a 2 hour set assuming each tune is about 4 minutes long,

60 minutes * 2 = 120 minutes / 4 min/song = 30 songs * $10 = $300

starting to get the picture? thats $150 an hour, what most djs that have
"broken in" to some degree get paid. THEY ARE GETTING PAID AT-COST FOR THEIR
RECORDS. so quit bitchin when you don't even know what you are talking about

this trying to make some deep philosophical discussion over a very obvious
concept is quite annoying. think before you post.

namaste (and greetings from the nw)
skye

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Dj's vs. music
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Just to support what Lee had to say about "dj's as creators" - 

I don't think that DJ's are seen as a non - creative entity.  Exactly the
opposite - they have a tough job - there aren't too many artforms where the
"performer" is constantly listening intently to the audience for direction.
Most performers - take rock or whatever - use a set list.  This would be the
equivalent of playing mixed tapes at clubs.  Not quite the sam,huh?  The DJ
can dial in the exact mood of the evening.

As far as identity and music and the creator, I don't think that the
concrete identification of every record being spun is important.  What I
love about this scene is that there is an utmost focus upon the SONIC
component of the experience - there is no stage to stare at, no performer to
identify the music with.  They have all my respect through my ears and that
is all that matters.  If I hear something that is mindblowing you better
believe I am going to burn rubber over to the DJ to find out what it is.

In many parts of the world the idea of a singular "composer" is nonexistent
- there is simply a heritage of material to work from - one borrowing from
the other - the people of such a society can identify individual songs, and
certainly like some better than others, but the individual creator does not
neccessarily exist.  When the focus remains upon the music itself, and not
the personality, the biological growth of a genre will keep expanding.
Forever.

get off my horse

(as in, ok, I will get off my horse now.)

Paul

Darkness considers his words,

> If you going to quote me
> If you going to quote me
> If you going to quote me
> If you going to quote me

The DJ works the crowd.  I have to believe that the creators
of the music have this in mind when they make it.

My friend realized the other week that "being a dj" for many
guys nowadays is the same as "being in a band" used to be.  
This was a revelation to her.  I thought it was obvious.
All those Heavy Metal bass players are spinning techno ...

I rarely recognize a dj or know who played unless someone
tells me.  This doesn't mean I don't have favorite djs.

I post, regardless of my mood.  If someone misunderstands
what you write - then you failed to communicate your ideas.
And on that note, I always "Get It", however, I also 
understand the concept of colloquialisms.

I like swearing although I've been told "it's beneath me".
Calling bullshit bullshit seems fairly straightforward and
easy to understand ... no confusion there.

Money in the Bank
I always encourage my friends to get Paid

I've also seen alot of misplaced innocence and trust when
people first get involved in a business deal.  It's a game
played by sharks - that game can be really fun if ya want to
play along but don't think you can bring your whole earth fantasy
world to the table and expect it returned in kind.  I personally
would stomp on ya the first chance I get.  If you can't deal 
with that you don't belong there in the first place.

To elaborate, I also think it is a matter of maturity to be
able to separate something like a business deal from your personal
feelings.  Call it a mutual understanding.  Getting stomped on
is one of the best ways to learn a few good moves.

I hope my manicurist isn't on speed,
Dave

BEGIN QUOTE FROM Lee Fogel:
: 
: 
: I have a little problem with this "honor-the-creator" concept.  At a
: rave, we experience music that is mixed and presented in a context that
: completely transcends any one  "creator".  How about all the samples 
: that come from other "creators"?  How about the technology that makes 
: the music possible?  The recording engineers?  The party's sound system 
: and the people that tweaked it for us?   
: 
: How do we "honor" all these creators?  It's simple.  We dance our asses
: off and share our joy and give some money so that *everyone* who helped
: make the *whole* thing possible will do it again.  
: 


This is a lot of the same concepts that are behind Underground Resistance.
Mad Mike has had few (if any) pictures taken without some kind of mask
or face covering.  They often perform in hoods and gas masks.  Their point?
        WHO THEY ARE DOESN"T FUCKING MATTER!  IT'S THE MUSIC!!


--

    I really confused 'bout all this Jungle shit. I mean, I keep hearing
people say they would like to hear more Jungle at parties. Yeah....I guess
that's cool 'n' all....to each his own. BUT, is it really possible to dance
to this stuff for more than ten minutes without passin' out? Don't get me
wrong, I DO like Jungle, as much as I like hardcore. Yet, I could only listen
to it, feel it, and maybe stomp my foot to it, but not dance to it. I've seen
people dance to it, but most people quit dancing, sit down, and wait for
something slower.
    Now my questions are: Is it possible for anybody to dance to Jungle all
night long? Would YOU guys prefer to dance to acid, trance, blah, blah, blah,
or would you prefer to dance to hardcore/jungle, blah, blah, blah?............
after all, it could depend on what kinda mood yer in.. :)

adios....
jor.dee....

On Fri, 24 Feb 1995, Fred Heutte wrote:
> Hey, why is this even an issue?   If the party gets busted, almost always
> the promoter has already collected 80% or more of what they're going to
> collect otherwise.  

The issue started because a party lost their space a few days before it 
was going to happen, and the DJ's still demanded to get paid.  No money 
was collected, and an enterprising DJ could probably still find work on a 
few days notice (hours maybe?).  Of course if a party were to get busted 
*while* it was in progress after a good chunk of change had been 
collected, it's a whole different ballgame even if the DJ didn't play.  

	Brian


From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 24 12:55:50 1995

From: Jonathan Tea <solrvibe@bga.com>
Message-Id: <199502242055.OAA23827@zoom.bga.com>
Subject: Chill (Drop it)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 14:55:46 -0600 (CST)

Content-Length: 1658

Precedence: bulk

Umm, can we drop this stupid thread now?  It's obvious everyone has
different opinions about what they scene can and should be.  I was attracted
to the rave scene first by the music and then by the fact that everyone here
was respectful of others' ideas.  What was that old saying... PLUR?

Does this not apply anymore?  Has rave changed so much that it's just like
every other crappy part of society?  Everyone here is at a different level
of experience, it's a constant learning process and that's a good thing.  

Let me ask you this:  when you went to your first rave, did someone come up
to you and say, "No clue.  You just don't get it man."  If they had, would
you still be raving?

Dammit!  You guys were the most loving, giving people last summer and were
so supportive of each other.  That's always what has made the SF scene so
special.  Did we decide to give that up?  I didn't get the fucking memo.

Everyone's got their opinions, some of them you'll agree with, some of them
you won't.  But we're all human beings trying to do something positive here
in this scene, and we all deserve a fucking chance.  If raving no longer has
anything to do with trying to make things better, then I don't know what to
say.  Who's gonna rewrite the hyperreal archives?  I guess we gotta dump
that shit about PLUR and The Spirit of Raving.  (I for one still try to live
by what our good sister Laura wrote about PLUR.)

Hopefully the disrespect I've seen from a few do not speak for the
majority on this list.  If you still believe in what this scene was built
on, say something, otherwise I gotta start a new scene.

vibrating at the speed of love

solarvibe

On Fri, 24 Feb 1995, Michel Battaglia wrote:

> but *where would raves be without them*? It took dj's like Paul Oakenfold 
> and Danny Rampling to *bring the music to the people*..You would have NO 
> RAVE and NO MUSIC. If English DJ's hadn't brought Chicago acid house from 

uhhh... Paul Okenfield? hehehe yeah right. There has always places to go
in the states to hear house & acid since the begining. Of course it didn't
get big until they brought the *rave* buzzword back from England. The guys
who created & played the music (Knuckles, Pierre) had alot more to do with
it, but thats beside the point.

> but when you're spinning - you come to a point where you 
> either have to 1)start getting paid or 2) stop dj'ing, unless you're rich.i
> can't afford to be buying records to keep up. maybe *you* can...

I don't get all these people who are expecting to get paid money in return
for buying & researching music they supposedly love. They have this notion
that they are spending time & money, not that they are just doing what
they want to be doing. Ravers gotta pay for parties, they do it not
expecting to get paid back for having fun, Dj'ng is not work. If the love you
get from playing the music for yourself *aint enough* & you have to go out and
play parties & get *paid* for it to be worth your while then you probably
should quit. I hate this notion of keeping up, this aint a race. I spend
all I can buying what *I* like, not trying to keep up with the latest hits.

> NOTHING is free, man.

Gee, I didn't know they had put a monetary value on love, fun, happiness
& anger already. I guess I just don't keep up.

> What does this matter? I see you as making statements you have no idea 
> about - being completely disrespectful, contradicting and mindless. This 
> scene you claim to love so dearly works in ways you haven't grasped yet - 
> my advice is start learning.
> 
> I have taken offense to 
> your statement that I mentioned earier.
> 
> The reason that i back up *evrything* that sami said is that what you 
> said has *ANGERED* me. You embody *everything* i hate about ravers today. 
> Everything you said...i've bitched about it endlessly...you said things 
> that *appalled* me - and the basic fact of that matter is you really nave 
> no idea...your naivete doesn't bother me as much as your statements do.
> 
> Brian, i'm sure you do mean well...but you have *alot* of learning to do 
> by your statements. I don't doubt that you're a nice person, just 
> ignorant of how things work and a little self-centered in your view of 
> this scene. If you'd like to know ,i'll be glad to tell you...Until 
> then....realize that there is alot here that you do not understand.

You are so fucking self-rightous man. Who put you on the know-it-all
pedastal above all those supposedly ignorant ravers. While I may have
disagreed with some of the statements made by Brian, I was sickened by
this out and out attack on him made by you. There is no "right way" for
somebody to think.
	josh

Matt is right:
>If you book a DJ and then call them the evening of the party to tell them
>it has been cancelled you have effectively ruined that DJ's chances at
>making money that night.  Therefore I think it's a bit harsh to
>automatically jump on a DJ for wanting to get payed even if he doesn't

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 16:22:37 -0800 (PST)
From: Jim Trickett <trickett@helix.net>

Subject: Re: DJ's vs Music
In-Reply-To: <Pine.2.4.55.9502241426.A1711@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.SUN.3.91.950224161237.22281C-100000@trance.helix.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



On Fri, 24 Feb 1995, Josh Bates wrote:

> I don't get all these people who are expecting to get paid money in return
> for buying & researching music they supposedly love. They have this notion
> that they are spending time & money, not that they are just doing what
> they want to be doing. Ravers gotta pay for parties, they do it not
> expecting to get paid back for having fun, Dj'ng is not work. If the love you
> get from playing the music for yourself *aint enough* & you have to go out and
> play parties & get *paid* for it to be worth your while then you probably
> should quit. I hate this notion of keeping up, this aint a race. I spend
> all I can buying what *I* like, not trying to keep up with the latest hits.

Of course these djs are doing what they want to be doing, but that 
doesn't mean they shouldn't get paid for it.  Yes, ravers pay to go to 
parties, but most have jobs and such and going to parties is done in 
their leisure time - committed djs pretty much devote their lives to 
music, and I for one appreciate it enough that I'm willing to pay for 
it.  As for djs quitting if they expect to be paid...well, I'd hate to 
see it, as most of my favorite djs wouldn't be able to keep spinning, as 
they'd have to find other means of paying rent, buying food, etc.  I'm 
glad you buy what you like, and the djs I know do the same, but in order 
to buy enough music to play good, original sets week after week, they 
need to get paid for the job they do.  And yes, djing is work.  For 
many, it's a full time job.  Just because you enjoy doing something 
doesn't mean it's not work...
Just my $.02.

Jim

My agents report medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU said:
> One Brian points out the sad truth:
> >> Ya gotta pay for the food even if no one comes to ur restaurant...:)
> And the other one sed:
> >If life were about economics no one would throw parties, much less attend 
> >them.  
> I agree more with the second brian (of equaly hard spelling)
> Folks, parties are about fun. remeber that. Not avbout who was there, who
> knows who, who was on the list, who is the baddest mofo, who has ID.....are
> we losing site? 

milton, i understand what you are saying, but understand this: parties don't
just materialize out of thin air. love is just not enough: at a bare minimum,
promoters are going to have to PAY for venue(?), sound, and lights, and the dj
is going to have to pay for records. all the love we can possibly generate 
isn't going to make Massive Amplifier Corporation X and Struggling To Survive
Smalltime Record Label Y *give* you what you need to throw a party. so, 
an expense in generated and the money has to be brought from somewhere. as
much as it would be lovely for promoters and dj's to do it for free for the
love of it, fact is...

why the hell should promoters and dj's be expected to bear the entire cost
of the scene?

with a very few, and i mean VERY FEW, exceptions, there isn't anyone getting
rich off the scene (drugs excluded). i'm not saying all djs should be paid
$400 an hour, nor am i saying all parties should be $20. i'm just saying that
nothing is free. and thats the truth, ruth. 

i think what some are relly losing sight of is the fact that economics and
a good strong community vibe are *not* diametrically opposed. like it or
not they have always been working together and until the world become one
huge commune (yeah right), thats just the way its going to be.

You say "parties are about fun". well, for those throwing it, its about fun
too but fun on a different level, [ideally] the joy of bringing fun to others.
fact is you are running around so much trying to keep things together that
often the promoters/djs get very little chance to actualy sit back and enjoy
the party. to take a more standardized view, the promoters/djs are creating and
the attendees, of which this list seems to comprise mostly of, are CONSUMING.
granted, the crowd creates too, because there wouldn't be anything to consume
if there was nobody there, but isn't that the way it is with all media, all
art? the promoter/dj creates a space where that can happen. and creating that
environment takes bucks. so whats wrong with that? nothing.

i've totally forgotten what i started talking about
please note that this is really a reply to the last several posts i've seen
and not necessarily yours, milton :)

oh yeah! i think the whole dj+money+canceled show thing is easily
resolved by taking mikebee's suggestion, that is writing up real live 
contracts, then if the dj doesn't show there is recourse... i can see this
becoming more and more the standard, especially (and probably only) where
big names and big money (hence big risk) is involved.

gee, be glad i only get sfraves at work kids, that means i won't be posting
any more after 5:00pm

namaste
skye

On Fri, 24 Feb 1995, Jim Trickett wrote:

> Of course these djs are doing what they want to be doing, but that 
> doesn't mean they shouldn't get paid for it.  Yes, ravers pay to go to 
> parties, but most have jobs and such and going to parties is done in 
> their leisure time - committed djs pretty much devote their lives to 
> music, and I for one appreciate it enough that I'm willing to pay for 
> it.  As for djs quitting if they expect to be paid...well, I'd hate to 
> see it, as most of my favorite djs wouldn't be able to keep spinning, as 
> they'd have to find other means of paying rent, buying food, etc.  I'm 
> glad you buy what you like, and the djs I know do the same, but in order 
> to buy enough music to play good, original sets week after week, they 
> need to get paid for the job they do.  And yes, djing is work.  For 
> many, it's a full time job.  Just because you enjoy doing something 
> doesn't mean it's not work...
> Just my $.02.
 
I'm not saying that dj's should not get paid. I just don't beleive they should
be doing something they love(d) for work. If you need every single gig
to have a roof over your head & food in your stomach you are going to
do things you otherwise would not do. Alot of those guys have been
playing 3+ nights a week for the past 3 years with no break, while it is
respectable that they are still able to do this I don't beleive most of
them realy enjoy playing anymore. Don't you think that is unhealthy for
both the individuals artform & the scene. As for djs quiting if they
expected to be paid, I was talking about up&comers/beginers buying all
those records cause they were hoping/expecting to get paid back for them.
Most of the big dj's don't even buy that many records anymore, most of the
"hits" are gotten free as promos & they got enough to last em' years already.
	josh

Heres my 2 cents worth, now lets let this thread die hard.
  I know two kinds of D.J.s   ...   Those who PLAY records...and love it 
  and those who WORK and generally bitch about it. after all you dont go
to a rave to WORK your records. Agreed records are tools to move people,
but the folks who PLAY thier records are ussually a lot more busy than
those who treat it as work. After all most people would agree WORK SUCKS,
I'd rather spend my time PLAYING anyway.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Feb 24 20:23:32 1995

	id UAA26221; Fri, 24 Feb 1995 20:23:20 -0800
Message-Id: <199502250423.UAA26221@netcom22.netcom.com>
To: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Cc: medeiros@nature.berkeley.edu
Subject: Cops N' Robbers N' Drug Dealers OH MY! (was Re: Dr. Strangelove (or, how i learned to stop worrying and love the permits) )
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 23 Feb 95 12:00:23 PST."
             <199502232000.MAA26271@nature.Berkeley.EDU> 
Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 20:23:19 -0800
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Milton (medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU) sez:
>Permits are about money. Permits are about organized crime (cops) getting a
>piece of the action. Al Capone dealed in extortion/protection. What's
>different from the cops in SF? You put 20 cents in the meter for
>protection, or you lose $27. You pay a shitload of money for a liscense to
>entertain 18 year olds, or they shut you down and haul you off. What's the
>difference? They're legal, gangsters ain't. Cops got the edge. that's all. 

Niels rants for no particular reason...

Yes, it's a racket. Go beyond the whole permit thing and look at the
places where the big bucks are being spent, and it's clear that  both
sides have much to profit from. Take the War on Drugs. The drug dealers
love it because it allows them to maintain high prices, pocket huge
profits, and make lots of money simply because they are operating
outside of the law. The cops love it too -- they get direct kickbacks
from seized drug property (houses, cars, boats, planes), they get paid
a lot of money because they are dealing with danger, they occasionally
get to steal drug-dealer money and supplies before it gets impounded as
evidence. It keeps lawyers, DA's, judges, prison guards, prison food
suppliers and prison construction companies well funded. A classic
"racket" -- both sides got the edge. And those of us on the outside are
the ones that lose....

Nobody wants to rethink "the system" because the system, good or bad,
is keeping a lot of people employed and fed. And that's ultimately what
people want and vote for. Any rational talk about legalization or
controlled distribution gets drowned out because $$$ rule over
rationality. We are addicted to this "war" because our addiction keeps
both sides armed and dangerous, powerful, and employed. Including
politicians and their "take back the streets" hype.

However, we need to separate the "system" from the "individuals". It
might be easy for some of us college educated folks to diss a cop
because they are working that job, as opposed to a more "politically
correct" job. But perhaps they didn't have the opportiunities we had
that allow us to vote with our feet and choose a less controversial
career path? Perhaps they need to put food on the table for their
family and children, and who are we to judge the compromises they have
to make in order to get by? (Yes, you can go too far with this line of
"just following orders" "just doing my job" and "not my responsibility"
thinking, but hopefully you get the point)....

Yes there are bad cops and good cops, just like there are bad and good
people. And just like any other *person* a cop wants some respect, and
wants to be judged by their merits, and not by the clothes, uniform,
and job that they're doing. Give them a little respect and they may
treat you with respect. Give them attitude, and they will fuck with you
because they can (yes, this isn't good, but it's just the way things
are -- and it's not just cops that'll act this way -- anybody in a
position of power will use it sometimes). But give a person a chance to
use their position of power for "good" and they may very well surprise
you. A lot of people, unless they're really fucked up, prefer good over
bad, prefer helping over hurting. Even cops.

I recently had a reason to call the cops on someone who has been making
threats to my person and property. I just wanted a report on the logs
in case anything happened. So I invited them into my house, gave them
some soda,  told them about my problems, and had them give me some
advice on my rights in such situations while they were filing their
report. They were very friendly and helpful. Of course, these weren't
downtown SF cops, they're from the Ingleside Station, and perhaps they
don't have to deal w/ the kind of scumbags that downtown SF cops have
to deal with (SOMA drunk drivers, partying drunk/drugged fratboys,
people fighting, thieves, panhandlers, hustlers, and gangsters acting
out petty turf battles, etc). And of course, I had called them, they
hadn't come to me looking for trouble... nonetheless, I have a much
better view of some cops now than I did before my encounter.

While they were in my apartment, these cops also saw all my music
equipment and wanted to check out some of the stuff I was doing --
turned out both of the cops were musicians and were totally into music.
They saw my massive stereo setup, and they were looking at my CD
collection going  "cool" "yeah" and oohing and ahhing over my reggae
collection, but they weren't into techno at all.... Finally, they hit
my P-funk collection and wanted to hear what it sounded like on my
speakers ... Pretty soon I had these two cops w/ their guns and belts
and radios flapping around bopping around my apartment listening to
"Flashlight..." and "Up for the down stroke" with da boomin bass...
they were telling me all about the good old days when they were younger
and partying to all of George Clinton's hits ...

So I spent about 1/2 an hour just chatting with these guys about music
and whatever after they were done w/ business... It was kinda fun cuz
normally i never get a chance to just "hang" with cops and talk to them
AS PEOPLE. I know that if I ever have any reason to be on their wrong
side (like getting pulled over by them) I'll recognize them, they'll
recognize me and hopefully give me some respect!

So like I said, cops are people too. Get rid of the "us vs them"
thinking and maybe we can all get along, even if we don't agree w/ some
of the laws they're enforcing. Just give 'em a little respect, don't
get in their face too hard, and don't give them attitude just because
they're doing what they're doing.... remember that they are working a
stressful, dangerous job and are probably more on edge than most of us.

PS: For the most part, I'll give more props to a cop walking a street
beat than some scumbag investment banker or stockbroker or lawyer
trying to sell the american public down the river so they can buy
another BMW and whatever else it is they need to fullfill their yuppie
dreams. But then again, I typically side with people that work for a
living rather than parasites (aka "upper management", financial types,
etc).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==     Niels Mayer -- http://cyborganic.com/~niels -- mayer@netcom.com     ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Dear sfraves;

	Just for the record; I don't have any hard feeling to all the 
comments I got back with regard to the DJ's vs Music thread. As I've said 
I don't mind critisum; I do mind the characater assination stuff; I just 
don't feel that it helps in someone tring to make or get his or her point 
across. It just closes the channels that are open; and most of the time; 
puts people backs up against a wall so even if they know their wrong in 
their hearts and minds they won't admitt it. I used to do this myself and 
found out by people telling me that it just didn't work; and that 
sometimes you just can't make the other party see your way. But when you 
use characater assination it just makes things worst. How many times have 
you gotten into a debate over something called the other party names  and 
stuff and had them say; oh your absolutely right I agree with you 
totally; its never happened to me; the oppsite usually happens.. I just 
don't feel it helps; I am much more interested in how something I said 
makes you feel. Like if I said something like I think there not enough 
emphaisi placed on the music and to much on the DJ's. And you responded 
to me by saying well Brian thats makes me very angry to hear that and 
this is why. Isn't that what your tring to communicate to me in the first 
place. Some of you did do that; and I want to make it clear that peoples 
feeling are very important to me; that I always have time to hear them, 
and I also understand that its riskey to do that. This is why I try and 
make it safe; I hope that I will never invalidate someone elses feelings; 
but being human myself I image I have and will on a rair occasion. But if 
we talk about it I sure than we can resolve it. Even if we don't agree; 
I'm still interested in how something I said makes you feel; and I 
promise I won't minize it. So please leave the character stuff out of it; 
I think were all worth wild; loving, capable intelligent people; who all 
have something important and meaningful  to say. Because I do and your no 
different than me. I really mean it when I say  the message is love; I 
have a smile and a kind word for everyone I meet most of the time. So 
like Amy said please be kind to one another; there are so many forces out 
there tring to tear us apart lets not be part of that; I remeber a song 
my Depeche Mode Flies on the Wind Screen. We have so little time compared 
to the big picture here on this planet; and are constantly reminded about 
death; lets try and live and love each day like its our last. I have no 
time to hate!!!!!

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		   aka Brian darkness, LMT/BSEE

... stop wasting time let's do it today.

My humble first post from here in the Northwest.

1) People are people, no matter how old. We all have different things to
learn from the world and each other at different points in our lives. One
of the reasons I enjoy raves is that (at least here in Vangroovy) they are
the only all ages events happening. That means I can freely meet and
interact with a wider range of people.

2) Music makers vs. DJs? Huh? I thought the basis of _house_ music was that
the DJ was the music maker. Bring in some rekkids, your drum machine, a
sampler, a synth. You spin the beats & samples & riffs right into your set.
With vinyl your a DJ, without vinyl your a musician... humm, where's the
line? ...and as for DJ worship, the only reason I like to spin is because I
love the music and I can dance behind the tables as well as in front
(though, maybe not so vigourously).

Big rain-drenched hugs,
lar

>Amusing Rants from Dave Winer's Desktop
>Posted on 2/17/95; 1:22:06 PM PST

>
>  Imagine if, at the dawn of the nuclear age, a US Senator proposed a bill
>  that required that all uses of nuclear technology be peaceful. The
>  law would only be enforcable within the borders of the United States.
>
>  You could admire the spirit of the idea, but we all know it couldn't
>  possibly have worked.
>
>  You'd have to conclude that the senator didn't understand how
>  nuclear technology works.
>
>  Senator Jim Exon (D-NE) -- the man who proposed the Communications
>  Decency Act of 1995 -- clearly doesn't understand how online
>  technology works.
>
>  According to the Electronic Messaging Association, info@ema.org,
>  "In an effort to stamp out digital pornography, the act makes all
>  telecommunications providers doing business in the United States
>  (from the telephone companies all the way down to offices that use
>  LANs) liable for the content of anything sent over their networks. To
>  avoid the possibility of tens of thousands of dollars in fines and up
>  to two years in jail, business owners would be forced to police their
>  networks and monitor in advance all messages sent over them."
>
>  I understand that there's actually a serious possibility that this
>  legislation will pass. In preparation, I was going to suggest that we
>  all establish dial-in accounts to Internet nodes in Canada or
>  Mexico. But even that won't work. The phone companies would be liable
>  for the content of our calls out of the country.
>
>  No one is going to be willing to assume responsibility for other
>  people's postings. We have a shortage of connectivity right now.
>  This will make it impossible for the new industries, that we need, to
>  develop.
>
>  Senator Exon doesn't get it. The net is a global thing. The US Senate
>  can't control it. Australia is almost as close as Sausilito. The US is
>  just one country. He doesn't get to say what goes on the net.
>
>  But he can keep Americans from using the net.
>
>  Think about it folks. How much value do you place on electronic mail?
>  What would you do if two months from now you can't do email anymore? You
>  don't think it can happen? The experts think you're wrong.
>
>  This bill would devastate the US online industry, which is already
>  suffering from great growing pains. And it totally fucks the people
>  of the United States who want to be online.
>
>  Let's stop this madness, ASAP.
>
>  Dave Winer
>
>  PS: Aside from that, Exon's goal is offensive. He doesn't say the
>  Internet should only be used for peaceful purposes, he says we can't
>  talk about sex on the Internet. I guess Senator Exon is a tough
>  customer too.
>
>  PPS: What's the answer? We need legislation that says that all our
>  rights to free speech guaranteed under the Constitution apply to
>  speech on electronic networks.
>

On Fri, 24 Feb 1995, Josh Bates wrote:

> I'm not saying that dj's should not get paid. I just don't beleive they should
> be doing something they love(d) for work. If you need every single gig
> to have a roof over your head & food in your stomach you are going to
> do things you otherwise would not do. Alot of those guys have been
> playing 3+ nights a week for the past 3 years with no break, while it is
> respectable that they are still able to do this I don't beleive most of
> them realy enjoy playing anymore. Don't you think that is unhealthy for

Don't know about the djs in SF (I'm waaaay up in Vancouver B.C.) but 
here, one dj in particular comes to mind: Markem, formerly from LA.  He 
has three regular nights in local spots, plus any parties he plays on 
weekends, and he's still one of the nicest people I've met and remains 
very positive about his music and playing it.  He feeds off the energy of 
the crowd and you can just tell that he loves it, and loves playing a 
part in the creation of it.  I don't think playing/loving the music and 
being paid are mutually exclusive.  But, you do, and I can respect that.  
It seems we just have different beliefs and I'm happy with that - I don't 
intend to scream from a soapbox in order to try to change your mind...

Jim



From sfraves-owner  Sat Feb 25 08:56:57 1995

Dear Sfraves;

	Well with a review I'm supoosed to be objective right; ok. First 
I would like to say that personnally I had and Ok time last night. The 
music was heavy trance very trance or trance trance trance; thats why I 
say For Sure, the visiuals I thought by far where the best I've seen that 
were obviously theme based; good produuction. Everything else seemed 
great.

	But my personal view is; its was my first time at Cearsars Latin 
Plalace and it jsut had to weirdest feel to me; I felt like outsider 
renting some land in a forgien hositile country. I have a bunch of 
liberal bummer stickers on my car ProChoice; Kill your television; Fight 
Aids not People with Aids ..etc maybe you have seem me a White Jeep 
Cherokee. Anyway I was putting my things in my car; and these three guys 
in the parking lot were throwing beer cans in my direction; it 5:30am i'm 
a lone ;yaeh right guys I'm going to start a fight with the 3 of you; 
dream on; get in my car and leave unmolested. 

	I thing the guys at Ravers did a fanstastic job for there first 
show; but I wouldn't go back to Cearser unless it was the only thing 
going.
	I rememeber back in those Punk days of mine; we rented a Elks 
Club in this neighborhood in Kensigten, Phila, PA; a very blue collor 
working class neighborhoor as are most in good old Phila. Well during the 
show a bunch of guys from the neighborhood came in and started clubing 
people and throwing M80's with bee bee clued to the outside of them into 
the crowd; it was really bad; and the cops didn;t do a thing.

	I would never what to see something like that happen here 
althought with the amount of hatred, and iggnorence on the streets 
Cearsers would have been a perfect place. But in there defense there 
security seemed pretty tight and organized; my car which was out in their 
parking lot with all my massage stuff in it; was undidtrubed; so I gave 
the parking lot attendent a fiver.

	All and all I thought it was a good party; I just didn't like the 
venue; it just had a weird feel to it. I asked a lot of people; they said 
the same thing. Good job guys(Ravers People); maybe a different venue 
next time, I'll definately go; if its not Cearsers.

		Peace & Love From Across Cyberspace
		    aka Brian darkness, LMT/BSEE

To: SFRaves <sfraves@sfraves.org>
Subject: Out a Sight & Re: GG Park party today
In-Reply-To: <199502261737.JAA16179@well.sf.ca.us>
Message-Id: <Pine.SOL.3.91.950226094232.25716A-100000@mercury>
Mime-Version: 1.0

Precedence: bulk



I called the Organic line and they had no mention of a free party today
on Sunday.  I had heard a rumor a few days back that mentioned a
possibly Wicked/Organic in the Park but I guess it's not true.  Organic
will be having a 2nd anniversary on March 11th.

-----

I went to the Out-A-Sight on Friday.  Mike and I made our trek to the
map point.  A quiet cafe with a short line.  A muddled Fisher Price
stereo rumbling as people were hanging out eating chips, smoking,
talking.  The directions weren't wrong, but we got lost anyway.  It was
right off of Mission.. near MOMA.  A map point near the party.  Thank
you folks!

A straight forward security, no problems.  A quick frisk and a metal
detector to check for weapons.  They should do these type of checks more
often.  They had a few rooms: two dance rooms, one small hallway
connecting the main dance room to the bar/chillout room.  To get to the main
room one had to climb up the stairs.

The sound in both rooms were too loud.  It was the first time I had to
wear ear plugs.  Kleenex this time, but I'll have to look at Larry's
tips for ear plugs because the highs were drowned out.  The bass in the
main room could have been a little stronger.

Since the music was too loud upstairs, I headed down to the bottom room.
Markie (?) was spinning some trip-hop, funk, a big mix of non-4/4 beats.
He also played Josh Wink's Acid Break part one.  I didn't stay for long;
it had a weird vibe.  Maybe its because I'm used to boom boom boom boom
rather than boom chik dum dum dak.

Went back up the main room.  Caught the end of Garth's (?) set and Spun
got on.  Don't what to say Spun.. didn't really pay attention.  THEN,
Robbie Hardkiss came on!  Wow!  There were times on the dance floor I
just stopped to look at him just groovin to the music, fixing the
beats, smoking his cigarette.. Does he usually use more than 2
turntables?  Beautiful layering... took the energy up and down,
sideways, diagonal.. what a mind workout.  It was interesting to hear a
lot of breaks, but they were not predictable. Its my first time hearing
him, but if this is usual, go dance to his music!

I for some reason danced sometimes to the background sounds.. the space
free flowing 'ambient' sounds going from here to nowhere.  Sort of like
doing Tai Chi to trippy dance music.


The visuals were not very good.  Pictures of the space, flowers,
silohuettes of naked woman, fractals, various odd pictures.  The SAME
ones all through the night.  At some points I wish they could have had
it turned off or had gone into some sort of interesting theme of
pictures. The visuals were projected right above the DJ.  I would have
liked to see the people dancing behind me, but the visual lights kept
getting in the way.

Two bathrooms; one in main room, on the bottom room.  (Do people ever
review bathrooms?)  The bottom room was dark but I felt bad for the DJs
because ever once in a while the bathroom lights would just flood the
room.  Maybe the promoters could use a red bulb instead of white.  Also,
the bottom room had a small down ramp that people did not see and saw
lots of people mis-stepping, losing their balance.  Bad accidents could
have happened there.

I thoroughly enjoyed myself.. and my wallet said to me the morning after
"You should let out sometimes, I don't like having to smell your hot
sweat all night!"  For $8 a very fun party.  Better than the Palladium
or City Nights.. ;)

Sun

Overall I had a good time at spread love, but as far as an objective 
rating for a rave, I say it was just ok.  The party was held at the old 
oasis, is not such a bad space.  I never did understand why more party's 
haven't been held there.  I like the access to the roof, which provided a 
nice place to chill and get some fresh air.  Unfortunately they closed it 
off not long after I got there about 2am. 
Some of the people working there seemed a little obsessive compulsive 
with their cleaning.  First they insisted on taking my water bottle at 
2am.  At least they provided cups after that, But I had to use about 5 
cups.  Everytime I left my cup, and it had water in it each time, I found 
it missing.  Even when I stood near it, I had to keep the clean up guy 
from taking it.
There weren't that many people there, and it seemed to take some time 
before people got into it.  Didn't care to much for charlete's set.  I'm 
not that good with recognizing dj's so excuse me if I make a mistake.  
She just about emptied the dance floor by the end of her set.  I'm not 
sure who came on next, but I thouroughly enjoyed that set.  
Unfortunatedly it ended about 4am when they closed the place.  Pretty 
early for a saturday night or any night.
Could have been better with more people and longer party.  Give me some 
good music and a dance floor and I'll usually have a good time.



peter

Two points.  One, it is not legislation that is needed to protect free
speech right, but rather for an electronic free speech case to come
before the Supreme Court.
Two, as I posted a few months ago, Newt is in favor of more freedom and
less government intrusion into the electronic networks, so this is
unlikely to pass the House.  (for more information, check out the
position paper at the WWW page at pff.org ).

Subject: Re: DJ's Vs Music
Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 18:24:23 GMT
Message-Id: <9502261224086987@tigerteam.org>
Organization: Tiger Team Buddhist Info Net:  Modem (510) 268-0102
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

Hello,

I think there is simply a small misunderstanding here on the part of
Brian D.  Let's see if I can explain it clearly...

In the old system, artists played music on stage and they also recorded
music which we listened to at home. In the late 70's, dance clubs became
popular where DJ's spun vinyl, matching beats to make a seamless groove.
Previously, dance clubs usually had live bands.

Then, in the 80's, house music was created where DJ's began to *create*
music by mixing together different elements.  In this music, the DJ's
*were* the artists.  Those who recorded the vinyl were *also* artists,
but that their art was *for* the DJ's, who were the ones who appreciated
it.

Then, some of the musicians who made especially popular vinyl that was
coveted by DJs (and had dancers asking the DJs - "what was that you just
spun") reverted back to the old system and began making LPs to sell to
people to listen to at home (eg 2 unlimited).

Thus, many of the most popular musicians who make vinyl for DJs now
*also* make LPs for people to listen to at home.

However, that is really two entirely different things.

The last time I was in the Bay Area, back in August, one of the
soul/dance FM stations had (on Friday at 4 PM) 4 DJs spinning on 8
turntables, a mixture of hip-hop and some house.  There was no way you
could identify any particular vinyl that was spun, but the result was
actually pretty good (unfortunately 99% of the time that station just
has top 40 pap).  The point is that what they created was *different*
from the vinyl they used to create it with.

So, since this seemed to provoke so much anger, instead I propose
that people respond postitively and post the DJ's and titles of their
favorite DJ tape(s)!

respect to all,

Ken

I'd say "ok" was generous.  The Oasis is the center point of San Francisco's
Little Tijuana District.  It was thankfully a cheap party - one that didn't
come together very well.  If anyone cares, the pacific connection was a loose
one.  Senor Love Daddy threw it.  

I was invited to a party (new nightclub) on Minna street that Saturday.  This
was a very nicely done acid jazz affair with dj's, a band in a great intimate
setting, and a kitchen for afterhours cooking ...  I don't really know if
this is has happened before or will happen again.  There is a jazzid up
connection (mushroom jazz).

There's gotta be something about taking a weekly to the weekend or a weekend
to the week that helps a party happen.  I suppose this is the thinking behind
map points and such.

hang in there,
Dave

Howard Stern talks about so much; where a little old lady while going
though the Mcdoonals drivethur spilled the hot coffee in her lap that she
had just purchased form them; and sued them and won something like
$1,000,000. With reference to mi nors the judges are even more leaient to
the claiment(the person sueing)

	I'm a health care profession Zack and I do really care about 
people; I became an engineer in hopes of changing the world in a positive 
way. I as engineer was never in charge of the important decsions and if I 
reached a point inthe company that I was making those decisons I wouldn't 
be doing the engineering(design) that I loved so much. But I found out 
that if I can change myself for the better; and if I help just one person 
in a positive way; than I can feel really good about that. The world is 
abig task to take on, and to change the world you must do it one person 
at a time. 

	I would like to appolloize for my sarcasstic remarks in the first 
letter I was just tring to me funny; sorry if you took them the wrong 
way; I quess I just didn't understand how frustrated you and your friends 
are about this whole issue. Well anyway Zack have a goodnight and 
pleasent raver dreams......:)

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995, Brian Darkness wrote:

> make the party not the DJ's; they are just the individuals who play the
> music for the people. In the end the people decide whats played not the

NOT TRUE. dj's don't just "play the muzik".  At least good dj's don't.  
there's so much more to being a good dj than beatmatching.  a dj works 
the crowd and brings the vibe to people around.  a shitty dj can play a 
few good tunes and make people dance, but it takes a good dj to really 
send people into the groove and get the muzik flowing right.

>  I think people put to much emphazies on
> who's spinning rather than on who's created the music, how many people can

acshully if you talk to any dj, they will put *a lot* of emphasis on who 
makes the muzik.  true, it's really unfortunate that most party attenders 
never bother finding out about the creators, but most dj's and others who 
buy muzik do.  Also, people like Josh Wink aren't just famous for their 
awesome dj'ing skills.  Winks also puts out some of the freshest records 
around and is really respected for his muzik. also many sf dj's such as 
harkiss, spun, doran, and tony make muzik too.

> requested to be paided to spin there. I don't like it when I hear about
> anyone working hard to put something together for the benefit of all and
> at the last minute due to things behond anyones control it going flatt. It

look at it from the dj's point of view.  what's he supposed to do.  
starve??  Also, speaking of 'for the benefit of all'  there are *lots* of 
dj's out there who are willing to spin for *free* if it's a free 
non-profit party.  so dj's out there do have plenty of love for the 
scene.  but if a person who puts together a party gets paid, the dj's 
should definitely get a piece of the action.

laters

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

----- Begin Included Message -----

>From anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl Mon Feb 27 04:01:29 1995
Return-Path: <anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl>
Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 11:41:57 +0000
From: cllv13 <cllv13@ccsun.strath.ac.uk>
To: 1-union@lever.com
Subject: On the Criminal Justice Act
Cc: anarchy-list@cwi.nl
X-Sun-Charset: US-ASCII
Content-Length: 3116
Sender: anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl
X-Lines: 80
Status: RO

Hi folks

This is the text of a leaflet handed out at an Anti-Criminal
Justice Act demo in Edinburgh, Scotland. The CJA is a piece
of nasty class based legalisation being used to increase
social atomisation and protect private property against those
who could use it (eg squatters) or those protesting injustice
(eg Hunt sabs or strikers).

Iain


Fight The Power!
Party Hard!


The Criminal Justice Act is bad news. That's clear. The government 
wants to make the rest of society as 
boring as they are! It attacks our freedom to 
party and protest. There's only one thing left for us to do. Kill 
this act by partying and protesting! Its up 
to us, no one else will do it for us.

While claiming the C.J.A. is to protect us, its 
clear that all it does is protect rich landowners, bosses and the 
state against the few "civil liberties" remaining for 
us. Most of the Act is concerned with criminalising all 
direct action and unauthorised demonstrations, particularly 
against pickets, hunt sabs and road protesters -
even hillwalkers. Its main aim is to give the police 
even more power - the right to stop and search anyone, 
an end to the right of silence, the introduction 
of plea bargaining, exclusion zones, "aggravated trespass" 
and paranoid "anti-terrorist" laws. The only 
freedom it protects is the freedom of power to do 
exactly what it wants....

We must recognise the C.J.A. for what it is, a piece 
of class based legislation for and by the rich and 
powerful. It was never just about targeting squatters, 
hunts sabs and ravers. It's a direct attack on all 
working class people. Liberal protest ain't going 
to work. Only direct action gets the goods. Why 
else is the C.J.A. trying to ban it?

Remember this is just the latest in a long series 
of attacks on our class. We need to link up all our 
struggles and fight to win. By fighting isolated 
struggles we can be picked off one by one. But by 
uniting together we can win. Just look at the Poll Tax. 

Our fight so far has some great features in it. Unofficial 
mass demos where we took over the streets and 
made them ours. D.I.Y. gigs, raves and parties which 
have raised lots of money and awareness for the fight 
as well as providing many a good night. Excellent 
pickets and solidarity marches. Over the country a 
network of mutual aid and support is spreading, a 
network of angry people who know how to party! 

We must organise and make all this stronger. By 
doing this we can make this act unworkable. By mass 
defiance, direct action  and solidarity we can win. 
So let's party and protest. We don't need boring speeches 
to tell us what's wrong or what to do. Its OUR 
lives, OUR liberties. We need to organise ourselves 
to take the power back. No one else is going to do it. 
No one else can. The only parties we need are the ones with 
loud music. The ones we organise ourselves. The ones 
that play OUR tunes. 

Let us experience the freedom of protest and party hard 
until the C.J.A. lies along side the Poll Tax in the 
dustbin of history. 

"If I can't dance then its not my revolution"
Emma Goldman, anarchist.
 




----- End Included Message -----

and a lot of rave music. The groovy thing was that everyone, and i do mean
everyone, got involved and started dancing. There were a bunch of school

groovy thing. once again a positive example of how groove and rhythm (which
are fundamental) united everyone.

>The music studio where I work is looking for interns.  This is the studio
>that is the home base of Sound Traffic Control (who put on the 3-D
>sound shows in November) and the new dark ambient label Asphodel.  We
>need smart, technologically savvy people, and it's a hip place with
>an underground feel, so I figgered sfraves was a good place to look...
>
>Thanks! -- Jessica Wing

>-----------
>
>
>       SAN FRANCISCO STUDIO NOW ACCEPTING DIGITAL AUDIO INTERNS
>
>
>Informusik Studios is now accepting interns who will learn and perform 
>various digital audio tasks including basic audio editing, digital 
>transfers, looping and sample processing. They will gain an understanding  
>of  the digital/analog  interface, MIDI applications, Macintosh-based 
>digital audio workstations and various samplers and processors through 
>exposure  to  a  unique  sound  environment  and  intensive  hands-on  
>experience.
>
>Informusik is a state-of-the-art digital and analog sound facility that 
>specializes in the design and utilization of an advanced, detailed sonic 
>environment for large-scale live audio productions in the Bay Area and 
>elsewhere.  We are also the home base of recording activities for several 
>unusual  record/CD labels.  We are a non-commercial space; our musical 
>focus dwells in the areas of ambient, cinematic, ethno-electronic, 
>classical, gothic/industrial, and other experimental or non-mainstream 
>forms of music.  
> 
>DESIRED QUALIFICATIONS: We are seeking trustworthy, enthusiastic, highly 
>motivated people who have a familiarity with the Macintosh, some music or 
>sound experience, an accurate mind, and a desire to advance in the area of 
>music production and/or digital audio editing.  Transportation by car is a 
>must, and interns must be willing to work off-hours (any time between seven 
>in the evening and noon, or weekends). We require a commitment of at least 
>two days a week. DJ's, musicians, composers, engineers, beat & bass 
>programmers, technicians, and sound sculpturists are encouraged to apply, 
>as all special skills may be put to use.
>
>PAY:  All training is unpaid.  Once interns are fast and productive at a 
>given task, they could become qualified for an above-minimum-wage salary 
>according to their demonstrated ability.  Tasks and payment will be 
>adjusted based on individual capabilities; there is definitely room to 
>advance here!
>
>TO REPLY: Send a note describing your experience and interests via e-mail 
>to naut@netcom.com.
>
>          THANK YOU!

In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9502261805.A4753-0100000@liberty.liberty.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9502271437.A4980-0100000@freenet3.scri.fsu.edu>
